questions.text: 1. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication of fibrinolytic therapy for the management of myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
The absolute contraindication of fibrinolytic therapy is suspicion of aortic dissection.

Clear contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic agents:

* History of cerebrovascular hemorrhage at any time

* Non-hemorrhagic stroke or any other cerebrovascular event within the past year

* Marked hypertension (systolic arterial pressure >180 mmHg and/or a diastolic pressure >110 mmHg)

* Suspicion of aortic dissection, and active internal bleeding (excluding menses).  

Relative contraindications to fibrinolytic therapy, which require the assessment of the risk-to-benefit ratio:

* Current use of anti-coagulants (INR ≥2) (Option A)

* Recent (<2 weeks) invasive or surgical procedure or prolonged (>10 min) cardiopulmonary resuscitation (Option B)

* Known bleeding diathesis

* Pregnancy (Option D)

* Hemorrhagic ophthalmic condition (e.g., hemorrhagic diabetic retinopathy),

* Active peptic ulcer disease

* History of severe hypertension that is currently adequately controlled.

Pearl PM0603: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

* Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage

* Anistreplase

* Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

* Alteplase - has the shortest half-life

* Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose

* Reteplase

questions.text: 2. A patient presents with tinnitus and hearing loss. CT of the brain showed a tumor at the cerebellopontine angle. An image from the biopsy is shown below. What does the area marked with an arrow represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Verocay bodies, which are found in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that often arise from cranial and peripheral nerves and exhibit Schwann cell differentiation. They can be sporadic or associated with neurofibromatosis-1 (NF1) or occur as vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma) in cases of neurofibromatosis-2 (NF2).

They present with features of nerve compression involving both the adjacent structures and the nerve involved. Most tumors occur in the cranium as acoustic neuromas that affect vestibular branch of VIII cranial nerve near the cerebellopontine angle. They present with tinnitus, hearing loss, and symptoms resulting from compression of the brainstem and cerebellum.

Microscopically, they are comprised of a mixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively. 

* Antoni A areas are dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern

* The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

* Antoni A area leaves central nuclear-free zones surrounded by the palisading of nuclei, resulting in the formation of structures termed Verocay bodies.





Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin. They are seen in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: 3. A 57-year-old man complains of shortness of breath and tachypnea on post-op day 2 following emergency surgery for a ruptured appendix. He is now requiring oxygen via a face mask to keep his oxygen saturation above 94%. His chest radiograph is given below. Which of the following treatment strategies is least likely to be beneficial in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the chest radiograph point to a diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Surfactant replacement has no role in the management of patients with ARDS. 

ARDS refers to an acute onset and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema that occurs due to endothelial injury in the pulmonary capillaries due to inflammation. The diagnostic criteria for ARDS include:

* PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 300 mmHg

* Acute onset (within 1 week of a clinical insult)

* Chest radiograph shows diffuse bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema

* Absence of any left atrial hypertension (ie, pulmonary edema is not due to a cardiac cause)

Conditions associated with direct lung injury like pneumonia, aspiration of gastric contents, pulmonary contusion, near-drowning and toxic inhalational injury are associated with ARDS. Systemic conditions causing indirect lung injury and ARDS include sepsis, severe trauma (head injury, burns, multiple bone fractures), multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.

The chest radiograph of a patient with ARDS will show diffuse bilateral alveolar infiltrates with a classic ground-glass appearance consistent with pulmonary edema that can be difficult to distinguish from left ventricular failure. 

The main treatment strategy which has been shown to reduce mortality in patients is low tidal volume ventilation (option C) (6 mL/kg of predicted body weight). Conventional tidal volume ventilation leads to overdistension injury because the lung in ARDS is already consolidated and any attempt to push more air through it will lead to barotrauma. Apart from this, high PEEP(option A), prone position (option B), early neuromuscular blockade, and use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)  may also be useful. Management strategies that have not been shown to improve the outcome in ARDS patients include glucocorticoids, surfactant replacement, anti-inflammatory therapies like NSAIDs and inhaled vasodilators.

Pearl PM0464: Indications of Mechanical Ventilation

* Direct measurement

* Arterial oxygen tension <50 mm Hg on room air

* Arterial CO 2 tension >50 mm Hg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis

* Derived indices

* Pa O 2 /F IO 2 ratio <300 mm Hg

* PA–a o 2 gradient >350 mm Hg

* V D /V T >0.6

* Clinical indices

* Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

* Mechanical indices

* Tidal volume <5 mL/kg

* Vital capacity <15 mL/kg

* Maximum inspiratory Force > −25 cm H 2 O

questions.text: 4. Siponimod is used as a first-line drug in the treatment of multiple sclerosis, with a clinical pattern shown in the image below. What does siponimod act on?
questions.solution:
Siponimod is a sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P1 and S1P5 selective) modulator, which is used as a first-line drug in the treatment of secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS), which is shown in the graph. 

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system (CNS) characterized by inflammation, demyelination, scarring, and neuronal loss, leading to a relapsing or progressive course. Common symptoms include sensory disturbances (paresthesias, hypesthesia), weakness, optic neuritis, diplopia, and vertigo. Three clinical types of MS have been identified as shown in the image:-

* Relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS)

* Secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS)

* Primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS)



Secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS) starts as discrete episodes of neurological dysfunction and deteriorates over time. Permanent disabilities are seen, and the patients do not return to baseline neurological functions, as opposed to relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.

Other options

Option A: Carnitine palmitoyl transferase inhibitors, such as etomoxir, have shown positive advancements in the treatment of multiple sclerosis in mouse models, due to their effects on fatty acid oxidation. 

Option B: Natalizumab, an anti-α4 integrin monoclonal antibody, is responsible for preventing lymphocytes from entering the central nervous system by inhibiting their binding to endothelial cells. Thus, it is used in the treatment of rapid relapsing multiple sclerosis (RRMS).

Option D: Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase inhibitor, mycophenolate mofetil, is used for prophylaxis in organ transplant patients.

questions.text:
5. A 15-year-old patient, who has chronic asthma with mild severity and occasional exacerbations, is on regular use of MDI-containing steroids. Which of the following steroid is likely being used?

MDI - Metered dose inhaler
questions.solution:
Metered dose inhaler contains an inhaled type of steroid. Therefore, budesonide is the likely steroid being used. 

Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are glucocorticoids that have high topical and low systemic action. The commonly used ICS are:

* Beclomethasone dipropionate

* Budesonide

* Fluticasone

* Ciclesonide

They act by suppressing bronchial inflammation, increasing PEFR (peak expiratory flow rate), thereby reducing the use of inhalational beta2-agonist. They prevent acute attacks of asthma but are not effective during acute asthma or in status asthmaticus. 

Regular low-dose ICS can be started as part of Step-2 management of asthma and continued along with other add-ons according to the type of asthma. In seasonal asthma, regular low-dose ICS is given 3-4 weeks before an anticipated attack. ICS is indicated in patients with persistent asthma requiring a daily dose of beta 2 agonists, and those who taper oral steroids require additional inhalational steroids to prevent withdrawal symptoms. High-dose ICS is useful in severe COPD with exacerbations.

ICS is given through MDI, nebulizer, or dry powder inhaler forms. Hoarseness of voice, sore throat, dysphonia, and oropharyngeal candidiasis are a few of the side effects that can be prevented by the use of a spacer to reduce the drug deposition from the mucosa.

Other options:

Option A: Hydrocortisone is a potent systemic glucocorticoid that is used to treat status asthmaticus. 

Option B: Dexamethasone is a systemic steroid that is used in inflammatory and allergic conditions. 

Option D: Methylprednisolone is a systemic steroid that is primarily used in immunosuppression therapy, such as post-renal transplant and nonresponsive active rheumatoid arthritis.

Pearl PM2453: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2025)

Asthma management - GINA 2025

questions.text: 6. A 24-year-old male was brought to the hospital with sudden onset abdominal pain and vomiting. During clinical examination, maximum tenderness was present over McBurney's point. Which of the following imaging studies is highly effective as well as accurate in diagnosing the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of acute abdominal pain with maximal tenderness over McBurney's point is suggestive of acute appendicitis. A CT scan is the most effective and accurate imaging modality used to diagnose this condition.

The diagnosis of appendicitis on CT is based on the appearance of a thickened, inflamed appendix with surrounding “stranding” indicative of inflammation. The thickened inflamed wall and mural enhancement give an appearance known as a target sign. CT scans are operator-independent and they are easy to interpret.

Ultrasound provides the advantage of avoiding ionizing radiation but it is highly operator dependent. In pediatric and pregnant patients, ultrasound can be preferred to avoid the risk of radiation exposure. MRI is typically reserved for use in pregnant patients.

Acute appendicitis typically presents with abdominal pain that is initially difficult to localize. This pain arises from discomfort in the midgut due to inflammation and blockage of the appendix. It often begins in the periumbilical region and is accompanied by loss of appetite, feelings of nausea, and typically one or two instances of vomiting that occur after the pain starts. Loss of appetite is a consistent and helpful symptom, especially in children who almost always experience vomiting.

The tenderness associated with acute appendicitis is located at a point called McBurney point, which is positioned one-third the distance between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus. Pointing sign, Rovsing's sign, Psoas sign, and Obturator sign are some of the signs to be elicited in a patient with appendicitis.

The Alvarado scoring system is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis.

Pearl PM1317: Alvarado Scoring System

Findings | Points Migratory right iliac fossa pain | 1 Anorexia | 1 Nausea / vomiting | 1 Tenderness in right iiliac fossa | 2 Rebound tenderness right iliac fossa | 1 Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C | 1 Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L | 2 Shift to the left of neutrophils | 1

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

7. A 19-year-old trekking enthusiast embarks on a month-long trek across the Himalayas. Which of the following physiological adaptations would you expect to see in him at high altitudes following acclimatization?
* Erythropoietin secretion increases 
* Tissue mitochondria increase in number
* Tissue myoglobin decreases
* Tissue content of cytochrome oxidase also increases
* pH of blood increases
questions.solution:
Myoglobin increases to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues in high altitudes following acclimatization.

Compensatory mechanisms that are carried out to increase altitude tolerance are called acclimatization. 

The following are the physiological changes that occur during acclimatization:

* Hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis and shift of the oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left (and shifts to the right after acclimatization).

* Increased erythropoietin secretion, leading to an increase in circulating red blood cells

* Increased number of mitochondria

* Increased myoglobin to facilitate the movement of O2 into the tissues

* Increased tissue cytochrome oxidase

* Increased sympathetic tone

* Renal suppression of carbonic anhydrase and excretion of dilute alkaline urine bring the pH of the blood to normal.

* Decreased maximal exercise capacity (by ~1% for every 100 meters gained above 1500 meters)

Pearl PM1009: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: 8. A post-cataract surgery patient who had the surgery 3 months back presents with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. On fundoscopy, there is a honeycomb appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and a honeycomb appearance on fundoscopy is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows loss of foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  honeycomb appearance. In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:



Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B: Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:



Option C: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:



Option D: Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

They can present in different patterns such as:

* Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 

* Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.

* Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It is indicated when the patient is symptomatic.



Pearl PM2181: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

* Acute post-operative endophthalmitis

* Retained lens matter

* Corneal edema

* Wound leak and dehiscence

* Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

* Posterior capsule opacification (most common)

* Delayed-onset post-operative endophthalmitis

* Cystoid macular edema

* Secondary glaucoma

* Retinal detachment

* Intraocular lens malpositions:

* Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium

* Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation

* Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation

* Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: 9. During a diabetes education session, participants are asked to demonstrate insulin injection practices after an explanation. One does it correctly, the other asks for clarification. This scenario highlights which component of the communication process?
questions.solution:
The given scenario, highlighting communication, where one participant demonstrates insulin injection correctly while the other seeks clarification, showcases the component of effect (feedback).

Effect/Feedback is the response from the audience to the sender. It shows whether the message was understood or accepted. In interpersonal communication, feedback is immediate; in mass communication, it may take time and is gathered through surveys or interviews. It gives the sender a chance to adjust the message and make it more understandable and acceptable.

The correct order for the process of communication is:  Sender(source) → Message(content) → Channel (medium)→ Receiver (audience)→ Feedback(effect).

Other options:

Option A: The content(message) is the information/instructions that the sender wants to convey.

Option B: The medium (channel) represents the physical method that carries communication between the sender and receiver. It includes mass media, folk media and interpersonal communication.

Option D: The receiver (audience) represents the person or the group for which the message is intended.

questions.text: 10. Which of the following disorders is assumed to be present in any paediatric case presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly, unless proven otherwise?
questions.solution:
A pediatric case presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly is presumed to have esophageal variceal bleeding until proven otherwise.

The upper GI endoscopy provides a definitive diagnosis and aids in predicting the risk of bleeding with an option to treat via band ligation or sclerotherapy.

Blood transfusions, vasoactive medications (such as octreotide), short-term antibiotic use, and endoscopy for ligation or sclerotherapy, are all important components of the management of acute variceal bleeding. When variceal bleeding is not responding to medication or endoscopic therapy, a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt should be considered.

Nonselective β blockade and obliteration of varices through repeated ligation or sclerotherapy treatments are used in secondary prophylaxis to lessen bleeding recurrence. 

Prolapse gastropathy secondary to emesis, Mallory-Weiss syndrome and peptic ulcer are all differential diagnoses for gastrointestinal bleeding in childhood.

questions.text: 11. Identify the type of MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T1-weighted image as the CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, but the most classic ones are T1- and T2-weighted imaging.

In T1 images, CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

In T2 images, CSF is bright/hyperintense, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. (water is white on T2, so is CSF)

The following images are T1 and T2 images:



Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. So, CSF is dark, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. 

The following shows FLAIR image:



Short-tau inversion recovery (STIR) is an inversion-recovery technique that nulls fat. So, fat is black.

questions.text: 12. A massive flood disrupts the healthcare in a coastal area. In this post-disaster period, which of the following diseases is least likely to appear immediately as an outbreak?
questions.solution:
Dengue will not appear immediately. Vector-borne diseases may take several weeks to reach epidemic levels.

The most commonly reported disease outbreak following a disaster is gastroenteritis, like cholera (Option A). Outbreaks of gastroenteritis are mainly due to overcrowding, population displacement, and a contaminated water supply. Acute respiratory infections like influenza (Option B) are also commonly reported in the displaced population. But vector-borne diseases like malaria and dengue take several weeks to reach epidemic levels.

Immediately following a disaster, the most critical health care is treating the casualties and preventing the spread of communicable diseases. Disasters can increase the transmission of communicable diseases for various reasons, such as overcrowding and poor sanitation, population displacement, which can lead to the spread of diseases to which the migrants or indigenous people are susceptible, contamination of the water supply and damage to sewer systems, and displacement of animals, domestic and wild, which carry zoonoses with them. Some of these animals could be reservoirs for zoonoses such as leptospirosis (Option D).

The disaster cycle consists of two phases:

* Recovery phase - It includes disaster response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction.

* Risk reduction phase - It includes disaster mitigation and preparedness.

questions.text: 13. A young male presents with fever, malaise, and a persistent dry cough for 7 days. On examination, he has mild crackles in the lungs. Over the last 24 hours, he has developed painful mucosal erosions as shown in the clinical picture. Lab tests reveal positive cold agglutinins. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, malaise, and a persistent dry cough for 7 days, and examination shows mild crackles in the lungs, with positive cold agglutinin that points towards a diagnosis of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. The subsequent development of painful mucosal erosions and targetoid rash is highly suggestive of erythema multiforme/Stevens-Johnson syndrome, respectively, a classic extrapulmonary manifestation of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection.

Mycoplasma is the smallest free-living organism and lacks a cell wall, and is resistant to β-lactams. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the most common cause of primary atypical pneumonia (walking pneumonia ). The illness typically begins insidiously with low-grade fever, malaise, and persistent dry cough, and chest examination reveals only mild crackles while the x-ray shows patchy, diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Pneumonia due to M. pneumonia is also referred to as Eaton agent pneumonia.

Upper respiratory tract infection (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) and pneumonia are common pulmonary manifestations. It can also present with extrapulmonary manifestations, including erythema multiforme/Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), cold agglutinin disease, Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, arthritis, myocarditis, pericarditis, and encephalitis.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions. A key diagnostic hallmark is the presence of cold agglutinins (IgM antibodies against the I antigen of RBCs). Culture shows a typical fried egg appearance (central opaque granular area of growth surrounded by a flat translucent peripheral zone) on PPLO agar. The diagnosis is made by serology or by PCR. Macrolides are the most effective drug for management.

The image given below shows fried-egg colonies of Mycoplasma.



Other options: 

Option A: Streptococcus pneumoniae usually produces acute, lobar pneumonia with productive cough and rusty sputum

Option B: Legionella pneumophila causes atypical pneumonia but is more often associated with hyponatremia, diarrhea, rather than mucocutaneous lesions or cold agglutinin positivity.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus causes post-viral or cavitating pneumonia.

questions.text: 14. A 6-month-old infant is brought to the paediatrician by her parents with complaints that she has a weak cry, and appears floppy when held. On examination, she has severe hypotonia, absent deep tendon reflexes, and tongue fasciculations. What is the most specific test for this disease?

choices.text: Genetic testing for the SMN-1 gene
Genetic testing for trinucleotide repeat expansion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an infant with spinal muscular atrophy. The most specific test for spinal muscular atrophy is genetic testing for the SMN-1 gene.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a group of inherited lower motor neuron diseases of early onset, caused by loss of the SMN protein needed for RNA processing across the nuclear membrane. It is caused by a homozygous deletion in the survival motor neuron(SMN1) gene on chromosome 5q13.

Features of lower motor neuron disease include flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, fasciculations characterized by visible muscle twitches appearing as flickers under the skin, hypotonia (decreased muscle tone), hyporeflexia, or areflexia.

SMA has a wide clinical spectrum. Five types have been defined based on clinical findings: SMA type | Age at onset | Motor Function | Age at death SMA 0 | Prenatal | Unable to breathe, arthrogryposis | <1 month SMA 1, Werdnig-Hoffman disease | 0-6 months | Unable to sit | <2 years SMA 2 | 6-18 months | Unable to stand | >2 years SMA 3, Kugelberg-Welander disease | 18 months-3 years | Able to stand and walk | Adult SMA 4 | Adult | Able to stand and walk | Adult

Other options:

Option A: Muscle biopsy in patients with a suspicion of SMA is generally reserved for patients with equivocal or negative genetic test results.

Option C: MRI brain doesn't have any diagnostic use in SMA.

Option D: Trinucleotide repeat disorders include:

* Fragile X syndrome- CGG repeats

* Friedreich ataxia- GAA repeats

* Myotonic dystrophy - CTG repeats

* Huntington’s disease - CAG repeats

questions.text: 15. A male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with intermittent rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge. He passes 4–5 stools a day. Histological examination showed the following lesion. What is the first-line management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of crypt abscesses and other symptoms are consistent with moderate ulcerative colitis and may be treated with sulfasalazine (5-amino salicylic acid agents), glucocorticoids, immunosuppressants, and biologics. The treatment differs based on the severity of the disease.

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by the involvement of the rectum and colon. Patients usually present with rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge per rectum. Generally, in most cases, the condition is confined to the rectal area but may spread proximally. 

Ulcerative colitis is graded based on the frequency of bowel movements and systemic involvement. 

* Mild disease - ≤4 stools per day with/without rectal bleeding;

* Moderate disease - ≥4 stools per day with few systemic signs of illness; 

* Severe disease - ≥6 blood stools per day with fever, tachycardia (≥90 beats/min), anemia (hemoglobin <10.5 g/dL), and elevated levels of inflammatory markers (ESR ≥30 mm/h)

* Fulminant disease - >10 stools per day with severe anemia requiring blood transfusion and progressive colonic dilation (toxic megacolon)

5-ASA agents can be given to patients with mild to moderate disease. Glucocorticoids, immunosuppressants, and biologics are effective in patients with moderate to severe disease. Surgery is indicated in patients with fulminant disease.

Other options: 

Option B: Resection of the affected colon/surgery for ulcerative colitis is indicated when there is an intractable disease, fulminant disease, toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, massive colonic hemorrhage, colon dysplasia or cancer, colonic obstruction, or extracolonic manifestations.

Option C: Avoid NSAIDs (except for acetaminophen) since these medications may sometimes worsen symptoms.

Option D: Antibiotics generally have no role in the treatment of ulcerative colitis, except when patients develop pouchitis after colectomy and ileal pouch–anal anastomosis (IPAA).

questions.text: 16. A 32-year-old woman presents with irritability, peripheral neuropathy, and microcytic hypochromic anemia. She has been on isoniazid therapy for pulmonary tuberculosis for the past 3 months. Which of the following is not used for the biochemical assay of the vitamin deficient here?

choices.text: Activation of erythrocyte transaminase by pyridoxal phosphate
Urinary excretion of xanthurenate after tryptophan load

questions.solution:
Erythrocyte glutathione reductase activation coefficient is not used for the biochemical assay of the vitamin deficiency here, that is, vitamin B6. It is used for the assay of vitamin B2 (riboflavin).

The woman has been on isoniazid therapy for the last 3 months and presents with irritability, peripheral neuropathy, and microcytic hypochromic anaemia, suggesting pyridoxine/vitamin B6 deficiency. Chronic isoniazid therapy is a common cause of vitamin B6 deficiency; hence, pyridoxine is always given alongside isoniazid.

Vitamin B6 is used to collectively represent the three compounds - pyridoxine, pyridoxal, and pyridoxamine. The active form of vitamin B6 is the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate, which the above three compounds can synthesise. Pyridoxal phosphate participates in reactions like transamination, decarboxylation, and deamination. Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with neurological symptoms such as depression, irritability, nervousness, peripheral neuropathy and mental confusion. Microcytic hypochromic anaemia is seen in B6 deficiency. This is due to a reduction in heme production.

The biochemical assays for vitamin B6 include:

* Erythrocyte transaminase (Option A) - Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is required for activation of erythrocyte transaminase. Hence, it is used as a biochemical assay.

* Measurement of urinary pyridoxic acid levels (Option B) - It is a major catabolite of vitamin B6 excreted in urine. There is low excretion in deficiency and high excretion in vitamin excess.

* Tryptophan load test (Option C) - Since kynureninase requires pyridoxal phosphate, xanthurenate excretion in response to tryptophan is diagnostic of vitamin B6 deficiency.

* Measurement of the plasma concentration of vitamin B6 is also used.

questions.text: 17. A middle-aged female presented to the OPD with a 1-month history of a rapidly enlarging lump in the right breast associated with erythema and warmth. On examination, skin changes as shown in the following image are seen along with an ill-defined palpable lump. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Staging of this type of breast CA is based on the size of the tumour
Skin changes are due to tumour emboli causing dermal infiltration
Chemotherapy is alone sufficient in this type of malignancy
Surgery is the first line of management once diagnosis is established

questions.solution:
Skin changes are due to tumour emboli causing dermal infiltration, which is the correct statement.

The given scenario, along with the image pointing towards the classical peau-d-orange appearance, is suggestive of inflammatory breast carcinoma. The hallmark feature is diffuse involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels without any discrete mass. The tumour emboli infiltrate and block the dermal lymphatics. This obstruction leads to lymphatic stasis and manifests as erythema, warmth, tenderness of the breast, and edema, leading to a peau-d'orange appearance. This infiltration explains why the disease spreads rapidly.

On pathological examination, the histological hallmark is tumour emboli seen inside the dermal lymphatics. Axillary lymph node metastasis is quite common here, which predicts the incidence of distant metastasis. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is generally deferred, and ALND (Axillary Lymph Node Dissection) should always be performed. 

Although it is rare, it accounts for 1-5% of all breast tumours and is the most aggressive variety. It is characterised by redness involving > 1/3rd of the surface of the breast with or without a lump. It is staged as T4d irrespective of the size of the lump in the TNM classification (option A).

The current treatment approach is an aggressive, multimodality approach in the following sequence: neoadjuvant chemotherapy to shrink the tumour, followed by mastectomy. Post-mastectomy radiation therapy is crucial to reduce local recurrence. This is followed by systemic/targeted therapy. Systemic therapy involves endocrine therapy for ER-positive tumours and targeted therapy such as Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumours (option C).

Generally, chemotherapy precedes surgery (option D) in inflammatory breast carcinoma management. Sentinel lymph node biopsy alone is not adequate. Axillary lymph node dissection(ALND) is recommended because it has a high risk of nodal involvement.

questions.text: 18. Which of the following best describes the term "exaltation" in microbiology?

choices.text: Reduction in a microorganism's ability to cause disease
Inherent capacity of a microorganism to cause disease
Ability to spread within the host tissues

questions.solution:
An increase in a microorganism's virulence best describes the term exaltation in microbiology.

Exaltation refers to the process by which a microorganism becomes more virulent, often through repeated passage in susceptible hosts or favourable conditions that enhance its pathogenic potential. This can result in more severe disease manifestations.

Other options:

Option A: Reduction in a microorganism's ability to cause disease is described by the term attenuation. It refers to a decrease in virulence, commonly used in the development of live attenuated vaccines to reduce pathogenicity while retaining immunogenicity.

Option C: The inherent capacity of a microorganism to cause disease is described by the term pathogenicity. It describes the qualitative ability of a microbe to cause disease, that is, its inherent potential to cause disease in a host regardless of severity.

Option D: Invasiveness is the ability of a microorganism to invade and spread within the host tissues after establishing infection. It contributes to the overall virulence of the pathogen.

questions.text: 19. What raw material is used for suture material that slowly absorbs in 1-2 years and is commonly used for fixing drains, as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given scenario involves the use of silk as a suture material, which is obtained from the raw silk of the silk worm.

Silk is a natural protein obtained from the silkworm. It is a type of non-absorbable suture material, whose fibrous encapsulation occurs inside the body within 2-3 weeks; however, it is slowly absorbed over 1-2 years. 

It is used in the ligation and suturing when long-term support is needed for the tissues, as in securing drains externally. Since it is braided and multifilament, the chances of infection and tissue reactions are high. It is generally avoided for use with vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation. 

Other options: 

Option B: Alloy of iron, nickel, and chromium is the raw material of surgical steel, which is a type of non-absorbable suture material commonly used for closure of sternotomy wounds and not for drain fixation. 

Option C: Sheep collagen is the raw material for catgut, which is a type of absorbable suture material; however, it is not used for fixing drains. 

Option D: Polyamide polymer, the raw material for nylon, degrades at about 15-20% per year and is used as a non-absorbable suture material in general surgery.

questions.text: 20. A 60-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo 4 cycles of chemotherapy. After her first cycle, she developed thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 19,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. Oprelvekin is an IL-11 analog used in the prophylaxis and treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. IL-11 stimulates the megakaryocytes to mature into platelets.

Other options:

Option B: Filgrastim is a G-CSF (Granulocyte-Colony Stimulating Factor), which is used for neutropenia.

Option C: Darbepoetin alfa is a modified form of erythropoietin, which stimulates erythroid proliferation. It is used to treat anemia in patients with chronic renal failure, HIV-infected patients treated with zidovudine, and cancer patients treated with myelosuppressive cancer chemotherapy. 

Option D: Intravenous immunoglobulins are prepared from pools of thousands of healthy donors and used in the treatment of a number of conditions like primary immunodeficiency disorders, Kawasaki disease, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, Guillain-Barré syndrome, and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. They have no role in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia.

questions.text:
21. A young female presents to you with primary amenorrhea. She has well-developed breasts but sparse/absent pubic and axillary hair. She is diagnosed with AIS, but she wants to have a child. Which is the best option for this patient?

AIS - Androgen insensitivity syndrome
questions.solution:
Adoption is the only option for a patient with Androgen insensitivity syndrome to have a child, since they don't have any internal genitalia.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder in which the androgen receptors fail to respond to testosterone. In complete AIS, the individual is born as a phenotypically normal female but has a male karyotype. The external genitalia appear normal, with absent or scant pubic and axillary hair.  The clinical features include primary amenorrhea due to the absence of the uterus and cervix.

They have normally developed breasts due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen. Swelling in the inguinal region is suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, due to loss of action of testosterone on its receptor. The absence of uterus and cervix is due to the production of Müllerian inhibiting substance from the Sertoli cells of the testis, and no functional ovaries( have testes instead of ovaries). Therefore, they cannot produce their own gametes. Hence, biological motherhood is not possible. 

Other options:

Option A: Intrauterine insemination is not possible because the patients do not have a uterus or ovaries to produce an ovum.

Option B: In vitro fertilisation is not possible because there is no ovum production.

Option C: Surrogacy is also not possible because she has no ovum.

questions.text: 22. A 5-year-old child with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis underwent multiple surgical excisions for laryngeal papillomas. Parents report that despite surgery, the child continues to have stridor and recurrent infections. Which of the following is the most likely complication in this case?
questions.solution:
The most likely complication in this case is subglottic stenosis. 

In the clinical scenario presented, a patient has undergone multiple excisions for laryngeal papillomas. This can lead to subglottic stenosis due to the cumulative effects of repeated surgical trauma and subsequent scarring in the subglottic region. Subglottic stenosis is characterised by a pathological narrowing of the airway situated immediately below the vocal cords. This anatomical constriction can severely impede airflow, leading to significant respiratory distress.

The primary cause of subglottic stenosis in patients undergoing repeated laryngeal procedures is the sustained pressure exerted by endotracheal tubes or cuffs on the delicate airway mucosa. This prolonged pressure precipitates inflammation, ischemia, and ultimately, fibrotic scarring, which progressively reduces the luminal diameter of the subglottis. These include stridor, dyspnea, and hoarseness.

Diagnosis is made by laryngoscopy/bronchoscopy/ imaging studies like CT/MRI. Management includes the following:

* Endoscopic Interventions: Balloon and mechanical dilatation techniques can be used.

* Laser Therapy: CO2 laser

* Surgical Excision

* Tracheostomy: In instances where immediate and definitive bypass of a severely obstructed airway segment is critical to preserve life, a tracheostomy may be performed.

Other options

Option A: Malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma is very rare, mainly in adult-onset papillomatosis and with prior radiotherapy.

Option B: Tracheobronchial papillomatosis can occur by downward spread, but it is less common than subglottic stenosis

Option D: Pulmonary papillomatosis is very rare, usually follows tracheobronchial spread, and is associated with significant morbidity, but is uncommon.

questions.text: 23. While conducting animal studies, a scientist is experimenting with a drug called vesamicol that causes skeletal muscle relaxation. What is the mechanism by which the drug causes muscle relaxation?

choices.text: Breakdown of acetylcholine after its release into the synaptic cleft
Blocks the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle
Inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals
Prevents the release of  acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.solution:
Vesamicol causes skeletal muscle relaxation by blocking the transport of acetylcholine into its storage vesicle.

It acts on the cholinergic nerve terminals and blocks the transport, thus preventing the repletion of acetylcholinesterase following transmitter release. 

Other options:

Option A: Acetylcholine esterase is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine after it is released into the synaptic cleft to acetate and choline.

Option C: Hemicholinum inhibits the uptake of choline into nerve terminals.

Option D: Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.text:
24. A 30-year-old woman reports that “the fan is whispering secrets to me”. On mental status examination, she insists the sound is coming from outside but has no evidence to support it. Which domain of MSE is this documented under?

MSE - Mental status examination
questions.solution:
The given scenario should be documented under hallucination.

Hallucinations are false perceptions occurring in the absence of external stimulus, with full consciousness, and resembling a real perception. True hallucinations are experienced as coming from the external world (outer objective space), for example, “I hear a man shouting behind me”. If the person perceives it as coming from inside the head/mind (inner subjective space), it is called pseudohallucination. Different types of hallucinations include auditory, visual, olfactory, gustatory, tactile, etc.

Other options:

Option A: Illusion is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus. There is some real sensory input, but the brain interprets it wrongly, for example, a shadow in the dark is mistaken for a person.

Option B: Delusion is a disorder of thought content. It is a false, fixed belief that is firmly held despite clear evidence to the contrary, not shared by others in the person’s culture, and not explained by intelligence, education, or background. For example, a patient saying " My intestines are made of glass" is a somatic delusion.

Option D: Derealization is a disturbance of perception in which the external world feels strange, unreal, and distant, but reality testing is usually intact. For example, a person feels "Everything around me seems like a movie scene, not real life". The patient usually does not completely believe in the delusional change and describes it as an “as-if” phenomenon.

questions.text: 25. A young man comes to the urology department with a chronic history of deformity of the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. On examination, there were palpable penile plaques and penile ultrasound showed a thickened area of tissue around tunica albuginea. He has been using the device shown below but is now seeking a permanent solution. What surgical procedure you would recommend for him?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the traction device/ extender used to treat excessive penile curvature. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbit's procedure.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture as a part of the Galezia triad (Dupuytren's contracture, retroperitoneal fibrosis, peyronie's disease).

Some cases may resolve spontaneously. If not, conservative measures such as oral tamoxifen, vitamin E, terfenadine, intralesional verapamil, etc. can be tried. Intralesional collagenase has also been used. Penile extenders/ traction devices such as that shown in the above image have also been used. However, if none of these methods are effective, surgical management can be tried using Nesbit's procedure.

Nesbit's procedure is indicated when all other interventions have failed and the patient is experiencing difficulty in their sexual and personal life because of it. The procedure is started by creating an artificial erection by injecting normal saline. Following this, an elliptical excision is done on the convex side of the penis (opposite to the thickened plaque). The width of the excised tissue depends on the degree of penile deformity. The side with the plaque is left as it is. 

The images attached below depict the pathology in Peyronie's disease and the ultrasound finding observed in the disease-





Other options:

Options A and B: Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgical procedures performed for a hydrocele.

Option D: Anderson-Hynes operation is a pyeloplasty procedure performed for hydronephrosis.

questions.text: 26. An elderly male patient presented with sudden onset palpitations over the last 3 days. ECG is shown below. There was evidence of a thrombus in the left atria on transesophageal electrocardiography (TEE). How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of palpitations for 3 days (>48 hours) along with the ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm with absent 'p' waves suggests atrial fibrillation. The TEE shows evidence of thrombus. Thus, the patient is managed with anticoagulation for 3 weeks. 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterised by disorganised, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. 

It is common in men, and risk factors are underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, obesity, and sleep disorders.

Features include a heart rate that typically ranges from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur, and thromboembolic events can take place.

Typically, an ECG shows an absent P wave.

Management is mainly by control of rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifiable risk factors.

Immediate cardioversion (option B) should be done when the patient presents within 48 hours and is at low risk for developing stroke, whereas in patients presenting after 48 hours or if the duration is not known, there is an increased risk of thromboembolism. Therefore, anticoagulation should be done for 3 weeks, followed by cardioversion and then continue anticoagulation for 4 weeks post cardioversion.

The other approach is to start anticoagulation followed by transesophageal echo, and only if the thrombus is absent, cardioversion can be done.

The rate control strategy (option D) is adopted to reduce the patient's symptoms. It is achieved with calcium channel blockers/ beta blockers and digoxin.

questions.text: 27. A 27-year-old G2P1L1 female presents to the ENT department with complaints of bilateral hearing loss, which was insidious in onset. A diagnosis of otosclerosis is being considered. Presence of which of the following features is unlikely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of the stapedial reflex is unlikely to be associated with otosclerosis. 

The stapedial reflex is a protective reflex that protects the ear from loud noises by bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle. In otosclerosis,  the fixation of the stapes footplate with disease progression leads to immobility of the footplate. This, in turn, prevents movement of the stapes footplate following contraction of the muscle.

Otosclerosis is an autosomal dominant condition characterised by bony overgrowth of the enchondral layer of the otic capsule. It worsens with pregnancy and menopause. Conductive hearing loss and tinnitus are the common symptoms seen. Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type, and fissula ante fenestrum is the initial site involved.

Other options:

Option A: A normal tympanic membrane can be seen in otosclerosis. The tympanic membrane is mobile. Sometimes, on otoscopy, the Schwartz sign or the 'flamingo flush' is seen as a reddish hue of the tympanic membrane due to the ample vascularity of the active otosclerotic focus. The given image represents the Schwartz sign:



Option C: Tinnitus is seen in cochlear type of otosclerosis as the abnormal sclerotic bone is metabolically active, which damages the sensory hair cells of the organ of Corti, generating spontaneous abnormal neural impulses that are perceived as tinnitus.

Option D: Paradoxical hearing or 'paracusis wilisii' is a diagnostic clue for otosclerosis. This happens because the background noise is less disturbing in conductive loss, while people raise their voice in noisy surroundings, making speech easier to hear.

Pearl PM1751: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

* Can identify malingerers.

* To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.

* Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

Pearl PM0835: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Pearl PM2512: Stapedotomy special considerations and complications

Special considerations for stapedotomy:

* In cases of active otosclerosis, surgery is not performed until the condition has matured. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used to hasten the maturation.

* During pregnancy, the procedure is not performed. It is performed only after delivery.

* In a patient with co-morbid Meniere's disease, the surgery is performed after managing Meniere's disease or is performed with caution.

* For divers and frequent air travellers (or pilots), a scheduled break from these activities is required after the procedure.

* The procedure is contraindicated if otosclerosis involves the only hearing ear.

Post-op complications:

* Conductive hearing loss (due to prosthesis displacement, incus erosion, or recurrence of otosclerosis)

* Sensorineural hearing loss with possible dead ear

* Facial nerve injury

* Vertigo

* Perilymphatic fistula

* Discomfort from loud noise

* Alteration in taste

* Cholesteatoma

* Meningitis

Note: Stapedotomy is performed under local anesthesia.

questions.text: 28. The histopathological analysis of a myocardial biopsy taken from a patient with acute rheumatic carditis is shown below. What type of necrosis is associated with the finding seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The most likely lesion shown in the myocardial biopsy specimen of acute rheumatic carditis is Aschoff's bodies, which shows fibrinoid necrosis.

Fibrinoid necrosis is usually the result of the deposition of immune complexes and plasma proteins in the arterial wall. On biopsy, fibrinoid necrosis appears as bright pink and amorphous deposits in the vessel wall. 

The Aschoff bodies consist of a focus of fibrinoid necrosis of collagen fibers, leukocyte infiltrates, and occasional large histiocytes called Anitschkow cells. The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and large, vesicular nuclei, as seen in the image below.



Other options :

Option A: Coagulative necrosis is a form of necrosis in which the architecture of the dead tissue is preserved for some days. it has a firm texture. The injury denatures the structural proteins and enzymes so the dead cell proteolysis is blocked. The necrotic cells are broken down by the action of lysosomal enzymes derived from infiltrating leukocytes, and they also remove debris from the dead cells by phagocytosis. 

The image below shows the coagulative necrosis of cardiomyocytes.



Option C: Fat necrosis is a focal area of fat destruction, due to the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substances of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. It is mainly seen in acute pancreatitis. 

The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within the breast tissue.



Option D: Caseous necrosis is often seen in foci of tuberculosis infection. On microscopy, these necrotic areas appear as a structureless collection of fragmented or lysed cells and amorphous granular debris enclosed within a distinctive inflammatory border. This appears as a characteristic focus of inflammation called a granuloma.

The image below shows tuberculoid granuloma associated with caseous necrosis (upper right) and surrounding epithelioid cells, Langhans' multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text:
29. Match the following shapes of RBCs with the conditions they are associated with.

1. Acanthocytes | a. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia 2. Degmacytes | b. Myelofibrosis 3. Dacrocytes | c. Uremia 4. Echinocytes | d. Post splenectomy 5. Schistocytes | e. G6PD deficiency
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows: 1. Acanthocytes | d. Post splenectomy 2. Degmacytes | e. G6PD deficiency 3. Dacrocytes | b. Myelofibrosis 4. Echinocytes | c. Uremia 5. Schistocytes | a. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia

Spur cells, also known as acanthocytes, are characterized by several irregularly spaced membrane projections of differing lengths. Conditions with acanthocytes include-

* Renal disease

* Abetalipoproteinemia

* Post-splenectomy/ hyposplenism.



Degmacytes or bite cells or blister cells are seen in Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells are formed when splenic macrophages extract Heinz bodies from red blood cells. Heinz bodies can be appreciated by Supravital staining – crystal violet





Dacrocytes or tear-drop cells are seen in myelofibrosis, myelodysplastic syndromes, hemolytic anemias, and thalassemias.



Burr cells, or echinocytes, have numerous small, evenly spaced, rounded membrane protrusions, which are more consistent in size and arrangement compared to acanthocytes. They also tend to be reversible, unlike acanthocytes. They are seen in anemia of renal disease (uremia), in premature infants, after exchange transfusion, and may sometimes be seen as storage artifacts.



Schistocytes or helmet cells are fragmented RBCs that are seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias and mechanical valves.

questions.text: 30. A 10-month-old child, after intake of high-protein food, developed severe vomiting, acidosis and convulsions. The vomitus and the child have a rancid cheese odour. Which enzyme deficiency can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of isovaleric acidemia due to the deficiency of the enzyme isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase.

Deficiency of isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase will result in impaired leucine degradation, resulting in the accumulation of substances like isovaleric acid, isovaleric glycine, and 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid in the body. This helps in the biochemical diagnosis and screening of the disease.

These toxins are responsible for the clinical features such as lethargy, vomiting, hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, dehydration, and sweaty feet/ rancid cheese odour. Some people also have mild forms detected only by newborn screening.

If left untreated, it can cause repeated metabolic crises, seizures, bone marrow suppression, developmental problems or even death.

Diagnosis of Isovaleric acidemia is performed using tandem mass spectrometry. High levels of isovalerylglycine and C5-carnitine can be detected in blood and urine.

For the treatment of an acute attack, rehydration and correction of acidosis should be done. The medication of choice is L-carnitine, which helps remove the toxic compounds, and a diet low in leucine should be followed.

Other options:

Option A: Defect in trimethylamine oxidase is associated with trimethylaminuria/fish odour syndrome.

Option B: PHPP hydroxylase deficiency causes tyrosinemia type III. A partially active PHPP hydroxylase will cause Hawkinsuria, which has a characteristic odour of a swimming pool.

Option D: Defect in tyrosine transaminase causes type II tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart syndrome.

questions.text: 31. A 3-year-old child is brought in with developmental delay and intractable seizures. Laboratory evaluation shows markedly elevated urinary sulfite and thiosulfite, along with low plasma cystine. A mutation in the MOCS1 gene affecting molybdopterin synthesis is found. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
Mutation of the MOCS1 gene and elevated levels of urinary sulfite and thiosulfite, with low levels of cystine, are due to a deficiency of sulfite oxidase.

Sulfite oxidase is an enzyme required for breaking down sulfur-containing amino acids. Molybdenum is a cofactor for sulfite oxidase. Mutations in any one of three genes - MOCS1, MOCS2, which are required for the synthesis of molybdopterin, can lead to sulfite oxidase deficiency.

There is a defect in the breakdown of the sulfur-containing amino acids cysteine and methionine, resulting in the accumulation of these amino acids. Clinical features include severe neurological diseases, seizures, developmental delay, and early death. Laboratory findings reveal increased sulfite, thiosulfite, and decreased cysteine and methionine.

Molybdenum is a key component of the cofactor molybdopterin. Including sulfite oxidase, molybdopterin also serves as a catalytically essential prosthetic group for enzymes Xanthine oxidase and Aldehyde oxidase.

The average daily dietary intake of molybdenum is 100 micrograms. Molybdenum is found in cereals. Excessive molybdenum consumption can lead to the development of molybdenosis, a condition distinguished by stunted growth, haematological deficiencies, and gastrointestinal disturbances. Deficiency of molybdenum is associated with mouth and oesophageal cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Xanthine oxidase is required in purine metabolism to convert hypoxanthine to uric acid. It is not related to sulfite accumulation.

Option C: Aldehyde oxidase catalyses the oxidation of aldehydes. It is also involved in drug metabolism. Deficiency of aldehyde oxidase does not lead to sulfite accumulation.

Option D: Nitrate reductase is also a molybdenum-containing enzyme, but is found only in plants and fungi. It is required for nitrogen fixation.

questions.text: 32. A young man is diagnosed with hypertension. His laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. He says that his mother was also diagnosed with hypertension at a younger age. Genetic testing revealed the presence of a mutation in ENaC gene. Which of the following drugs is commonly used in the treatment of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical, laboratory, and genetic features are suggestive of Liddle's syndrome. It occurs due to the increased function of epithelial sodium channels. Amiloride blocks these channels and is therefore commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome.

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels in collecting tubules. Therefore, it reduces sodium retention and potassium wasting. Triamterene acts similar to amiloride. However, it is less potent and more toxic than amiloride.

It is used to treat Liddle's syndrome, hypokalemia due to other diuretics, and lithium-induced polyuria. Its toxicity can cause hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis.

Liddle's syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene which codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. Due to increased sodium retention, patients present with hypertension and hypokalemic alkalosis. They have normal aldosterone levels. They respond to treatment with amiloride.

Other options:

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic and acts by inhibiting Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Therefore it is not used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome. A condition that mimics overdose loop diuretic is Bartter's syndrome. This syndrome occurs due to a defect in the Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Patients will have low blood pressure, polyuria, polydipsia, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, and normal to increased calcium excretion. 

Option B: Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist. Since the levels of aldosterone are normal in Liddle's syndrome, it cannot be used in the treatment of the condition. The toxicity of spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia and gynecomastia.

Option D: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic and acts by the inhibition of the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Therefore it is not commonly used in the treatment of Liddle's syndrome. A condition that mimics an overdose of thiazide diuretics is Gitelman syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disease that causes a defect in the Na+/Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Patients present with low blood pressure, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria.

questions.text: 33. A medical student learns that the structure given below in red plays an important role in memory. Which of the following can the patient not do if this structure is damaged?

choices.text: Drive a car to his place of work
Remember the first day of college

questions.solution:
The structure in red is the hippocampus, which, when damaged, hampers the patient's ability to remember the first day of college. Hippocampus, along with the medial temporal lobe and neocortex, is responsible for episodic memory. This includes events such as remembering various milestones in life, important days, etc.

The two forms of memory are explicit and implicit memory. 

Factual knowledge about people, things, and events, which is regulated by conscious awareness, comes under explicit/declarative memory. It is further subdivided into two types:

* Semantic memory (facts) - The lateral and anterior temporal cortex of the brain, along with the prefrontal cortex, is involved. For example, knowing the prime minister of the country, important dates, names of people (Option D - grandmother's name), etc.

* Episodic memory (events) - The hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and the neocortex are involved. For example, remembering the events on the first day of college, events that took place on the day one got into an accident, etc.

Implicit or non-declarative memory refers to the memory responsible for actions and behaviors that do not need conscious recall. The four types of implicit memory are as follows:-

* Procedural memory, or the skill and habits acquired by the person over time, which do not need any conscious effort and become automated. Driving a car (Option A), riding a bike, and swimming are all examples. The striatum, cerebellum, and the motor cortex are the sites of processing such skills.

* Priming is dependent on the neocortex. It is the ability of a person to recognise words or objects due to being exposed to them previously. Lesions in the neocortex affect a person’s ability to recall words when prompted (Option C)

* Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitization and is dependent on different reflex pathways. Habituation involves multiple neutral stimuli that, on repetition over time, evoke diminished responses. For example, sleeping at home when it rains outside. Sensitization, on the other hand, is associated with linking the habituated response to a noxious stimulus. For example, a person who is startled by a loud noise suddenly may be more responsive to softer sounds from then on.

* Associative learning depends on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for motor responses. It includes classical and operant conditioning, where one understands the relationship between two different stimuli.

Pearl PM0907: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: 34. A 45-year-old woman presents to a district hospital with complaints of chest pain for 2 hours. The facility has specialists in medicine, surgery, paediatrics, along with laboratory and imaging facilities. She is stabilised and referred for cardiac catheterisation. The healthcare facility is an example of which level of healthcare?
questions.solution:
District hospitals (DH) come under the secondary level of healthcare.

In the given scenario, the woman goes to a district hospital, which is a secondary healthcare system. District hospitals and subdistrict hospitals provide secondary care health services. Every district should have at least one comprehensively functioning DH. Districts with a population of less than 5 lakhs and with a functional DH do not need a subdistrict hospital (SDH). Districts with a population of 5–10 lakhs can have one Subdistrict hospital. For a population of more than 10 lakhs, 1 SDH is needed for every 10 lakh population.

The three pillars of district hospital services are providing clinical care, providing a knowledge hub for capacity development, and public health programs.

Important functions of DHs:

* Providing curative services

* Palliative and rehabilitative services

* Implementation of health programs

* Drugs and diagnostic services

* Administrative and other support services

* Health promotion and educational services.

In the Indian healthcare system, health services are organised at three levels, each supported by a higher-level/centre to which the patient can be referred. These levels are- 

* Primary health care - Includes primary health centres and their subcentres. It is the first level of contact between the public and the healthcare system. Care is delivered by ANM/MPW at subcentres and MBBS medical officers at PHCs. Diagnostics are limited.

* Secondary health care - Facilities include Community Health Centres, Sub-district hospitals, and District hospitals. They serve as the first referral level in the three-tier system. Specialists, 24/7 emergency services are available.

* Tertiary health care - Includes medical colleges, teaching hospitals, and apex institutes with super-speciality services, advanced ICUs, and high-end diagnostics/therapeutics. Examples of tertiary procedures- cardiac catheterization, neurosurgery, oncology chemo/radiotherapies.

Quaternary is a conceptual extension sometimes used in global literature, but not included in the Indian healthcare system.

Pearl PM0155: Levels of Healthcare System in India

questions.text: 35. An 8-year-old boy had abdominal pain for the past 1 week and associated swelling of his knees with non-blanching rashes. His platelet levels were normal. What is the probable immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a boy presenting with abdominal pain, swelling of knees, non-blanching rashes, and a normal platelet count is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura. The immunoglobulin involved in the pathogenesis of this condition is IgA.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. Vasculitis occurs due to immune complex depositions involving IgA. It is characterized by a purpuric rash and is commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. Renal manifestations vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies generally show a mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count, and occasionally eosinophilia. IgA and C3 complements are elevated in the serum.

questions.text: 36. A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of breathlessness on lying down and chest pain. He was diagnosed to have congestive cardiac failure and was administered torsemide. This drug inhibits which of the following type of transport mechanism?
questions.solution:
Torsemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits Na+ K+ 2Cl- co-transporter on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This is an example of secondary active transport.

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. As one of the substances (e.g., sodium) diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, energy is released, which is used to drive another substance (e.g., glucose) against the gradient. Thus, secondary active transport does not require energy directly from ATP.



Examples of secondary active transport

Counter-transport/exchanger

* Na+ Ca+ exchanger

* Na+ H+ exchanger

* H+ K+ exchanger

Co-transporters/symporter

* Na+ Glucose co-transporter

* Na+ K+ 2Cl- co-transporter

questions.text: 37. A 60-year-old was admitted with a dislocated hip and was taken up for reduction under anaesthesia. She is intubated on request, and etomidate is used. Which of the following is she at risk of following the administration of etomidate?
questions.solution:
The patient is at risk of developing myoclonus following the administration of etomidate, which can be decreased with the use of opioids.

Etomidate is an intravenous anaesthetic that acts by increasing the affinity of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), by binding to GABAA receptors. It can be used as an induction agent in general anaesthesia, for rapid sequence intubation, and as an anaesthetic for short-term procedures such as dilatation and curettage, reduction of dislocated joints, cervical conization, and cardioversion. It is also used for inducing deep sleep for brief periods in retrobulbar blocks. 

Since it is excreted by the kidneys, patients with impaired renal function and the elderly are prone to developing adverse effects. 

Other options:

Option A: Adrenal stimulation is not seen with etomidate. Instead, it causes adrenal suppression and can therefore be used in patients with hypercortisolism. Etomidate is therefore not used in sepsis because of the increased mortality that is seen due to adrenal suppression.

Option B: Painless injection is not seen; instead, etomidate injection is painful. This is due to its solution in propylene glycol. IV Lidocaine is therefore used before etomidate to alleviate the pain.

Option D: Instead of a marked decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, etomidate increases the heart rate and blood pressure when used as the sole drug for intubation. Hence, it can be used in patients with shock following trauma and hypovolemia.

questions.text: 38. A 2-day-old neonate born with microcephaly, floppy at birth, had a seizure episode in the morning. Neurosonogram revealed a smooth cerebral surface, and a T2-weighted image of the brain is shown in the image below. What prenatal advice will prevent this condition in future pregnancies?

choices.text: CMV Ig detection in maternal urine
Rubella vaccine in the antenatal period

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the T2-weighted image of the brain showing reduction in normal sulcation, smooth agyric cortex with hydrocephalus in Lissencephaly are suggestive of congenital Zika syndrome, which can be prevented by using insecticide-treated nets.

The Zika virus is an RNA flavivirus that is mainly transmitted by the Aedes mosquito and, in some cases, by sexual contact. Patients are usually asymptomatic. Rash, fever, joint pain, conjunctivitis, and headaches may be seen in infected mothers. The fetus may be severely affected regardless of the symptoms of the mother. A congenital Zika syndrome is seen, which includes

* Microcephaly, 

* Lissencephaly (loss of gyri and sulci from the surface of the brain), 

* Ocular manifestations (microphthalmia or coloboma, cataracts)

* Contractures, hyper/hypotonia

* Hearing deficits,

* Epilepsy

Prophylaxis for Zika virus infection includes the use of insecticide-treated nets, spraying insecticides to control vector mosquitoes, and avoiding sexual exposure to people who have recently been exposed. No specific treatments or vaccines have been developed yet.

Other options:

Option A: Undercooked/raw meat may contain tissue cysts containing bradyzoites of Toxoplasma gondii, hence should be avoided. They may cause infection in the mother, which, when transmitted to the fetus, may lead to congenital toxoplasmosis. The classic triad seen in toxoplasmosis includes chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. Low birthweight, jaundice, and anaemia are seen in clinically affected neonates.

Option B: Prenatal detection of CMV(Cytomegalovirus) immunoglobulin in maternal urine can be done if the mother presents with mononucleosis-like illness. Fetal transmission is mostly seen in the third trimester, and manifestations include microcephaly, growth restriction, ventriculomegaly, chorioretinitis, sensorineural deficits, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemolytic anaemia. 

Option C: Rubella vaccine is contraindicated in the antenatal period. It is a live vaccine and poses a risk of maternal rubella, which can lead to congenital rubella syndrome in the fetus. Congenital rubella syndrome is associated with a triad of cardiovascular abnormalities, cataract, and hearing deficits.

questions.text:
39. After a thorough evaluation, the nephrologist diagnosed a child as having an inherited disease affecting the area marked X in the image below. Which of the following corresponds to the ABG findings of the primary acid-base abnormality seen in this patient?

ABG - Arterial Blood Gas
questions.solution:
The inherited disease affecting the channel marked in the image is Bartter syndrome, which causes metabolic alkalosis. The ABG findings in Option B are indicative of metabolic alkalosis.

Bartter syndrome presents as hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalciuria due to mutations in the gene coding for the Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter located on the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Loss of sodium and chloride in urine leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which leads to volume contraction and stimulates distal uptake of sodium and further excretion of potassium. Secretion of hydrogen ions, in addition, causes metabolic alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.49 signifies alkalemia.

Step 2: The plasma HCO3- is 35mEq/L which is above normal (22 - 28 mEq/L), and the pCO2 is 42mmHg, which lies in the normal range (35-45 mmHg). This, along with high pH, signifies metabolic alkalosis.

Step 3: The expected compensatory increase in pCO2 can be calculated using the following formula: Expected increase in pCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Expected pCO2  = 40 + 19 = 59mmHg The measured pCO2 is 42 mmHg (which is less than the expected value), indicating that there is no respiratory compensation.
