questions.text: 40. A young male presents with recurrent itching and redness around the nasolabial folds and the perioral area. On examination, there are erythematous patches with greasy scales localized to the nasolabial folds and beard region. Which of the following is most closely associated with the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of seborrheic dermatitis, which is strongly associated with Malassezia restricta.

Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis affecting areas with high sebaceous gland density, like the scalp, eyebrows, nasolabial folds, external auditory canal, and presternal area. The lesions are characteristically erythematous, itchy, and greasy (yellowish) with fine scaling, often worse in winter.

The exact cause is multifactorial, including increased sebum production (which can be influenced by androgens ), individual susceptibility, and colonization by Malassezia yeast, specifically Malassezia restricta.

Malassezia is a lipophilic yeast that resides on sebaceous skin and can metabolize sebum, producing inflammatory byproducts that trigger the epidermal inflammatory response seen in seborrheic dermatitis.

The condition improves with antifungal therapy and sometimes worsens in an immunocompromised state (eg, HIV ), supporting a fungal-mediated inflammatory mechanism rather than a purely bacterial cause.

The image below shows seborrheic dermatitis around nasolabial folds.



Option A and D: Trichophyton mentagrophytes and Trichophyton rubrum are dermatophyte fungi causing tinea corporis, tinea faciei, and tinea pedis.It produces ring-shaped lesions with central clearing, not greasy erythematous patches in seborrheic areas.



Option C: Candida albicans causes candidiasis, including intertrigo, oral thrush, and paronychia. Lesions are typically moist, not scaly.

questions.text:
41. A 60-year-old man told his doctor friend that he has overgrown his hats. An evaluation was carried out, and ALP was raised with a cotton wool appearance on a skull radiograph. Which of the following is a complication of the man’s condition?

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man who has overgrown his hats and has raised ALP with a cotton wool appearance on a skull radiograph is suggestive of Paget's disease of the bone, and high-output cardiac failure is a complication of the same.

Paget’s disease of the bone is characterized by increased bone turnover, with the pelvis and tibia being the common sites. Bone thickening and enlargement are seen, and the bones become brittle. Raised plasma alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and C-terminal cross-linked telopeptides (CTX) are indicative of osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity, respectively. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are normal. Hypercalcemia can, however, be seen in rare cases where patients are immobilized for prolonged periods due to a mismatch in bone breakdown and formation.

Complications of Paget's disease of the bone include pathological fractures, osteoarthritis, high-output heart failure, nerve compression (can present as trigeminal neuralgia, impaired vision, facial nerve palsy, and hearing loss), spinal canal stenosis, hypercalcemia, osteosarcoma, and steal syndromes, which may cause cerebral deficits and ischemia of the spinal cord.

Though the diagnosis is incidental, some patients may present with a classic complaint of old hats not fitting and dull aching pain over the involved region, which worsens when the region is warmed up. X-ray findings include both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions:-

* Cotton wool appearance of the skull

* Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

* Osteoporosis circumscripta - large, well-defined lytic lesion of the involved bone.

* Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 

* Picture-frame appearance may be seen in vertebral bodies due to enlarged coarse trabeculae surrounded by a prominent radiodense periphery.

* Ivory vertebra sign may be seen due to a diffuse and homogeneous increase in opacity of a vertebral body.

The ivory vertebra sign is seen in the image below



The given below X-ray shows cotton wool skull.



Other options:

Option A: Struvite stones are not seen with Paget's disease. Calcium stones may be seen due to hypercalcemia.

Option B: Hemarthroses are uncommon in Paget's disease. Excessive bleeding during surgery is seen.

Option D: Septic arthritis may occur secondary to osteomyelitis or iatrogenic factors; however, it is uncommon in Paget's disease of the bone.

42. A 35-year-old patient presents six weeks after undergoing open reduction and internal fixation of a distal radial shaft fracture sustained during a fall on an outstretched hand. The patient continues to have pain and tenderness over the distal ulna. Clinical examination reveals instability of the distal radioulnar joint in supination. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

DRUJ: distal radioulnar joint

choices.text: Continue splinting the forearm in supination
Temporary fixation of the DRUJ with K-wires in supination
Repeat open reduction and internal fixation of the radius

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a previously treated Galeazzi fracture with associated distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ) dislocation, now presenting with persistent DRUJ instability six weeks after open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). The next best step is temporary fixation of the DRUJ with Kirschner wires in supination.

Persistent DRUJ instability after appropriate fixation of a radial shaft fracture is best managed with temporary K-wire stabilization to allow healing of the soft tissues and restoration of joint stability. This is typically done with the forearm in supination, and wires are usually removed after six weeks to permit forearm rotation.

A Galeazzi fracture involves the fracture of the radial shaft associated with the dislocation/subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint. It is an unstable injury that typically requires surgical management in adults. Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) are recommended for adult radial shaft fractures, as closed reduction and casting often lead to poor outcomes, and this approach stabilizes DRUJ dislocations.

While ORIF of the radius generally restores DRUJ alignment, if instability remains, K-wire fixation is the standard next step. In rare cases where instability persists even after fixation, additional procedures like triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC) repair or ulnar styloid fixation may be considered. If the DRUJ is irreducible, open treatment is warranted due to possible soft-tissue interposition.

Other Options:

Option A: TFCC repair is reserved for confirmed TFCC injury or instability persisting after K-wire fixation; it is not first-line.

Option B: Splinting in supination has already been attempted and failed; inadequate for persistent joint instability.

Option D: ORIF has been completed; there is no evidence of failure or malunion requiring revision.

questions.text: 43. Examination of a 9-year-old patient reveals signs that are suggestive of potential abuse. A sample from the child's perianal region was obtained and was tested using potassium iodide. This resulted in the formation of dark brown needle-shaped rhombic crystals. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test performed in this scenario is the Florence test, which is utilized to identify the presence of seminal fluid in suspected cases of sexual abuse.

Florence test detects choline which is secreted by seminal vesicles. The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide. A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. The test is not confirmatory for the presence of semen, however, a negative reaction rules out the presence of semen.

Other options:

Option A: Barberio test is used to detect the presence of seminal fluid. The stain used is saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. If semen is present, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option C: Paraffin test is used to detect gunpowder residue (nitrate and nitrites). 

Option D: Kastle Meyer test is used to detect the presence of bloodstain. A positive Kastle Meyer's (phenolphthalein) test is suggestive of a bloodstain. This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple colour indicates a positive test.

Pearl PM2133: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

* Barberio's test

* Florence test

* Acid phosphatase test

* Creatine phosphokinase test

* Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

* Benzidine test

* Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test

* Takayama hemochromogen crystal test

* Teichmann’s hemin crystal test

* Spectroscopic test

questions.text: 44. An 18-month-old toddler is brought by the parents for the oral polio vaccine (OPV) booster dose as per the national immunization schedule. They report a two-day history of diarrhea. What should be the appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Do not administer the vaccine, wait till recovery
Administer the vaccine as part of the series
Administer the vaccine, but do not count it; repeat the dose later
Defer OPV and give inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) instead

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of a toddler with diarrhea coming for OPV vaccination. In this case, we should administer the vaccine, but not count it as part of the series, and an additional dose should be given as soon as possible.

Diarrhoea is not a contraindication for OPV. However, if a child receives OPV while experiencing diarrhoea, that dose should not be counted towards the full series because it primarily impairs vaccine virus replication and mucosal immunity during diarrhea, which can reduce the vaccine’s effectiveness, and another dose should be administered as soon as possible to ensure complete protection.

Live vaccines are typically not administered to individuals with immunocompromising conditions. This includes patients with leukaemia, malignancy, and those receiving corticosteroids. For children with HIV infection, IPV is a suitable alternative to OPV.

Other options:

Option A: The vaccination may be postponed if there is severe diarrhea requiring hospitalization, and it can be administered once the condition improves.

Option B: The vaccine's efficacy will be reduced, and hence the dose may not work. Therefore not counted as part of the series.

Option D: OPV is deferred in case of immunocompromised individuals, not in this case, because it creates a missed opportunity; the child has come, and it’s safe to give the vaccine.

Pearl PM0601: Inactivated and Live Attenuated Polio Vaccines

Characteristic | Inactivated (IPV/Salk) | Attenuated (OPV/Sabin) Prevents disease | Yes | Yes Induces humoral IgG | Yes | Yes Induces intestinal sIgA | No | Yes Prevents intestinal colonization | No | Yes Secondary (herd) protection by spread to others | No | Yes Reverts to virulence | No | Yes, very rarely May cause disease in immunocompromised | No | Yes

Salk has K, so it is killed.

questions.text: 45. A surgeon is carrying out a carotid aneurysm repair through the area shown in the image. Which nerve provides innervation to the antero-inferior border of the area?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is the carotid triangle of the neck, whose antero-inferior border is formed by the superior belly of the omohyoid, which is innervated by the superior ramus of the ansa cervicalis.

The ansa cervicalis, or the ansa hypoglossi, runs anterior to the carotid sheath and supplies the inferior belly of the omohyoid, sternothyroid, and sternohyoid muscles. It forms from the union of the superior and the inferior root, which originate from the hypoglossal nerve and C1 nerve root, and C2 and C3 nerve roots, respectively. The superior root innervates the superior belly of the omohyoid before being joined by the inferior root, which innervates all the infrahyoid muscles except thyrohyoid.



The borders of the carotid triangle are :

* Superior border - posterior belly of the digastric muscle, innervated by the facial nerve

* Posterior border - sternocleidomastoid muscle, innervated by the spinal accessory nerve

* Anteroinferior border - superior belly of the omohyoid muscle, innervated by the superior ramus of the ansa cervicalis

The floor of the carotid triangle is formed by parts of the thyrohyoid, hyoglossus, inferior, and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles. The roof is formed by skin, superficial fascia, platysma, and deep fascia containing branches of the facial and cutaneous cervical nerves.

The contents of the carotid triangle include the carotid sheath (Common carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve) with superior and inferior roots of ansa cervicalis, branches of the external carotid artery, hypoglossal nerve, and spinal accessory nerve. The image below shows the contents of the carotid triangle.



Other options:

Option A: The facial nerve arises at the pontomedullary junction and supplies the muscles of facial expression, along with the stapedius, stylohyoid, and the posterior belly of the digastric. In addition, it provides secretomotor fibres to the submandibular ganglion and has a sensory supply to the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, where the chorda tympani is responsible for the taste sensation.

Option B: The Accessory nerve is a motor nerve that has 2 roots - the cranial root, which arises from the nucleus ambiguus, and the spinal root that arises from the long spinal nucleus. The spinal root innervates the sternocleidomastoid and the trapezius muscle, while the cervical nerves provide proprioceptive sensations to these muscles.

Option C: The Vagus nerve (X) arises from multiple rootlets between the olive and inferior cerebellar peduncle and exits the skull through the jugular foramen. In the neck, it descends within a carotid sheath between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein.

questions.text: 46. A female with a history of ischemic heart disease presented with acute migraine. She was prescribed Lasmiditan, after which her symptoms subsided. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
This patient with ischemic heart disease, presenting with acute migraine, was prescribed Lasmiditan, which is a 5-HT1F receptor agonist.

Lasmiditan is a selective 5-HT1F receptor agonist that works centrally to inhibit the trigeminal nociceptive pathways without causing vasoconstriction and has significant antimigraine efficacy. It is given orally. It has fewer adverse cardiovascular events compared to Triptans.

Dizziness, vertigo, paresthesia, and nausea are features of toxicity with lasmiditan.

Other options : 

Option A: 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist is the mechanism of triptans(eg, Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan) that induce cranial vasoconstriction. They are contraindicated in patients with CAD or uncontrolled hypertension due to the risk of myocardial ischemia.

Option B: 5-HTIB/1D receptor antagonists are not used clinically.

Option D: CGRP(Calcitonin gene-related peptide ) receptor antagonist is the mechanism of gepants (eg, Rimegepant, Ubrogepant). These are newer orally active small molecules, used only for the immediate treatment of acute attacks. Nausea, fatigue, and dry mouth are the side effects caused by gepants.

Pearl PM2496: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

* Unilateral pain

* Throbbing pain

* Aggravation by movement

* Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

* Nausea/vomiting

* Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: 47. A 60-year-old man, recently diagnosed with hypertension, was started on telmisartan 2 weeks ago. On the follow-up visit, his blood pressure was still high and investigations revealed elevated urea and creatinine. His medical history includes diabetes and coronary artery disease. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Ultrasound Doppler of the renal arteries

questions.solution:
This patient diagnosed with hypertension presenting with deranged renal parameters after starting an angiotensin receptor blocker likely is suggestive of atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis, for which ultrasound Doppler of the renal arteries is the initial investigation. 

Renal artery stenosis secondary to atherosclerosis is an important cause of renovascular hypertension, occurring due to the occlusion of the proximal part of the renal arteries. The prevalence increases with age, diabetes, and for patients with other vascular conditions such as coronary artery disease, peripheral aortic(as evidenced by aortic bruits), or lower extremity disease.  

Critical levels of stenosis lead to a reduction in perfusion pressure that activates the renin-angiotensin system, reduces sodium excretion, and activates sympathetic adrenergic pathways. These events lead to systemic hypertension and accelerated target organ injury, including left ventricular hypertrophy and renal fibrosis.

Severe or refractory hypertension, carotid or femoral artery bruits, flash pulmonary edema, unexplained deterioration of renal function or deterioration of renal function associated with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) or an angiotensin receptor blocker(ARB) should raise the possibility of renovascular hypertension. These agents decrease the glomerular filtration rate in a stenotic kidney owing to efferent renal arteriolar dilation, particularly in bilateral renal artery stenosis. Approximately 50% of patients with renovascular hypertension have an abdominal or flank bruit, due to the stenosed renal arteries.

If renal artery stenosis is suspected imaging studies should be the next step in the evaluation. Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries produces reliable estimates of renal blood flow and offers the opportunity to track a lesion over time. Contrast arteriography remains the gold standard for the evaluation and identification of renal artery lesions.       

Medical therapy should include the use of ACE inhibitors or ARBs, attainment of goal BPs, cessation of tobacco, statins, and aspirin. Follow-up requires surveillance for progressive occlusion manifest by worsening renal function and/or loss of BP control. Renal revascularization is now often reserved for patients failing medical therapy or developing additional complications. 

Other options :

Option A: Estimation of plasma-free metanephrines is done in cases of suspected phaeochromocytoma. Among the presenting manifestations, episodes of palpitation, headache, and profuse sweating are typical and constitute a classic triad. The presence of all three manifestations in association with episodic hypertension makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis. 

Option B: Plasma aldosterone: plasma renin activity is estimated in primary hyperaldosteronism, where it is elevated to > 30:1. Primary hyperaldosteronism can be familial or sporadic, caused by an aldosterone-producing adenoma or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. The age at the time of diagnosis is generally the third through fifth decade. In patients with primary aldosteronism, increased aldosterone production is independent of the renin-angiotensin system, and the consequences are sodium retention, hypertension and hypokalemia.

Option D: Estimation of 24-hour urinary cortisol excretion is used as a screening test for Cushing's syndrome, which is one of the causes of secondary hypertension. The mechanism of hypertension may be related to stimulation of mineralocorticoid receptors by cortisol and increased secretion of other adrenal steroids. However, there will be other features like truncal obesity, plethoric moon facies, purple striae, proximal muscle weakness, hypokalemic alkalosis, hyperandrogenism, and psychological disturbances.

questions.text:
48. A 32-year-old man came with progressive difficulty in swallowing food. Barium study showed marked dilatation of the esophagus proximal to the obstruction. Further investigations reveal incomplete relaxation of the LES in response to swallowing, high resting LES pressure, and absent esophageal peristalsis. Which among the following is responsible for this?

LES - Lower esophageal sphincter VIP - Vasoactive intestinal peptide NO - Nitric oxide ACh - Acetylcholine
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of achalasia cardia. In this condition, VIP and NO are decreased causing failure of the LES to relax.

Achalasia cardia is a condition in which food accumulates in the esophagus. It leads to massive dilatation as a result of increased resting LES tone and incomplete relaxation on swallowing. The myenteric plexus of the esophagus is deficient at the LES and the release of NO and VIP is decreased.

Normally, the tone of the LES is under neural control. The release of acetylcholine from vagal endings causes the intrinsic sphincter to contract, and the release of NO and VIP from interneurons causes it to relax. The crural portion of the diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerves. Its contraction is coordinated with respiration and contractions of the chest and abdominal muscles. Thus, the intrinsic and extrinsic sphincters operate together. This permits the orderly flow of food into the stomach and prevents reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus.



Pearl PM1301: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: 49. An elderly man with a chronic history of smoking was admitted to the respiratory medicine department for complaints of cough with sputum production and breathlessness while carrying out daily activities for the past 6 months. The image given below shows the posture of the patient. What clinical findings will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Expiratory wheeze will be seen in this patient whose clinical features point towards a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

COPD is a progressive, preventable, and treatable respiratory disease, characterised by airflow limitation and an exaggerated inflammatory response of lung epithelium to noxious stimuli. Common risk factors include tobacco smoke, chronic exposure to coal and silica, and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The two phenotypes that can be seen are:

* Pink puffers: Normal PaCO2, thin and breathless

* Blue bloaters: Raised PaCO2, may develop secondary polycythemia

The characteristic 'tripod position' seen in the image is observed in COPD, allowing the accessory muscles of respiration, including the intercostal muscles, scalene, and sternocleidomastoid, to take action. A barrel chest, due to hyperinflation, can also be observed during inspection. In addition, wasting and cachexia will be seen in advanced stages due to a chronic increase in the levels of inflammatory cytokines and reduced appetite. On percussion, a poor diaphragmatic excursion is seen, and on auscultation, expiratory wheeze may be heard along with an increased duration of the expiratory phase. 

Other options:

Option A: Clubbing is not seen in COPD. Respiratory causes of clubbing include bronchogenic carcinoma, interstitial lung disease, and lung abscess.

Option C: Fine crepitations are seen in interstitial lung diseases.

Option D: A supraclavicular mass is seen in Pancoast tumour and in cases where supraclavicular lymph node enlargement is seen, such as tuberculous lymphadenitis and metastatic carcinoma.

questions.text:
50. A 15-year-old patient is undergoing a tonsillectomy as a day-care procedure. Which of the following findings would delay this patient from being discharged?
* The patient is drowsy but arousable, and vital signs are stable
* Mild nausea persists, but the patient has tolerated sips of clear fluids
* Pain is controlled with IV paracetamol administered 1 hour ago
* The patient has voided once and is ambulatory with minimal assistance
* There is blood-stained saliva, but no active bleeding from the oropharynx
questions.solution:
1 and 3 would delay this patient's discharge.

The patient is still drowsy, and pain is controlled with IV paracetamol but not with oral analgesics. Hence, these findings would delay the discharge of this patient.

The following are the standard discharge criteria for patients undergoing day care surgeries: 

* Vital signs stable for at least 1 hour 

* Orientation to time, place, and person (if appropriate)

* Adequate pain control with oral analgesics and understands how to use them

* Adequate ambulation (if appropriate)

* Minimal nausea, vomiting, or dizziness

* Has taken an oral diet

* Minimal wound drainage/bleeding  

* Has passed urine (if appropriate)

* Responsible attender

* Instructions about postoperative care, follow-up advice

In general, there is no specific time restriction as a criterion for discharging patients who undergo day care surgery; however, in tonsillectomy patients, in-hospital observation for 6 hours is necessary 

Day care surgery is the admission of selected patients to a hospital for a planned procedure and returning home on the same day. 

Surgical criteria include: 

* Low risk of significant immediate postoperative complications

* Tolerate oral diet postoperatively  

* Postoperative pain relief by oral analgesics

* Appropriate ambulation of the patient postoperatively.

Examples of day care surgeries include simple mastectomy, tonsillectomy, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, vaginal hysterectomy, knee/shoulder arthroscopy, ureteroscopic stone removal, and transluminal operations of the iliac and femoral vessels. 

Medical exclusions to daycare surgery include: 

* Unstable ASA 3

* ASA 4 or 5

* Any poorly controlled comorbidity

questions.text: 51. An elderly patient presents with fever, cough, and breathlessness after returning from his cruise journey. Auscultation reveals rales, and labs show hyponatremia. Which of the following culture media is used for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient returning from a cruise with fever, breathlessness, and auscultatory rales, along with hyponatremia, the diagnostic culture media typically used for testing Legionella would be BCYE (buffered charcoal yeast extract) agar (image 2) 

Culture provides a definitive diagnosis for Legionella pneumonia. It is highly sensitive and specific. Legionella is a fastidious organism that grows slowly (3–6 days) on enriched BCYE agar with L-cysteine, requiring 5% CO₂, pH 6.9, temperature 35°C, and high humidity (90%). Legionella is a gram-negative, aerobic, motile bacillus that stains poorly with the Gram stain but can be seen with silver and Giemsa stain.Legionella pneumophila serogroup 1 is the most common cause of human disease. It causes Legionnaires' disease (atypical pneumonia) and Pontiac fever (mild, flu-like illness). 

Transmission occurs via aspiration ( oropharyngeal colonisation or ingestion of contaminated water) or inhalation of contaminated aerosols. No human-to-human transmission is seen. Diagnosis is via direct immunofluorescence test, PCR or urinary antigen test (for serogroup 1). The urinary antigen test remains reliable even after prior antibiotic use. Azithromycin and respiratory quinolones are used for treatment.

Other options:

Option A: This represents TCBS agar, which contains thiosulfate, citrate, bile salts, and sucrose, which is used to culture Vibrio cholerae. It ferments sucrose, forming large yellow colonies.

Option C: This represents swarming on blood agar, which is exhibited by Proteus and Clostridium tetani.

Option D: This represents nutrient agar where colonies of Staphylococcus aureus produce golden yellow non-diffusible pigments.

Pearl PM0001: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria: Organism | Medium for culture Staph aureus | Mannitol salt agar ludlam’s medium salt milk agar Strep. Pyogenes | Crystal violet blood agar Neisseria meningitidis | Thayer martin medium Corynebacterium | Potassium tellurite agar Tinsdale medium Mcleod medium B.anthrax | PLET medium B.cereus | MYPA (Mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin agar) PEMBA(polymyxin in egg yolk mannitol bromothymol blue agar Clostridium | CCFA ( cefoxitin cycloserine fructose agar) Shigella | DCA, XLD, SSA Salmonella | Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium Vibrio | TCBS Monsur GTTA Pseudomonas | Cetrimide agar B.pseudomallei | Ashdown medium H. influenza | Fildes agar Levinthal medium Bordetella | Bordet-Gengou glycerine potato blood agar Brucella | Casteneda medium B.burgdorferi | BSK medium Campylobacter | Skirrow's, Butzler's and Campy BAP media Legionella pneumophilia | BCYE medium Leptospira | EMJH medium

questions.text: 52. A 4 months-old male child was brought to the hospital with the complaints of a lesion in the abdomen as shown in the image. The drug used for the treatment of this condition is _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows flat to elevated, irregular, red-blue masses in the skin of the abdomen, suggestive of hemangioma. Propranolol is the preferred treatment of infantile hemangioma complicated by ulceration or in symptomatic patients who require intervention.

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis, and inhibiting angiogenesis. Propranolol at 2 mg/Kg/day has been found useful in infants younger than 6 months and children up to 5 years of age.

Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumours of infancy and childhood. They are of the following types:

* Capillary hemangiomas:

*

* They are the most common type.

* They occur in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and mucous membranes of the oral cavities and lips, as well as in the liver, spleen, and kidneys

* On histology, they show thin-walled capillaries with scant stroma

* Juvenile hemangiomas/strawberry type hemangiomas of the newborn are extremely common. They arise in the skin and grow rapidly for a few months, and usually regress completely by the age of 7 years.

* Cavernous hemangiomas:

* They are composed of large, dilated vascular channels; are more infiltrative; frequently involve deep structures; and do not spontaneously regress.

* On histologic examination, the mass is sharply delineated but unencapsulated, composed of large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces separated by a connective tissue stroma.

* They commonly show intravascular thrombosis with associated dystrophic calcification

* Brain hemangiomas cause symptoms related to compression of adjacent tissue or rupture.

* They form a component of von Hippel-Lindau disease in which vascular lesions are commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver

* Pyogenic granulomas

*

* They are capillary hemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingiva, or oral mucosa.

* They bleed easily and are often ulcerated.

* Lesions may develop after trauma, reaching a size of 1 to 2 cm within a few weeks.

* Treatment is curettage and cautery

Complications of infantile hemangioma include pain, functional impairment, or permanent disfigurement.

Timolol is also used in the treatment of infantile hemangioma.

Options B, C, D: Bisoprolol, acebutolol, betaxolol are cardioselective beta-blockers that are not used in the treatment of hemangioma.

questions.text:
53. Which of the following is an indication of emergency surgical exploration in case of renal trauma? * Avulsion of the pelvi-ureteric junction * Expanding retroperitoneal hematoma * Grade III AAST injury * Injury to the renal pedicle

AAST - American association for the surgery of trauma
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct indications for emergency surgical exploration in renal trauma.

Indications that require emergency surgical exploration are:

* Avulsion of the pelvi-ureteric junction

* Expanding/pulsatile retroperitoneal hematoma

* Injury to the renal pedicle

* Hemodynamic instability

* Grade V AAST injury

Renal trauma is more commonly the result of blunt injury. A unique mechanism of injury includes avulsion of the ureter at the pelvi-ureteric junction or renal pedicle, often caused by sudden, rapid deceleration—such as in high-speed motor vehicle accidents. Hematuria remains a hallmark sign of renal trauma; however, its absence does not rule out significant injury. The investigation of choice for diagnosing renal trauma is a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen in stable patients and a single-shot intravenous urogram in unstable patients.

In cases of lower-grade(I-III) renal injuries—including some grade IV injuries—conservative management is often sufficient. This typically involves bed rest, serial haemoglobin monitoring, and the administration of antibiotics in cases of penetrating trauma to prevent infection. Grade IV injuries, which require surgical exploration, involve intraperitoneal and vascular injury. Grade IV injuries with urinoma require a DJ  (double J) stent for sterile cases and pigtail catheter drainage for infected cases. Grade V injuries require partial/total nephrectomy.

Pearl PM2238: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Kidney Injury Scale

GRADE | INJURY | DESCRIPTION I | Contusion | Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal | Hematoma | Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration II | Hematoma | Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum | Laceration | <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation III | Laceration | >1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation IV | Laceration | Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system | Vascular | Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage V | Laceration | Completely shattered kidney | Laceration | Avulsion of renal hilum, which devascularizes kidney

questions.text: 54. A forensic pathologist is examining a specimen of a lung. The lung appears red, boggy, and heavy. A microscopic view of the slide is shown below. Proliferation of which of the following cells is seen in the proliferation phase of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts diffuse alveolar haemorrhage, which, along with the gross lung findings described, is indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Type II pneumocytes are known to proliferate during the proliferative stage of acute respiratory syndrome.

ARDS is referred to as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and has 3 pathological stages:- 

* Acute exudative stage

* Proliferative stage

* Fibrotic stage

Diffuse alveolar damage is observed in the acute exudative stage, where the lungs appear firm, heavy, red, and boggy. Furthermore, congestion and inflammatory changes, such as intra-alveolar and interstitial edema, followed by fibrin deposition, are observed, along with the formation of alveolar hyaline membranes by the remains of necrotic epithelial cells. Granulation tissue is seen in the proliferative stage due to the proliferation of type II pneumocytes. The granulation tissue may resolve or may cause fibrous proliferation of the alveolar septa in the late fibrotic stage.

Other options:

Option A: Type I pneumocytes are squamous epithelial cells forming the exchange barrier for gases in the blood. In ARDS, they are destroyed due to inflammation and are replenished by differentiation of the proliferating type II pneumocytes.

Option C: Goblet cells secrete mucin, which aids in trapping mucous and debris, thus protecting the respiratory lining. Moreover, they also facilitate mucociliary clearance and moisten the airway.

Option D: Club cells, previously known as Clara cells, are also protective cells that secrete the club cell secretory protein (CC16), which acts as a biomarker for respiratory inflammation in ARDS.

Pearl PM0384: Diseases Caused by Inflammation and Cells Involved

Disorders | Cells and Molecules involved Acute | ARDS | Neutrophils Asthma | Eosinophls, IgE antibodies Glomerulonephritis | Antibodies complement, neutrophils, monocytes Septic shock | Cytokines | Chronic | Arthritis | Lymphocytes and macrophages Asthma | Eosinophls, IgE antibodies Atherosclerosis | Macrophages, lymphocytes Pulmonary fibrosis | Macrophages, fibroblasts

ARDS: Acute respiratory distress syndrome

questions.text:
55. A patient came to the ED with a history of flexion and deflexion injury in an RTA. The picture below shows the posture. Excitation of which tract explains the flexion of the upper limbs?

ED - Emergency Department, RTA - Road Traffic Accident
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image, is suggestive of decorticate rigidity, in which the flexion of the upper limbs against the chest is due to the excitation of the rubrospinal tract.

Cerebral cortex injury leads to decorticate rigidity, as shown in the image, where the lower limbs are hyperextended and there is flexion of the elbows. The hyperextension of the lower extremities is because of the midcollicular decerebration, which interrupts all the cortical inputs, along with inputs from the red nucleus, to the lower limb muscles. 

Decerebrate rigidity, on the other hand, is due to activation of the alpha motor neuron, which is activated by the gamma motor neuron, which is excited by an excitatory stimulus from the reticulospinal pathway. It is characterized by the hyperextension of the upper and lower limbs.

The image below shows both decerebrate and decorticate posturing.



Other options:

Option A: The corticospinal tract is the principal motor tract. Lesions of the corticospinal tract lead to loss of activity of antigravity muscles, and a characteristic pyramidal pattern of weakness is noted, where the upper limb is flexed and adducted while the lower limbs are extended and abducted. Midcollicular decerebration, which causes hyperextension of lower limbs, interrupts cortical inputs, which include those from the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts.

Option B: The vestibulospinal tract plays an important role in maintaining posture, balance, and head position. The medial vestibulospinal tract adjusts head position by controlling the neck and axial muscles. The lateral vestibulospinal tract ensures stable upright posture by projecting to the entire spinal cord by activating the limb and trunk extensor muscles.

Option C: The reticulospinal tract, part of the extrapyramidal system, controls posture, balance, locomotion, and autonomic functions. It has two parts: the medial (pontine) tract, which facilitates voluntary movement and increases muscle tone, and the lateral (medullary) tract, which inhibits voluntary movement and reduces muscle tone. This tract coordinates motor activities and maintains body stability and is implicated in the pathophysiology of decerebrate rigidity.

questions.text: 56. A 28-year-old primigravida at term presents to the emergency department with 5 cm cervical dilation and lower abdominal pain. She requests pain relief. Up to which sensory level should the neuraxial blockade be administered for this stage of labor?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a neuraxial blockade should be given up to the T10-L1 sensory level, as the patient is in the first stage of labour.

The first stage of labour begins with the onset of true labour and extends till the complete dilatation of the cervix. During this stage, distension of the cervix and the lower uterine segments, along with isometric uterine contraction, is responsible for lower abdominal pain and discomfort via the sympathetic plexus (T10-L1). For pain relief in this stage, epidural analgesia is the most effective. A mixture of 10-15ml 0.1% bupivacaine with 2mcg/l fentanyl is used. Low-dose bupivacaine ensures that the motor function is preserved in addition to providing adequate analgesia.

In the second stage of labour, however, neuraxial blockade at T10-S4 is warranted. This is because pain in the second stage is caused by tissue damage in the perineum. Regional analgesia in the form of an epidural or spinal block can be given. Maintenance of the analgesia from the first stage can also be done. This can be done by ensuring regular top-ups, continuous infusions, or the use of patient-controlled epidural analgesia.

Entonox (50:50 mixture of N20 and O2) has also been used as an inhalational analgesic to alleviate pain during second-stage contractions. In case an episiotomy is done, a pudendal block should be given before the episiotomy.

Pearl PM0482: Regional Anesthesia in Obstetrics

* Pregnant patients display enhanced sensitivity to LA during regional anesthesia because of hormonal factors and engorgement of epidural venous plexus resulting in decreased epidural space and subarachnoid space (CSF volume).This enhances the cephalad spread of LA solution during spinal and epidural anesthesia.

* Lower doses of LA agents and pain relief drugs are used because of altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics during parturition as a result of hormonal and cardiovascular effects.

* Lignocaine is less protein bound and nerves are more sensitive to LA agents.

* NOT a cause of decreased anesthetic requirement during pregnancy Increased lumbar lordosis.

* The level of the block under spinal anesthesia is desirable upto T4.

* Lumbar epidural - The most preferred technique for painless labor.

questions.text: 57. A 16-year-old boy presented with complaints of multiple skin lesions over his back. On examination, various erythematous, scaly lesions parallel to the ribs are noted, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing the Christmas tree sign, is suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

Pityriasis rosea/pityriasis circinata et maculata of Vidal is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults.

Even though the exact cause is unknown, T-cell-mediated immunity and infectious etiology are thought to be responsible for this condition. An association with infectious agents like human herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and human herpesvirus-7 (HHV-7) has been found recently.

Clinical features include:

* Prodrome of a sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbance, fever, or arthralgia.

* Herald patch - Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk, or neck covered by fine scales

The image given below shows a herald patch.



* After 5-15 days, it turns into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales. 

* These secondary lesions occur as macules and papules that are elliptical or ovular, symmetric, and commonly involve the thorax, back, and abdomen.

* It is followed by a marginal collarette of scale with central wrinkling and atrophy. The collarettes of the scales are attached peripherally. It is also called a hanging curtain sign.

The image given below shows collarette scales.



* The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of skin tension parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.

The images given below show a Christmas tree pattern along the lines of skin tension on the back and the chest.





The rashes of pityriasis rosea usually resolve in 8 weeks.

Dermatoscopy shows:

* Yellowish background-color

* Peripheral arrangement of the scales

* Patchy distribution of loosely arranged dotted vessels

Histopathology shows:

* Superficial perivascular dermatitis with focal parakeratosis, hyperplasia and spongiosis in the epidermis.

* Extravasated red blood cells, along with a perivascular infiltrate and subcorneal pustules, are seen in the dermis.

No treatment is required for asymptomatic cases. Application of irritants to the skin and tanning should be avoided since it may result in pigmentary changes. Emollients and antihistaminics are useful in relieving itching. If symptomatic, various agents are used such as:

* First-line agents: If severe pruritus or poor cosmetic appeal is present

* Topical steroids

* Narrowband UV-B therapy

* Second-line agents: For a rapid resolution of the lesions, given the probable infectious aetiology.

* Antivirals like acyclovir

* Macrolides like erythromycin

Pityriasis rosea within the first few weeks of gestation may cause premature delivery and fetal demise. Pityriasis rosea-like eruptions were reported after ingestion of drugs like gold, captopril, aspirin, metronidazole and clonidine and after vaccinations like BCG, influenza, diphtheria, hepatitis B, and Pneumococcus.

Other options:

Option A: Psoriasis has silvery-white plaques.

Option C: Lichen planus has violaceous polygonal pruritic papules. It also has Wickham's striae.

Option D: Pityriasis rubra pilaris has circumscribed follicular keratoses.

questions.text:
58. Which of the following methods are used to estimate maternal deaths when complete and accurate civil registration methods are unavailable?
* RAMOS
* Census
* Sisterhood methods
* Verbal autopsy
* Lot Quality Assurance Sampling
questions.solution:
In the absence of complete and accurate civil registration systems, options 1, 2, 3, and 4 can be employed to estimate maternal deaths. 

According to the WHO, a maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management, but not from unintentional or incidental causes.

Methods for estimating maternal mortality:

* Civil Registration Systems provide the most comprehensive and accurate statistics on maternal mortality data, which ideally should come from routine birth and death registrations.

* Accurate assessment of maternal mortality often faces challenges due to the absence of comprehensive civil registration systems. In such cases, various alternative methods are employed to estimate the maternal mortality ratio (MMR):

*

* Reproductive-Age Mortality Studies (RAMOS) (Option 1) identifies and investigates the causes of all deaths among women of reproductive age within a defined population or area, utilising multiple data sources.

* Census (Option 2) can be adapted to produce estimates of maternal mortality by incorporating a limited number of relevant questions.

* Sisterhood Method (Option 3) involves interviewing a representative sample of individuals about the survival of their adult sisters. Information gathered includes the number of ever-married sisters, how many are alive or deceased, and how many died during pregnancy, childbirth, or within six weeks postpartum.

* Verbal Autopsy (Option 4) is used in settings where medical certification of death causes is not feasible. It assigns a cause of death through interviews with family or community members.

* Household Surveys offer a practical alternative when robust civil registration data are unavailable.

Lot Quality Assurance Sampling (LQAS) (Option 5) is an efficient method for quality assurance that enables quick and cost-effective data collection. It helps program managers evaluate performance and assess whether objectives and targets are met in a specific unit of interest. It does not estimate mortality.

questions.text: 61. A histologist is studying the structure of lymphoid tissue. The below finding is seen in which of the following lymphoid tissues?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows Hassall's corpuscles; these are seen in the thymus. 

Histology of the thymus

The thymus is a lymphoid tissue that is arranged in the form of lobules. The lobules are separated from each other by connective tissue.  Each lobule is made up of an outer, darker-staining cortex and an inner pale-staining medulla. The medulla contains small, pink, rounded masses called Hassall's corpuscles. They have a central core of degenerated epithelial cells that stain pink. Around this is a circle of epithelial cells that stain pink with hematoxylin and eosin stains. The function of these corpuscles is not clearly understood. The image below shows the histology of the thymus.



Structure of a lymph node

Each lymph node is bean-shaped. The concave part consists of the hilum, through which the blood vessels enter and leave the node. Microscopy shows the following features:

Each lymph node is surrounded by a thin capsule. Below the capsule is the clear space, which is called the subcapsular sinus. 

The lymph node contains the outer cortex and an inner medulla. The cortex consists of densely packed lymphocytes and therefore stains dark. Numerous follicles can be seen in the cortex. Each nodule has a pale-staining germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. The medulla consists of lymphocytes arranged in the form of anastomosing cords. It appears pale. Numerous blood vessels can be seen in this area.

The image below shows the histology of the lymph node:



Structure of spleen (Option A)

The spleen is the largest lymphoid organ of the body.

It is surrounded by a thick capsule. This capsule extends into the organ, forming trabeculae. The substance of the spleen consists of red pulp and white pulp. In red pulp, the lymphocytes are diffusely distributed and contain numerous sinusoids. In white pulp, the lymphocytes are densely packed and arranged in the form of cords around the arterioles.

When cut transversely, the cords are similar to the nodules in the lymph nodes. They have a pale germinal center surrounded by a ring of densely packed lymphocytes. However, there is an eccentrically placed arteriole within the germinal center.

The image below shows the spleen: WP- white pulp, RP- Red pulp, CR- central arteriole.



Structure of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (Options B and D)

The aggregations are in the form of lymphatic follicles. Germinal centers may be present. Between the nodules, there is diffuse lymphoid tissue, which is called a parafollicular zone. The nodules predominantly consist of B lymphocytes with T lymphocytes in the diffuse areas.

They lie close to the epithelium. They are not surrounded by a capsule and also do not have connective tissue septa. They have a supporting network of reticular fibers. Examples are palatine tonsils, Peyer's patches, and lymphoid nodules in the vermiform appendix.

The image below shows Peyer's patches.

questions.text: 62. A patient presents to the emergency department after a poisonous snakebite. On examination, there is rapid swelling of the entire limb. The spread of oedema and venom through the connective tissue is primarily the action of which venom enzyme?
questions.solution:
Hyaluronidase is responsible for the spread of venom through the connective tissue.

Hyaluronidase is an enzyme that breaks down hyaluronic acid, a key component of the extracellular matrix. It hydrolyzes hyaluronic acid, decreasing tissue viscosity and thereby allowing toxins to spread rapidly through tissues. It is present in every snake venom.

Snake venom is a complex mixture of enzymes, proteins, polypeptides, and toxins. It is produced in specialized venom glands and is delivered through the fangs. The venom is water and alcohol soluble. 

Based on predominant action, venom can be classified as neurotoxic, vasculotoxic, and myotoxic. Neurotoxic venom blocks the neuromuscular transmission, and its key component is neurotoxin. Vasculotoxic venom causes coagulopathy, hemorrhage, and DIC. Myotoxic venom causes rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria.

Other options:

Option A: Phospholipases cause neurotoxicity as they help in the penetration of neurotoxins into the nerves. It destroys phospholipids in the nervous tissue.

Option C: The yellow colour of the snake venom is due to L-amino acid oxidase. It is not responsible for the spread of venom.

Option D: Proteinases help in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin. Hence, they help in promoting a coagulant effect.

63. A patient presents with rapidly progressive oliguria and edema following an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis 2 weeks ago. His urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Serum creatinine is 4.0 mg/dL. Renal biopsy shows the presence of crescents. What is the likely diagnosis?

RPGN: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario the most likely diagnosis is type II RPGN mediated by immune-complex deposition. 

The patient presenting with oliguria, edema, with an elevated serum creatinine, crescents on renal biopsy, and a past history of streptococcal pharyngitis, is suggestive of postinfectious glomerulonephritis. It is a type II RPGN.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury. It is characterized by a rapid decline of renal function with severe oliguria. On histology, it is characterized by the presence of crescents in glomeruli. The crescents constrict the capillary tuft, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate, thus causing acute kidney injury.



Type II RPGN is characterized by immune complex deposition. Immunofluorescence will reveal granular deposits of antibodies and complement. Examples of this type include RPGN due to postinfectious glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis, IgA nephropathy, or Henoch-Schönlein purpura.

questions.text: 64. A 75-year-old male patient with chronic kidney disease comes for a routine follow-up. His chest radiograph is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a mitral annular calcification. It is a chronic degenerative process affecting the mitral valve ring and can be a rheumatic sequela. 

The clinical vignette gives clues towards the multiple co-morbidities and complications that may be associated with MAC. 

* Stroke

* Atherosclerosis

* Chronic Kidney Disease 

* Mitral Regurgitation 

* Mitral Stenosis 

* Arrhythmias, atrial fibrillation 

* Endocarditis 

* Aortic Stenosis 

Surgical treatment is indicated only if concomitant stenosis or regurgitation is to be corrected. Severe MAC makes the surgery difficult. Isolated MAC does not require endocarditis prophylaxis. Anti-coagulation and anti-platelet medications are recommended within the guidelines of treatment of the comorbid conditions.



Other options:

Option A: In aortic sclerosis, there can be aortic valvular calcifications with cardiomegaly. Signs of heart failure such as pulmonary venous congestion and pulmonary interstitial/alveolar edema can be seen. 

Option C: Atrial Myxomas have non-specific x-ray findings- 

* Cardiomegaly: left atrial enlargement

* Intracardiac tumoral calcification

* Mitral valve obstruction evidence 

* Elevated left atrial pressure findings- pulmonary edema

Option D: A calcified atrial thrombus is a rare entity that may show up as calcified lesions in the cardiac shadow on a chest x-ray. They are usually discovered by transthoracic echocardiography.

questions.text: 65. Which atypical antipsychotic is most likely responsible for QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
Among atypical (second-generation) antipsychotics, Ziprasidone is most likely responsible for QT prolongation.

Ziprasidone is most strongly associated with QT interval prolongation and carries a significant risk of precipitating torsades de pointes and sudden cardiac death.

QT interval represents ventricular depolarisation and repolarization, measured from the onset of QRS to the end of the T wave. Since QT varies with heart rate, it is corrected using  Bazett's formula, QTc = QT/ √RR. Normal QTc is about 440 ms. Values of more than 440 ms in males and 450 ms in females are considered to be prolonged. The patient presents with syncope, near syncope, or cardiac arrest. QT prolongation is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

The ECG in the image below shows QT prolongation.



Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia characterized by the twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance. 

The image below shows an ECG of torsades de pointes with twisting of the QRS axis and polymorphic appearance.



If the patient is hemodynamically stable, IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and prevention of the recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Other options:

Option A: Clozapine is associated with agranulocytosis, myocarditis, and metabolic syndrome.

Option C: Olanzapine is more associated with weight gain, metabolic side effects, and sedation.

Option D: Risperidone causes extrapyramidal side effects and hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: 66. A lesion in a brain region results in ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, pupillary dilation, and difficulty with upward gaze. The affected nuclei in this region develop from which embryological structure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests involvement of the oculomotor and trochlear nuclei, located in the midbrain. The midbrain originates from the mesencephalon.

A lesion in the midbrain causes ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, pupillary dilation, and difficulty with upward gaze because of the involvement of nuclei of cranial nerves III, IV, and Edinger-Westphal.

During development, the basal plate of the mesencephalon gives rise to two main groups of motor nuclei:

* A medial somatic efferent group, which includes the nuclei of cranial nerves III (oculomotor) and IV (trochlear), is responsible for innervating the extraocular muscles.

* A general visceral efferent group, represented by the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, which controls the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscles involved in pupillary constriction and lens accommodation.

Lateral to these motor nuclei, the marginal layer of the basal plate expands to form the crus cerebri (cerebral peduncles). These structures serve as major descending fiber tracts, carrying motor signals from the cerebral cortex to lower centers in the brainstem and spinal cord.

The alar plates of the mesencephalon develop into longitudinal elevations that are divided by a transverse groove into the superior and inferior colliculi. These colliculi form part of the tectum, or dorsal aspect of the midbrain:

* The inferior colliculi function as relay centers for auditory pathways and mediate auditory reflexes.

* The superior colliculi are involved in visual processing and coordination of visual reflexes, such as tracking moving objects.

The colliculi are formed through the migration of neuroblasts into the marginal zone of the developing tectum.

questions.text: 67. A 2-year-old child is brought by her parents complaining of seizures, perioral desquamating lesions and alopecia. The parents also complain that the child's urine has a peculiar odour-described as tomcat urine. Investigation reveals the child has multiple carboxylase deficiency. The vitamin deficient in this condition act as cofactor for all the enzymes except:
questions.solution:
The vitamin deficient in multiple carboxylase deficiency is biotin, which acts as a cofactor for all the given enzymes except for gamma-glutamyl carboxylase.

Gamma carboxylation is a post-translational modification of proteins where a carboxyl group is added to glutamate residues to form an amino acid gamma carboxyglutamate. This is a vitamin K-dependent process.

Vitamin K-dependent gamma carboxylation is necessary for activation of certain clotting factors such as Factor II,  Factor VII, Factor IX and Factor X. This is also necessary for the functional activity of osteocalcin as well as structural proteins of the kidney, lungs and spleen.

Multiple carboxylase deficiency can be caused by a deficiency in biotin, which acts as the cofactor for four-carboxylase enzymes. They are:

* Pyruvate carboxylase

* Acetyl-CoA carboxylase

* Propionyl-CoA carboxylase

* 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase

Multiple carboxylase deficiency mostly occurs due to defects in biotin metabolism. Deficiencies in holocarboxylase synthetase, biotinidase or biotin can result in impaired catalytic activity of carboxylases and organic acidemias.

Holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency is a rare autosomal recessive disorder where symptoms usually appear in the first few weeks of life. Affected infants present with breathing difficulties, feeding problems, vomiting, hypotonia, and may later develop rashes, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures, and developmental delay. Urine has a peculiar odour described as “tomcat” odour.

Biotinidase deficiency is also an inherited disorder causing impaired recycling of biotin, leading to biotin deficiency. Symptoms are similar to holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency but appear later, usually after weeks to years. Clinical features include skin rashes, alopecia, developmental delay, seizures, hypotonia, hearing and vision problems, and recurrent infections due to immune dysfunction. 

Multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with a pharmacological dose of biotin.

Acquired biotin deficiency can occur in infants on prolonged total parenteral nutrition without biotin, in patients taking long-term antiepileptic drugs, children with short bowel syndrome or chronic diarrhoea, and those on low biotin formulas. Clinical features include dermatitis, alopecia, and candidal skin infections.

questions.text: 68. A 40-year-old man presents with a history of weakness and fatigue for the past three months. There is no history of alcohol consumption or intake of any drugs. A complete blood count and peripheral smear show evidence of megaloblastic anemia and a normal reticulocyte count. He is found to have vitamin B12 deficiency on further laboratory testing. What is the most likely cause of anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Autoimmune gastritis.

Autoimmune gastritis refers to a chronic, diffuse inflammatory disease of the stomach that is restricted to the body and fundus. This disorder typically features diffuse atrophic gastritis, antibodies to parietal cells and the intrinsic factor, and increased serum gastrin due to G-cell hyperplasia. Due to the neutralization of the intrinsic factor, there is decreased absorption of vitamin B12. As a result, all lineages of bone marrow precursors show asynchronous maturation between the nucleus and cytoplasm (megaloblastic cells), and the peripheral blood displays megaloblastic anemia.

Various features of autoimmune gastritis include:

* Pernicious anemia (anti-intrinsic factor positivity is specific)

* Vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia 

* Hypergastrinemia 

* Reduce serum pepsinogen

* Achlorhydria

Megaloblastic anemia that is caused by malabsorption of vitamin B12, due to a deficiency of the intrinsic factor, is called pernicious anemia. Circulating antibodies to parietal cells occur in 90% of patients with pernicious anemia. Two-thirds of patients display an antibody to the intrinsic factor that prevents its combination with vitamin B12, thereby preventing the formation of the complex that is later absorbed in the ileum.

69. A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of the following features are present in this condition?
* Edema in the mastoid region
* Lateral rectus palsy
* Pus points below the conjunctiva
* Severe supraorbital pain
questions.solution:
The features of cavernous sinus thrombosis are edema in the mastoid region, lateral rectus palsy, and severe supraorbital pain.



Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis are:

* Fever

* Severe Headache

* Eye signs-

* Early abducent nerve (6th cranial nerve) involvement causing lateral rectus palsy.

* Later involvement of oculomotor (3rd cranial nerve) and trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve) causing palsy.

* Proptosis, restricted eye motility

* Severe supraorbital pain

* Chemosis

* Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve

* Ipsilateral ptosis dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex are signs of 3rd cranial nerve palsy.

* Edema in the mastoid region due to thrombosis of the emissary vein is a pathognomic sign.

* Focal neurological deficits

* Focal or generalized seizures

* Altered mental status. 

Investigation using brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently. Following early diagnosis, management of cavernous sinus thrombosis typically includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants.

questions.text: 70. Any of the following may be used for the management of a patient with mild scoliosis, except _____.
questions.solution:
The Sternal occipital mandibular immobilizer or SOMI brace is used in cervical spine injury, not in scoliosis.

Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. They usually extend from the thoracic and lumbar spine to the pelvis and have pads to push the spine into correct alignment. 

Braces used in scoliosis:

* Milwaukee brace : 

* Originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO), introduced in the 1940s

* Less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces

* Still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine



* Boston brace:

* It is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). 

* It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside.

* It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower.



* Risser's cast :

* Body cast that extends up to the cervical spine and touches the chin and skull

* A hole is cut in the abdominal region to make breathing easy



* Charleston bending brace & Providence brace:

* Used while laying down and sleeping at night for 8 to 10 hours

* Best suited for single thoracolumbar or lumbar curves

questions.text: 71. A 68-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease presents with complaints of persistent constipation. Which of the following laxatives will you not advise?
questions.solution:
Magnesium hydroxide is not advised for a patient with stage 4 chronic kidney disease because of the risk of magnesium accumulation and toxicity due to impaired renal excretion.

Magnesium hydroxide is a saline laxative that exerts its actions by osmotic water retention, thus stimulating peristalsis. It should also be used with caution in patients with cardiac disease, pre-existing electrolyte imbalances, or those receiving diuretic therapy. Magnesium-containing compounds, used as laxatives, may trigger the release of cholecystokinin, leading to fluid buildup in the intestines and increased bowel movements.

Other options:

Option A: Lactulose is a disaccharide that gently relieves constipation by drawing water into the colon and boosting natural bowel movements - especially helpful for opioid-induced, age-related, or chronic constipation.

Option C: Lubiprostone helps relieve constipation by activating chloride channels in the gut, increasing fluid secretion. This softens stools and naturally boosts bowel movements.

Option D: Senna, a natural stimulant laxative from Cassia plants, gently stimulates the bowel within 6–12 hours, but long-term use may cause side effects like cramping, nausea, and darkening of the colon lining (melanosis coli). It is safe in renal insufficiency as it is excreted via the bile.

questions.text: 72. An elderly asthmatic patient develops influenza-like illness and is started on a neuraminidase inhibitor. Soon after inhalation therapy, he develops bronchospasm. Which drug is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
This patient with influenza-like illness is started on a neuraminidase inhibitor but soon after inhalation therapy develops bronchospasm. The drug most likely responsible is Zanamivir.

Neuraminidase inhibitors are the mainstay of therapy for influenza A and B , acting by blocking the release of newly formed virions from infected host cells  . Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are the most widely used neuraminidase inhibitors.

Zanamivir is administered via inhalation; this route delivers high concentrations directly to the respiratory tract, but can precipitate bronchospasm, especially in patients with underlying airway disease such as asthma or COPD. Hence, zanamivir is not recommended in patients with chronic respiratory disorders.

Other options:

Option A: Oseltamivir, an oral neuraminidase inhibitor, does not cause bronchospasm.

Option B: Amantadine works as an M2 ion channel inhibitor, not a neuraminidase inhibitor.

Option D: Baloxavir marboxil is a cap-dependent endonuclease inhibitor.

questions.text: 73. A 55-year-old patient with a history of seizures is on maintenance treatment with Phenytoin. A few weeks after starting a new antifungal medication for an infection, the patient develops symptoms of phenytoin toxicity. Which of the following antifungal medications is the most likely cause of this interaction?
questions.solution:
Fluconazole is the antifungal drug that can cause phenytoin toxicity as it inhibits CYP2C9, which metabolises phenytoin.

Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant drug with a narrow therapeutic index. It is primarily metabolised by the CYP450 enzymes, specifically CYP2C9 and CYP2C8.

When a patient on phenytoin starts a new medication that can either inhibit or induce these enzymes, phenytoin metabolism will be affected.

questions.text: 74. A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of his nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. The histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a nodule on the nose and the given histological image showing Mikulicz cells are suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli. The history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodules corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). It has 3 stages:

1. Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

2. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.



3. Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called a tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option A: Even though the inner canthus of the eye is a common site for the occurrence of basal cell carcinoma, the given histology does not show palisade of the basaloid epithelium, which is very classical of BCC.

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

75. An 8-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of staring spells in school. She is diagnosed with absence seizures. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for ethosuximide, a drug commonly used for this condition?

GABA: gamma-Aminobutyric acid

choices.text: Inhibition of the T-type calcium channels

questions.solution:
Ethosuximide is commonly used in children suffering from absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is the inhibition of T-type calcium channels.

Absence seizures originate in the thalamus and produce the pathognomonic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG. This pattern is produced due to the intrinsic properties of the low threshold T-type calcium channels of the thalamus. These channels are activated at a much lower threshold and produce larger currents as compared to most other calcium channels in the brain. Hence, inhibition of these T-type calcium currents in the neurons of the thalamus by ethosuximide is effective for the management of absence seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Valproate acts by blocking both calcium and sodium channels. It is effective in the treatment of absence, myoclonic, focal, and tonic-clonic seizures.

Option B: Vigabatrin inhibits GABA transaminase and thus increases GABA concentration in the brain. It is the drug of choice for infantile spasms seen in tuberous sclerosis.

Option C: Benzodiazepines enhance GABA-mediated synaptic inhibition. Benzodiazepines act at GABAA receptors and increase the frequency, but not duration, of openings at GABA-activated Cl− channels

questions.text: 76. A young woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea, presents with complaints of heavy vaginal bleeding. On examination, an open cervical os with tissue protruding is seen. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material in the uterine cavity, no adnexal masses, no free fluid, and no viable pregnancy. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient has an incomplete abortion and the most appropriate management would be to evacuate the contents of the uterus with dilatation and curettage.

The patient can present with complaints of the expulsion of fleshy mass per vagina, continuous vaginal bleeding, and abdominal cramps. Internal examination reveals open cervical os, and products of conception protruding out of the cervix. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material (retained products of conception) within the cavity and no viable pregnancy. There are no adnexal masses, and no free fluid found on ultrasonography, ruling out ectopic pregnancy. All this confirms the diagnosis of incomplete abortion. 

Incomplete abortion can be managed surgically, or medically. The surgical method is by dilatation and curettage, it has the least failure rate and gives a quick resolution. For medical management of incomplete abortion at <13 weeks gestation, use of 600 μg misoprostol administered orally or use of 400 μg misoprostol administered sublingually, is recommended.

Note- For medical management of incomplete miscarriage, the use of 400–800 μg vaginal misoprostol has been removed in the updated recommendation from the WHO 2012 Safe abortion guidance (6).

Pearl PM2131: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

* Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother

* Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure

* Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest

* Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

* Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.

* MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.

* The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

* Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion

* 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion

* For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

* Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations

* Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)

* At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: 78. A 24-year-old woman using soft hydrophilic contact lenses presents with the following clinical picture. Which of the following is the first step in the management?
questions.solution:
The presence of giant papillae (>1mm ) on the upper tarsal conjunctiva in a patient wearing contact lenses is indicative of GPC (Giant papillary conjunctivitis),and the first step in management is the discontinuation of contact lens use, since the inciting factor must be removed for any therapy to be effective.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis, a specific type of allergic conjunctivitis, predominantly affects the superior tarsal conjunctiva. It is most often associated with contact lens wear ( particularly soft hydrophilic, but also rigid lenses with long-term use ) , exposed suture , or ocular prostheses. The pathogenesis involves a hypersensitivity reaction (types 1 and 4) triggered by chronic mechanical irritation and protein deposits on the lens surface.

Clinically, patients present with itching, watering, foreign body sensation, and blurred vision. treatment includes mast cell stabilizers, artificial tears, antihistaminic drops (Option C), and decongestants . Topical corticosteroids (Option A) may be used for short courses in severe cases, but only after the primary measure of lens discontinuation.

Other option:

Option B: Surgical excision of the papillae does not treat the root cause, mechanical or allergic irritation. and caries risk of scarring and papillae often recurs.
