questions.text: 80. In a microbiology lab, 50% of employees received the prophylactic pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine while the remaining 50% did not. Which of the following statistical tests can be used to see whether the vaccination program made any difference in the health outcomes of the employees?
questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is the statistical test that can be used to determine whether the vaccination program made any difference in the health outcomes of the employees. This is because it can test for differences in two or more categories when all the variables are qualitative or nominal (variables having two or more categories and a natural ranking or ordering). The variables in this case are qualitative.

The Chi-square test is a non-parametric test of significance employed for two proportions using qualitative variables. It has the advantage of being of use when more than two groups are to be compared. It also offers information on the significance of any observed differences.

Other options:

Option A: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option B: The student’s t-test is used for quantitative data. Here the data is qualitative, hence it can't be used.

Option C: Medical record linkage is the assembly and maintenance of a file for each individual in a population using important records relating to his health. It is a suitable method of studying associations between diseases.

Pearl PM1104: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

* See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?

* If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.

* If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

* If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

* If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

* Unpaired t tests

* Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.

* It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.

* Paired t tests

* "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"

* So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 

* Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.

* It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.

* It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.

* T scores 

* The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.

* The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

* The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

3. Chi-Square Test

* The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

* It is a test of proportions and associations.

* A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.

* If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: 84. The results of a meta-analysis of various studies on the relationship between rabies infection and mortality rates are plotted as shown in the image below. What is this graphical representation known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a funnel plot, which is a means to assess the extent to which a systematic review is influenced by publication and other biases.

In general, there will be more variability in the results of smaller studies than larger studies, so, this plot should look like an inverted funnel. The larger study results cluster around the overall mean effect more closely than the results of the smaller studies. A funnel plot displays the effect size plotted against the sample size.

If the distribution of results of smaller studies is asymmetrical, it suggests that some smaller studies that showed unfavorable results may be missing from the analysis because of various biases. An asymmetrical funnel plot shows the apparent presence of publication bias. 

Other options :

Option B: Forest plots are commonly used to present the results of meta-analyses. It allows the results to be seen at a glance, with ready identification of outliers.

The following image shows a generic forest plot showing the odds ratios of various studies, their confidence intervals, and the summary measure arrived at through meta-analysis.



Option C: Scattergram is a graphical representation of the bivariate distribution relationship between two correlated variables. Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. This is expressed in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient and its direction is indicated by the sign. 

The image below shows a scattergram.



Option D: An ogive is a cumulative frequency polygon that forms a typical S-shaped curve.

The following image shows an example of an ogive.



Pearl PM1148: Funnel Plots

* A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.

* In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.

* The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.

* Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.

* This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.

* A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.

* These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.

* In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.



Pearl PM0932: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

* A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.

* The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.

* The following image shows a histogram.



2. Bar Chart

* It is also called a bar graph.

* It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.

* The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.

* Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.



3. Pie Charts

* Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.

* The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.



4. Frequency polygons

* Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.

* In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.



5. Ogive

* A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.



6. Line chart

* It is also called a line diagram or line graph.

* Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: 85. A patient has presented with a swelling in the abdomen for the past few months. On examination, a midline laparotomy scar is noted, and the diagnosis of incisional hernia with a 4 cm defect is made. He is clinically stable with normal labs and is planned for elective incisional hernia repair. The best plan of open surgical management is:
questions.solution:
The best plan of open surgical management for a patient planned for elective incisional hernia with a 4 cm defect is Retrorectus mesh placement.

The retrorectus mesh placement / Stoppa technique involves placing a large mesh in the retromuscular space via an incision in the posterior rectus sheath. The space is dissected laterally, and the posterior sheath is closed to create an extraperitoneal pocket. The mesh overlaps the defect by 5–6 cm and may be secured with or without sutures, depending on the defect size. This approach avoids visceral contact and shows good long-term outcomes with a recurrence rate of ~14% for large hernias. Mesh should be used in a tension-free manner to augment primary fascial closure and not just to bridge the gap, as bridging the defect with mesh alone can cause bulging and mimic recurrence. However, if there is adequate overlap, a bridging repair can still be secure. Mesh is usually avoided in a contaminated field, such as with bowel perforation or strangulation.

The following principles are applied for the repair of an incisional hernia:

* The repair should extend across the entire previous incision site.

* Musculofascial layers must be brought together with minimum tension.

* Using a prosthetic mesh is recommended to lower the chance of hernia recurrence

Incisional hernias result from poor healing or excessive tension at a previous surgical site, frequently worsened by factors like infection, obesity, or increased intra-abdominal pressure. These hernias tend to enlarge over time, potentially leading to complications such as pain, bowel obstruction, or strangulation. Large defects may cause loss of abdominal domain, where organs shift outside the cavity, compromising muscle function and respiratory mechanics. The image below represents an incisional hernia:



Other options :

Option A: Primary suture repair to avoid mesh is not recommended due to high recurrence rates. It may be used only when the defect size is < 2-3 cm or when the mesh is contraindicated, such as in cases of gross contamination.

Option B: Onlay mesh placement carries a risk of exposure and contamination, especially if wound infection or breakdown occurs. It also carries risks of infection, seroma, and skin ischemia due to flap elevation.

Option D: Intraperitoneal mesh placement is technically demanding, and its placement is difficult during open surgery. It is preferably performed using laparoscopic techniques rather than open surgery. Following this procedure, due to the direct contact of the mesh with abdominal organs, complications such as adhesions, erosion, or fistula formation may occur.

questions.text: 86. A patient was brought dead to the casualty. Fundoscopy exhibits the sign as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most accurate inference regarding the time of death?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows the Kevorkian sign. Hence, the most accurate time of death is less than 1 hour.

Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels and lasts for about 1 hour. This means that the patient had died within the preceding hour. 

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels and occurs due to loss of blood pressure. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized using an ophthalmoscope.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

* Cornea: Dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled.

* Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death.

* Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous:  Linear increase up to 100 hours following death.

* Tache noir: One of the post-mortem ocular signs. A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with the base towards the margin of the cornea and the apex towards the medial or lateral canthus of the eye which becomes brown and then black. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

questions.text: 87. An elderly diabetic man, on medication for the same, developed gross, painless hematuria. A diagnosis was made, and cystoprostatectomy was carried out. Chronic administration of which drug can lead to the condition shown in the specimen?
questions.solution:
Chronic administration of pioglitazone leads to urinary bladder cancer, as shown in the specimen.

Pioglitazone is an oral hypoglycemic agent that belongs to the drug class - thiazolidinediones, which also includes rosiglitazone. They bind to the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPAR-γ) nuclear receptor and decrease the levels of circulating insulin, thus reducing insulin resistance. In addition, they are also responsible for the redistribution of fat from the centre to the periphery.

Thiazolidinediones are known to cause weight gain, congestive heart failure, and peripheral edema. Further, they are known to worsen diabetic macular edema; therefore, they should be avoided in patients with advanced diabetic eye disease. Rosiglitazone, another thiazolidinedione, raises the levels of low-density lipoproteins (LDL) and triglycerides in the blood and can predispose to myocardial infarction. If taken for more than 1 year, patients taking pioglitazone are at an increased risk of urinary bladder cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Semaglutide, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, influences the blood sugar levels by insulin secretion following incretin stimulation, which is dependent on blood glucose. Moreover, they suppress glucagon and slow gastric emptying, thus aiding weight loss, but do not cause hypoglycemia. Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, and an increased incidence of medullary thyroid carcinoma or multiple endocrine neoplasia.

Option B: Dapagliflozin, an SGLT-2 inhibitor, acts by increasing the renal excretion of glucose by preventing the reabsorption of glucose and lowering the renal threshold for glucose excretion at the proximal convoluted tubule by inhibiting the sodium-glucose cotransporter. They cause weight loss, predispose the patient to urinary tract infections, and impair kidney function. Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis is another serious adverse effect.

Option D: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, which acts like an insulin secretagogue by acting on the ATP-sensitive K+ channels on the beta islet cells and stimulating the release of insulin. It is known to cause hypoglycemia, mainly in the elderly, and weight gain due to increased insulin release.

questions.text: 88. Which combinations of microorganisms are used for quality control in the Gram stain?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus (Gram-positive cocci) and Escherichia coli (Gram-negative bacilli) are used as quality control organisms for Gram staining.

The Gram stain is a differential staining technique that helps microbiologists distinguish between two main types of bacterial cell wall structures while visualising their shape and arrangement.

Gram Staining Steps:

* Fixation: Prepare and heat-fix a bacterial smear on a slide.

* Primary Stain: Flood with crystal violet for one minute, then rinse. All bacteria appear violet.

* Mordant: Apply Gram's iodine for one minute, then rinse to form dye-iodine complexes.

* Decolorization: Add acetone for a few seconds, then rinse. Acetone-alcohol or ethanol can also be used. Gram-negative bacteria will lose the stain, while Gram-positive bacteria will retain it.

* Counterstain: Apply safranin for 30 seconds. Gram-negative bacteria will turn pink or red.

Finally, rinse, dry, and examine the slide under a microscope.

Gram-positive bacteria resist decolorization and keep the violet stain, while gram-negative bacteria are decolorized, take on the pink counterstain, and appear pink, as shown below.

Used to stain pathological specimens Basic stains. | Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction. Neutral stains | Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain). Type of stain | Applications Gram stain: | To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red). Acid-fast stain: | Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia. Fluorochrome staining: | Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells. Capsule stain | Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli). Silver impregnation | Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire. Silver staining | Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes. questions.text:
89. A 56-year-old male patient was brought into the emergency room after he collapsed at his residence. Attendants inform that he complained of weakness, chest pain, difficulty in breathing before he collapsed. On examination, the following findings are observed. His ECG revealed inferior wall myocardial infarction and the patient was started on an inotrope. Identify the inotrope of choice and what are the predominant receptors that it acts on?

Blood pressure- 80/64 mmHg Pulse- 110 bpm, irregular Respiratory rate- 26/min Urine output- normal Ejection fraction- 34%
questions.solution:
The inotrope of choice is dobutamine and it acts predominantly by agonist action on beta 1 & beta 2 receptors.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute congestive heart failure with systolic dysfunction, reduced ejection fraction & maintained urine output. In cases of acute CHF with systolic dysfunction, dobutamine is the inotrope of choice. 

Beta 1 receptors act mainly on the myocardium increasing the force of contraction, thus having a positive inotropic effect. The vasoconstriction due to alpha 1 agonist action is partly negated by the vasodilation due to beta 2 agonist action. The net effect is that of increased stroke volume(inotropic) with a mild decrease in afterload (vasodilation by beta 2 agonism).

Dobutamine is an exogenic catecholamine. The major dose-reducing side effects of dobutamine include tachycardia and supraventricular arrhythmia. 

Concurrent use of beta-blockers may blunt the response of dobutamine, during the management of patients with acute CHF with systolic dysfunction. Thus a higher dose of dobutamine is given. Beyond 4 days, patients might develop tolerance and phosphodiesterase 3 (PDE3) inhibitors such as milrinone and enoximone may be added.

PDE3 inhibitors are more advantageous in patients on beta-blockers and with high systemic/pulmonary vascular resistance as compared to catecholamines such as dobutamine in the management of acute CHF with systolic dysfunction. PDE3 inhibitors or levosimendan may be preferred over catecholamines in patients already on beta-blockers at presentation.

Other options: 

Option A:  Dopamine in inotrope doses acts by agonist action on beta 2 receptors and is not antagonistic. Dopamine is used as the drug of choice in acute CHF with oliguria and has a dose-dependent action. 

* At <2mcg/kg/min as a diuretic due to agonist action on D2 receptors.

* At 2-5mcg/kg/min as an inotrope due to agonist action on beta 1. 

* At 5-10mcg/kg/min as a potent vasoconstrictor by alpha1 agonist action

Option C: Norepinephrine acts as a potent agonist at alpha 1 & beta 1 receptors, with weak agonism at beta 2 receptors. The positive inotropic effect is due to beta 1 receptors. Peripheral vasoconstriction and increased afterload are due to alpha 1 receptors. Alpha 1 agonist action promotes cardiac ischemia and resistance to cardiac output, hence it is not used as an inotrope. But, due to the same effect, it is used in vasogenic shock in spite of good cardiac output.

Option D:  Epinephrine acts as an agonist at alpha 1, beta 1 & beta 2 receptors. Although the net effect is similar to dobutamine, it is considered the second inotrope of choice in the management of Acute CHF due to the higher tachycardic effect.

90. A 3D CT of the hip for a patient who is a known case of small cell carcinoma of the lung, shows lytic lesions as given below, which involve 1/3rd but less than 2/3rd of the cortex. The patient also complains of pain in the lower limbs that increases with movement. What is the Mirels' score for this patient?

3D CT - 3 dimensional computed tomography
questions.solution:
The Mirels' score for this patient is 11.

Based on the clinical vignette, the score is calculated as follows :

* Site - peritrochanteric; score 3

* Pain - functional (aggravates on movement); score 3

* Lesion - Lytic; score 3

* Size - 1/3rd to 2/3rd of the cortex width; score 2

Mirels' score is used for predicting the risk of pathological fractures in patients with metastatic bone lesions. The score is given in the table below. Variable | Score 1 | 2 | 3 Site | Upper limb | Lower limb | Peritrochanteric Pain | Mild | Moderate | Functional Lesion | Blastic | Mixed | Lytic Size (w.r.t width of the cortex) | <1/3 | 1/3-2/3 | >2/3

A score of ≥9 is an indication for prophylactic fixation before radiotherapy. While a lesion with ≤7, is managed conservatively.

Prophylactic fixation is advocated before radiotherapy to ensure proper mobilization of the patient, prevent pathological fractures, and decrease morbidity. Intramedullary nails can be used to ensure strong fixation such that the patient can start early weight bearing and does not have to undergo a prolonged rehabilitation period.

Pearl PM0655: Pathological fracture

Pathological fractures occur with normal stresses in the bones that have been weakened by a change in its structure or through a lytic lesion.

Factors suggestive of a pathologic fracture:

* Fracture after minor trauma

* Pain at the site before the fracture

* Multiple recent fractures

* History of primary malignancy

Causes:

1. Generalized bone disease: 

* Osteoporosis

* Metabolic bone diseases

* Osteogenesis imperfecta

* Paget's disease

* Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia

* Myelomatosis

2. Local benign conditions:

* Chronic infection

* Solitary bone cyst

* Aneurysmal bone cyst

* Chondroma

3. Primary malignant tumors:

* Chondrosarcoma

* Osteosarcoma

* Ewing's tumor

4. Metastatic tumors

* Mets from breast, lung, kidney, thyroid, colon and prostate

questions.text: 91. A farmer enters a deep, unused well to retrieve a bucket and collapses within minutes. On rescue, he was taken to the hospital. He is cyanotic, no unusual odor is detected, and no discoloration of the blood. What is the mechanism of action of the gas most likely responsible?

choices.text: Simple displacement of oxygen from atmosphere

questions.solution:
Simple displacement of oxygen from the atmosphere is the mechanism of action of the gas responsible here, which is carbon dioxide.

The given scenario shows a farmer who enters a deep well and collapses within minutes due to asphyxia(cyanosis mentioned). The most probable reason for asphyxia in a deep well is due to carbon dioxide, which tends to accumulate at the bottom of enclosed or poorly ventilated spaces like old wells, damp cellars, and mines because it is heavier than air. Carbon dioxide is a heavy, colourless, odorless gas and is present in the concentration of 0.04-0.05% in the atmosphere.  

The mechanism by which it causes asphyxia is by displacing oxygen from the ambient air. The lack of oxygen reduces the partial pressure available for respiration, leading to asphyxia. Since the farmer is at the bottom of the well where the gas accumulates, he rapidly becomes hypoxic and collapses. The key step in management is to immediately remove the patient from the contaminated area and provide oxygen support.

Diagnosis is done by analysis of the air sample collected from the scene for CO2 content. It must be noted that blood CO2 levels are not clinically significant because CO2 is normally produced in the body and readily accumulates postmortem as well.

Asphyxiants may be classified as follows:

* Simple asphyxiants - They displace oxygen from the environment, lowering the amount available for breathing. Examples -  carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and helium.

* Respiratory irritants - They damage the respiratory tract by damaging the mucosal barrier. Examples - ammonia, chlorine, hydrogen sulfide, sulphur dioxide.

* Systemic asphyxiants - They cause asphyxia by systemic toxicity and interfere with oxygen transport or utilization. Examples- hydrogen cyanide, carbon monoxide, and smoke.

Other options:

Option A: Formation of carboxyhemoglobin is seen with carbon monoxide poisoning. It would be seen in cases like fire smoke and would lead to cherry-red discoloration of skin, lips. No discoloration was seen in this case.

Option B: Inhibition of cellular oxygen utilization - seen in cyanide poisoning. It has a bitter almond odour, and bright red discoloration is seen, which is not the case here.

Option C: Oxidation of hemoglobin to methemoglobin is seen in methemoglobinemia with agents like nitrites. There is cyanosis with chocolate-brown coloured blood.

questions.text: 92. Which of the following diseases does not follow the inheritance pattern shown in the pedigree chart given below?
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart represents autosomal dominant inheritance. This pattern is not seen in Von Gierke's disease.

Von Gierke disease is a glycogen storage disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. The characteristic clinical features include hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Autosomal dominant disorders are passed on to the offspring when at least one parent is affected. Both males and females can be affected and can transmit the disease. In this pattern, when one parent is affected, every child has a one in two chance of having the disease.

Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (Option A) is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is strongly associated with renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.

Von Recklinghausen disease (Option B) (neurofibromatosis-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder with variable penetrance. Some of the manifestations of this condition include neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and axillary freckling. It is also associated with Lisch nodules, pheochromocytomas, and pseudoarthrosis.

Von Willebrand disease (Option C) is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and presents with easy bruising, increased bleeding from wounds, and heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: 93. Which of the following parts of the brachial plexus is most likely to have been injured in the following condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a typical presentation of a policeman's tip or waiter's tip hand deformity seen in Erb’s palsy, which occurs in injuries to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus.

The Erb’s point in the brachial plexus is in the upper trunk, where the six nerves meet. The nerves are the C5 and C6 roots, suprascapular nerve, nerve to subclavius, and the anterior and posterior divisions of the upper trunk.

Given below is a diagram depicting the location of the Erb's point



The brachial plexus is anatomically divided into: roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and branches. (summarized in the pearl below)

The common causes of Erb's palsy are the undue separation of head and neck i.e. fall on shoulder and birth injuries. The resulting muscle weakness results in the depicted deformity which includes the following features:

* Arm is adducted and medially rotated at the shoulder joint

* Elbow joint is extended

* Radioulnar joint is pronated

* Sensory loss along the outer aspect of the arm

Given below is an image further showing the features of patients with Erb's palsy

questions.text: 94. An elderly male patient presents to the hospital with a history of swelling of the legs for the past few months. During the examination, it is noted that the patient has bilateral pitting type of pedal edema, elevated jugular venous pressure, and enlarged liver. Auscultation reveals the presence of a third heart sound. This sound occurs due to:

choices.text: Closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Vibrations of the ventricular wall during diastole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
Clinical features suggest heart failure, which is one of the pathological causes of the third heart sound, which is caused by vibrations of the ventricular wall during diastole.

A third heart sound is a weak rumbling sound heard at the beginning of the middle third of diastole. It is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope. It may be normally present in children, adolescents, and young adults. In older adults, it usually indicates systolic heart failure.

Important aspects of other heart sound

First heart sound is caused due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves. It is a high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of a stethoscope. The first heart sound due to mitral valve closure is best heard over the apex of the heart, and due to the closure of the tricuspid valve is best heard in the fourth intercostal space in the left sternal border.

The second heart sound is caused by the closure of the aortic (A2) and pulmonary valves (P2). It is a high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of a stethoscope. A2 is best heard in the right second intercostal space, and P2 is best heard in the left second intercostal space. 

Fourth heart sound is caused due to late ventricular filling through active atrial contraction. It is a low-pitched sound, heard best through the bell of the stethoscope. When it originates from the left ventricular, S4 is best heard at the apex with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. When it originates from the right ventricular, it is heard best at the left lower sternal border. It is seen in ventricular hypertrophy, ischemic heart disease, ventricular aneurysm, etc.

questions.text: 95. A primigravida had a vaginal delivery at 38 weeks of gestation at midnight and did not void till 6 am the next morning. What should be done next?

choices.text: MRI pelvis to rule out uterovesical fistula

questions.solution:
In the postpartum period, if a woman has not voided in the 4 hours after birth, clinical examination followed by intervention if necessary is important. The first step in such cases is to carry out a perineal examination for genital tract/perineal hematomas, which may be responsible for compression/obstruction of the urethra.

This is followed by insertion of a Foley’s catheter (Option C) if the bladder is palpated per abdomen. The catheter can be left in place for 24 hours before another voiding trial can be done. An ultrasound of the pelvis (Option B) may be carried out if clinical examination does not reveal significant findings and there is recurrent retention of urine after removal of the catheter. 

Other options:

Option D: An MRI pelvis to rule out uterovesical fistula is not needed, as there are no risk factors for the development of fistula. Moreover, in the case of a fistula, the patient will experience constant dripping of urine from the vagina, and the urinary bladder will not be distended.

questions.text: 96. A 32-year-old male from Bihar presents with a history of prolonged fever and significant weight loss over the past 6 months. On examination, he has massive splenomegaly. His blood investigation is suggestive of pancytopenia. What is the infective form of the organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis or kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the infective form of this organism is promastigote.

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing disease caused by the protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania and is transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomous sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. In human beings, the disease occurs in three different forms. They are:

* Visceral leishmaniasis 

* Cutaneous leishmaniasis

* Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

* Amastigote form (LD bodies): It is seen within macrophages, monocytes, neutrophils, or endothelial cells and contains a kinetoplast.

* Promastigote form: It is the infective form present in the sandfly.

Kinetoplasts are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to the nucleus. They consist of the blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates, such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirates. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

The image below shows amastigotes located intracellularly within macrophages.



The drug of choice for most of the endemic regions is the pentavalent antimonial compound. In Bihar, there is resistance to antimony, so amphotericin-B-deoxycholate or miltefosine is preferred.

Pearl PM1757: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell | Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host. Promastigote | Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane | It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro. Epimastigote | Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end. | It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania. Trypo-mastigote | This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end. | This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

Sexual gratification by inducing his wife to have sexual intercourse with another man and watching them
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c 1. Troilism | d. Sexual gratification by inducing his wife to have sexual intercourse with another man and watching them 2. Klismaphilia | a. Sexual arousal from enemas 3. Mysophilia | b. Sexual arousal with smelling, touching, or chewing of a soiled garment 4. Tribadism | c. Sexual gratification of a woman obtained by generalised body contact with another woman

Sexual perversions are persistent sexual behaviours or fantasies where a person seeks and finds complete sexual satisfaction through acts that do not involve sexual intercourse. These acts are generally considered socially forbidden or unacceptable. Some examples of sexual perversions are:

* Troilism is a sexual practice involving 3 people. It is an extreme degree of voyeurism wherein a perverted husband gets sexual satisfaction by inducing his wife to have sexual intercourse with another man and watching them.

* Klismaphilia

* Mysophilia

Tribadism: Female homosexuality is called tribadism or lesbianism. It is not an offence in India.

Pearl PM1869: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders: Disorder | Description Exhibitionistic disorder | Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger Pedophilic disorder | Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger Voyeuristic disorder | Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities Sexual sadism disorder | Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation Frotteuristic disorder | Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person Fetishistic disorder | Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female undergarments Transvestic disorder | Sexual arousal from cross-dressing Sexual masochism | Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

* Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)

questions.text:
98. A child was brought with some lesions over the chin, as shown below. Which of the following statements is true about the infection suspected in the child? * Bullous impetigo is caused by the exfoliative toxin of GAS * Impetiginization affects intact skin * Non-bullous impetigo is caused by S. aureus * Nikolsky sign is negative in bullous impetigo

GAS - Group A Streptococcus
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with lesions on the chin showing erythema and honey coloured crusting is suggestive of impetigo, for which statements 3 and 4 are correct

Impetigo is a cutaneous bacterial infection that exists in two clinical patterns - Bullous impetigo and Non-bullous impetigo. 

Bullous impetigo is generally seen in children and is caused by the exfoliative toxins of S. aureus strains (Statement 1), which cleave the desmoglein-1  in the epidermis, leading to the formation of clusters of thin-roofed bullae, vesicles, and pustules. When these bullae rupture, they form crusts and erythematous erosions. The superinfection of a preexisting lesion with S. aureus is called impetiginization, which usually does not affect intact skin (Statement 2). 

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by Staphylococcus aureus (most common) or Group A streptococcus (GAS) or both (Statement 3). It begins as erythematous papules, which become vesicles and pustules that rupture and lead to honey coloured crusted papules with an erythematous base. S. aureus is seen in the nares in carriers, and non-bullous impetigo is seen as a temporary papule or pustule around the nares with itching and soreness.

A positive Nikolsky sign refers to the sheet-like separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis on application of firm tangential shearing pressure, thereby producing erosion. It is seen in conditions that produce intraepidermal blisters. However, it is negative in bullous impetigo (Statement 4) because of a lack of acantholysis and a tough bulla.



Pearl PM2455: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:



b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:



c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:



d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:



e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:



Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

The given image shows impetigo:

Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:



d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

questions.text: 99. A 35-year-old male came to the casualty with a history of intake of antipsychotics for 4 days. He presents with grimacing, abnormal posturing, and increased tone in the muscles with a flexed neck. Which of the following is the best drug in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed acute muscular dystonia. Benztropine can be used for the management of acute dystonia.

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics that occurs within 1-5 days of intake. It is characterized by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back.

Pearl PM0479: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text:
100. Which of the following components of pancreatic juice are secreted by the epithelium of ducts and ductules of the gland?
* Secretin
* Water
* Bicarbonate
* Enterokinase
* Chymotrypsin
questions.solution:
The epithelium of the ducts and ductules of the exocrine pancreas secretes water and bicarbonate.

The exocrine pancreas secretes pancreatic juice, which contains digestive enzymes and a bicarbonate-rich, alkaline fluid. Additionally, it contains electrolytes such as Na⁺, K⁺, Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺, Cl⁻, SO₄²⁻, and HPO₄²⁻. The acinar cells of the pancreas produce the following enzymes:

Protein Digestion:

* Trypsin cleaves peptide bonds on the carboxyl side of basic amino acids

* Chymotrypsin (Option 5), activated by trypsin, acts on aromatic amino acids

* Elastase targets aliphatic amino acids

* Carboxypeptidase A removes C-terminal aromatic/branched aliphatic amino acids

* Carboxypeptidase B removes the C-terminal basic amino acids

Lipid Digestion:

* Lipase converts triglycerides to monoglycerides and fatty acids.

* Colipase anchors lipase to fat droplets in the presence of bile salts

* Phospholipase A₂ converts phospholipids to fatty acids and lysophospholipids

* Cholesterol esterase converts cholesteryl esters to cholesterol and fatty acids

Carbohydrate Digestion: α-Amylase cleaves starch at α-1,4 glycosidic bonds

Nucleic Acid Digestion:

* Ribonuclease cleaves RNA into nucleotides

* Deoxyribonuclease cleaves DNA into nucleotides

In contrast, the ductal and ductular epithelial cells secrete water and bicarbonate. These components serve to neutralize the acidic chyme entering the duodenum from the stomach, providing an optimal pH for enzyme activity.

Secretin (option 1) is not a component of pancreatic juice; it is a hormone secreted by S cells in the duodenal mucosa in response to acidic gastric contents. It stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate-rich fluid but is not itself secreted by the pancreas.

Enterokinase (option 4) is an enzyme secreted by the intestinal mucosa, not by the pancreas. It activates trypsinogen to trypsin in the small intestine.

questions.text:
101. An alleged female convict is arrested for a crime she did not commit. She was tortured by the investigating officer and was raped by him in police custody. Under which section will the inquest be done in this scenario?

IPC - Indian Penal Code CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code BNS - Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita BNSS - Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of custodial rape. A magistrate inquest is done under BNSS Section 196 (Section 176 CrPC).

Custodial rape is defined as the offence committed by persons who are in supervisory positions indulging in sexual intercourse with women in their custody by inducing or seducing the woman by taking advantage of his official position.

BNSS 196 (Section 176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

* Custodial rape

* Death in police custody or police interrogation

* Death in police firing

* Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school

* Death in a psychiatric hospital

* Dowry death

* Cases of exhumation.

Other options:

Option A: BNS Section 63 (Section 375 IPC)deals with the definition of rape. In BNS 63, the Age of Consent of 15 years is replaced by 18 years in BNS. Exception 2 of Section 63 states that “sexual intercourse or acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under 18 years of age, is not rape”.

Option B: BNS Section 68 (Section 376 IPC) deals with the punishment of rape by a person in authority. It is termed custodial rape.

Option D: BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence.

questions.text:
102. An elderly male with progressive loss of vision is diagnosed with wet ARMD due to choroidal neovascularization and is scheduled for photodynamic therapy. Which of the following agents is used in this therapy?

ARMD - Age related macular degeneration
questions.solution:
Verteporfin is used for photodynamic therapy in wet ARMD.

Age-related macular degeneration(ARMD) is a degenerative disease of the macula, leading to central vision loss in the elderly. It is of two types: dry and wet. Dry ARMD (most common) is characterised by retinal pigment epithelium atrophy, while wet ARMD is characterised by choroidal neovascularisation. These vessels are fragile, leak fluid and blood, leading to scars.

Verteporfin is a photosensitising agent used in photodynamic therapy for subfoveal choroidal neovascularization, commonly seen in wet ARMD. After intravenous administration, verteporfin localises in the abnormal neovascular tissue. When activated by a non-thermal laser, it generates reactive oxygen species. This causes selective thrombosis and closure of abnormal choroidal vessels. It can also cause photosensitivity reactions. Hence, bright light/ sunlight must be avoided for a few days after therapy. All of the given drugs can be used for the treatment of wet-ARMD, but only verteporfin is used in photodynamic therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Ranibizumab is a monoclonal antibody fragment that targets VEGF-A, thereby inhibiting vascular proliferation. It is used as an intravitreal injection for diabetic macular edema and wet-ARMD.

Option C: Bevacizumab is also a monoclonal antibody targeting VEGF-A. It was the first anti-VEGF commercially available, used for diabetic macular edema and wet-ARMD, but it was less effective than ranibizumab.

Option D: Pegabtanib specifically binds to VEGF-165 and inhibits it. VEGF-165 induces angiogenesis and is responsible for the progression of ARMD.

questions.text: 103. An 18-month-old baby girl is being investigated for recurrent episodes of dermatitis. She develops blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight. Parents report pinkish discoloration of the child's diapers. Characteristic "monkey-like" facies, delayed eruption and reddish discoloration of teeth are noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an 18-month-old baby with characteristic monkey-like facies, blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight, reddish discolouration of teeth, erythrodontia, and pink stain in diapers are seen in congenital erythropoietic porphyria. 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma urine, and faeces.

Portwine urine or pink stain in diapers is seen. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia (as shown in the image below).



Other options:

Option B: Porphyria cutanea tarda also presents as blistering photosensitivity but typically manifests in adults. Moreover, erythrodontia is not seen. It is the most common type of porphyria, which is caused by a deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.

Option C: Erythropoietic protoporphyria presents as non-blistering photosensitivity, unlike in this case.

Option D: Acute intermittent porphyria presents with neurovisceral symptoms after puberty. It presents with abdominal pain and psychosis with no cutaneous features. It may be precipitated by drugs, decreased carbohydrate intake, and infections.

Pearl PM0844: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

* Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.

* Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: 104. Identify the type of joint marked in the given image
questions.solution:
The joint shown is the median atlantoaxial joint, a classic example of a pivot joint that has uniaxial movement, allowing rotation of the head from side to side, such as when indicating "no".

The median atlantoaxial joint is formed between the dens (odontoid process) of the axis (C2) and the anterior arch of the atlas (C1). The dens acts as a vertical pivot around which the atlas and the skull rotate. A ligamentous ring (transverse ligament of the atlas) holds the dens in place, forming the osteoligamentous ring characteristic of pivot joints.

A pivot joint is a uniaxial synovial joint that allows for rotation around the axis of an osseous pivot contained within an osteoligamentous ring. Pivots allow rotational movement in two ways: the pivot can rotate within a ring, like the head of the radius in the annular ligament, or the ring can rotate around a pivot, as seen with the atlas rotating around the dens of the axis.

Other options:

Option A: Pivot joints allow only uniaxial (rotational) movement.

Option C and D: Bicondylar joints (e.g., knee) allow predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation, not at the atlantoaxial joint.

105. A 4-year-old girl with grade Ⅲ bilateral vesicoureteric reflux is on antibiotic prophylaxis. She has no other ureteric anomalies. She develops two episodes of febrile UTI despite compliance. DMSA shows new cortical scars. What is the next best step?

DMSA - Dimercaptosuccinic acid
questions.solution:
Ureteric reimplantation is the next best step of treatment.

The child has grade Ⅲ bilateral vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and was on antibiotic prophylaxis, but still developed two episodes of urinary tract infections. This is called breakthrough UTI. Breakthrough febrile UTIs are an indication for surgical repair of VUR.

Vesicoureteric reflux is a condition where there is retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureter and kidney. Normally, the ureter is attached obliquely between the bladder mucosa and the detrusor muscle, forming a valve-like mechanism.

VUR can be primary or secondary. Primary VUR is usually an autosomal dominant trait and occurs due to congenital incompetence of the valvular mechanism. Secondary VUR is associated with other anomalies of the urinary tract.

The following image shows the grades of VUR:



The following image shows the management of vesicouretric reflux:



Indications for surgical repair of VUR are - breakthrough febrile UTI, or if there is deterioration of renal function due to parenchymal injury/scarring.

Other options:

Option A: Voiding behaviour modifications and observations are acceptable in low-grade VUR.

Option B: Here, the child has a febrile breakthrough UTI, which indicates prophylaxis failure. Just changing the drug will not prevent reflux or damage.

Option D: Nephrectomy is indicated only in a non-functioning kidney with severe scarring.

questions.text: 106. Which molecular principle forms the basis of the FELUDA test for COVID-19 detection?
questions.solution:
Feluda (FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay) is a CRISPR-Cas9-based detection method.

The Feluda test was developed by CSIR-IGIB (Council of Scientific and Industrial Research), India. In this test, detection is done on a lateral flow strip. It is a rapid test, making it useful for point-of-care COVID-19 testing. It is a very affordable, sensitive, and specific strip test that can detect viral genetic material within 45 minutes.



CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9) is a form of acquired or adaptive immunity found in many bacteria. It helps to prevent reinfection of bacteria by a bacteriophage. It uses an RNA-based targeting to bind to any complementary DNA and then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA. This system has been adapted for use in human cells as well, where it can be used for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and modulation of gene transcription.

Other options:

Option B: ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) uses antibodies that are linked to a reporter enzyme like alkaline phosphatase. They can be used to detect antigens that produce fluorescence after binding. ELISA is used to detect antibodies against the spike antigen in COVID-19.

Option C: Real-time PCR is the gold standard for COVID-19 detection. It works by amplifying and detecting viral RNA using fluorescent probes.

Option D: A DNA microarray can be used to detect DNA sequence variations.

questions.text: 107. A 28-year-old woman comes to the primary health center to avail of a contraceptive provided under a new government program. She does not want to take daily pills. She was started on the contraceptive shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs is used in this?
questions.solution:
Injectable contraceptive medroxyprogesterone acetate (MPA) is introduced under the Antara program.

The dosage is 150 mg I.M every 3 months. This injectable contraceptive is not to be refrigerated. It is to be stored always at room temperature (15-30 degree centigrade).

Mechanism of action:

* Inhibition of ovulation

* Cervical mucus thickening and thereby preventing sperm penetration

* Endometrial atrophy preventing implantation.

The first dose can be taken: 

* Anytime after regular menstruation, or 

* After 6 weeks of delivery, or 

* Immediately after abortion

This injectable contraceptive should not be given to a woman with:

* Unexplained vaginal bleeding 

* Stroke or severe diabetes

* Breast cancer (past/present)

* Active hepatitis or liver tumor

* A desire for rapid return to fertility

Disadvantages

* Menstrual irregularities: Light / heavy bleeding or amenorrhoea

* Slight weight gain

* No protection against HIV/STDs 

* A slight loss in BMD during the first 2 years of use

Note:

Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were recently launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas.





Pearl PM2328: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

* Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)

* Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate

* Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)

* Norgestrel 75 μg

* Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone

* Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia

* Post-coital pills or interceptive

* Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart

* Mifepristone 10-600 mg

* Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse

* Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse

* GnRH agonists  

* CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

* Progesterone only injectables

* DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months

* NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months

* Combined injectables

* Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg

* Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

* Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg

* Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

* Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day

* Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week

* Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text:
108. A 65-year-old man presented with flank pain, a mass in the right lumbar region, and hematuria. On evaluation, advanced renal carcinoma was diagnosed. Which mTOR inhibitor has been approved for use in such cases?

mTOR - Mammalian target of Rapamycin
questions.solution:
Temsirolimus is a drug used in advanced/ metastatic renal cancers with a poor prognosis. It is an mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) inhibitor that acts by getting converted to sirolimus, which binds to FKBP-12 and inhibits mTOR. This, in turn, inhibits the progression of the cell cycle. 

Temsirolimus has been approved for use in metastatic renal cancer. Trials are underway to test its efficacy in the treatment of solid organ tumours (like non-small cell lung carcinoma), mantle cell lymphoma, and cervical carcinoma, in conjunction with other immunosuppressants.

Side effects include anaemia, thrombocytopenia, anorexia/weight loss, diarrhoea, dyspnea, non-specific pneumonitis, hypercholesterolaemia, hyperglycemia, skin rashes, stomatitis, and aphthous ulcer. 

Other options: 

Option A: Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor used prophylactically to prevent solid organ graft rejection, similar to cyclosporine.

Option C: Sirolimus is used in combination with glucocorticoids and cyclosporine for the prophylaxis of organ transplant rejection. It has also been incorporated into stents to inhibit local cell proliferation and blood vessel occlusion.

Option D: Pimecrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor, approved for the treatment of atopic dermatitis in patients 2 years and older.

questions.text: 109. A 40-year-old man with hyperthyroidism receives radioactive I-131 therapy. Two years later, he develops thyroid carcinoma. He sues the treating physician for medical negligence. Which of the following best describes this situation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a therapeutic misadventure.

A therapeutic misadventure refers to an unintentional adverse outcome that occurs during the proper administration of a medically indicated therapy, without any negligence on the part of the treating physician. In the given scenario, the treating physician prescribes radioactive iodine therapy to treat hyperthyroidism. I-131 therapy is an accepted treatment. Rarely, it can induce thyroid carcinoma, which is considered an unintentional adverse effect, and is considered a therapeutic misadventure.

Therapeutic misadventure is of three types: 

* Therapeutic - when the treatment is being given

* Diagnostic - where diagnosis only is the objective at the time

* Experimental - where the patient has agreed to serve as a subject in an experimental study.

Examples of therapeutic misadventure include:

* Hypersensitivity reaction, sometimes fatal, may be caused by penicillin or aspirin.

* Excessive administration of an antidote to a poisoned patient may cause death. 

* Prolonged use of stilboesterol may cause breast cancer. 

* I-131 therapy may cause thyroid cancer.

Other options:

Option A: This situation is not considered medical negligence because the physician did recommend a standard, accepted treatment modality, and the resulting carcinoma was an unintentional adverse effect.

Option C: Novus actus interveniens is a new, independent event that breaks the chain of causation. For example, if the patient was discharged safely, but later got injured by an unrelated accident.

Option D: In the given case, the patient has shown no contributory negligence.

Pearl PM2391: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

* Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.

* Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions

* Refuses to take the treatment

* Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice

* Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

* Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

* Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

* Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.

* Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

* Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: 110. During your visit to the CHC, you notice the ANM takes one frozen vial of a vaccine, as control, and another vial of the same vaccine. She shakes both the vials and is trying to compare the rate of sedimentation of solutes in both vials. For which of the below-mentioned vaccines would you not be performing this test?
questions.solution:
The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by the Shake test. It is used for all freeze-sensitive vaccines - all the 'T-series' vaccines. The shake test is not used for the MMR vaccine.

The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by Shake test.

* A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.

* Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.

* If the rate of sedimentation in test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

* Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. Examples: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Liquid Haemophilus influenza type b (Hib), Hepatitis B.

Measles vaccine:

2. Schwartz strain.

*

*

*

*

Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

*

*

*

*

*
