questions.text:
111. As a forensic expert, you are asked to examine a fingerprint impression found at a crime scene. On examination, you notice that only fragments of the fingerprint are available, with no precise
pattern. Which of the following techniques can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, poroscopy technique can be used in cases where only fragments of the fingerprint are available with no specific pattern.

Poroscopy was discovered by Edmond Locard in 1912. It is a method of personal identification through the comparison of the impressions of sweat pores (present on friction ridges of palmar and plantar surfaces). These microscopic pores are formed by the ducts of subepidermal sweat glands.

1 mm of ridge contains up to 9-18 pores. These pores are permanent and unchanged throughout life. They differ in size, form, distribution, and arrangement along a particular length of ridge in each individual.



Other options:

Option A: Ridgeology is the evaluation of friction ridges on fingerprints.

Option C: Edgeoscopy is the study of edges of friction ridges on fingerprints.

Option D: Podography is the evaluation of footprints. Toe and heel skin patterns are just as unique and permanent as finger patterns.

questions.text: 112. While the genetic code has 64 codons, there are only 20 naturally occurring amino acids. Most amino acids are encoded by more than one codon. This feature of genetic code is said to be:
questions.solution:
The genetic code is degenerate because most amino acids are encoded by more than one codon.  

Other features of the genetic code are:

* Unambiguous: Each codon specifies only one amino acid. 

* Non-punctuated: There is no punctuation between codons, and the message is read in a continuing sequence of nucleotide triplets until a translation stop codon is reached.

* Non-overlapping: The reading of the genetic code during the process of protein synthesis does not involve any overlap of codons. Read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases

* Universal: Genetic code is conserved throughout evolution.  

Exceptions: Methionine and tryptophan are encoded by only one codon (AUG and UGG, respectively)

questions.text: 113. A 55-year-old female was posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anaesthesia. THRIVE was employed in place of tidal volume preoxygenation. What does THRIVE stand for?
questions.solution:
Transnasal humidified rapid-insufflation ventilatory exchange (THRIVE) is a method of preoxygenation used in difficult airways and spontaneous ventilation. 

High-flow oxygen is an important feature of THRIVE. When used at 100% O2 at 60L/min for 3 minutes, its effects are the same as those of preoxygenation with tidal volume using a face mask.  

THRIVE has been useful in regulating ventilation in a non-invasive manner using a nasal cannula before securing a definitive airway. The high flow oxygen supplied by the nasal cannula creates a turbulent vortex in the supraglottis by circling the soft palate and exiting via the mouth. This reduces the work of breathing through warming and humidification. In addition, it also prevents airway collapsibility and atelectasis.

This vortex, along with cardiogenic oscillations, formed by the compression and expansion of small airways due to the movement of blood in and out of the thoracic cavity, results in the movement of a small volume of gases within the trachea. THRIVE replaces this volume with 100% O2, thus aiding efficient gas exchange. Further, since it provides continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and continuously flushes the dead space, it delays apnea.

The other methods of preoxygenation are deep breathing, rapid breathing at FiO2, and the four vital capacities method, used when patient cooperation is compromised.

Pearl PM0412: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

* Obstructive sleep apnea

* History of snoring

* Obesity

* Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery

* Previous head and neck radiation

* Head and neck trauma

* Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck

* Rheumatoid arthritis

* Down syndrome

* Scleroderma

* Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

* Mallampati scores (III and IV)

* Thyromental distance less than 6 cm

* Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension

* Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women

* Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth

* Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: 114. A 20-year-old male has a 4-day history of fever, severe throat pain, and trismus. Intraoral examination shows medial tonsil displacement and external examination reveals lateral neck swelling. How should the airway be secured for planned drainage under general anesthesia?

choices.text: Oral endotracheal intubation under general anesthesia
Nasotracheal intubation using a fibreoptic scope

questions.solution:
Elective tracheostomy before abscess drainage is required to secure the airway in this patient with throat pain, trismus (difficulty opening the mouth), and fever, along with the tonsil being pushed medially and a lateral neck swelling, which is suggestive of a parapharyngeal abscess.

Given the diagnosis of a parapharyngeal abscess, establishing a secure airway is not just recommended but mandatory. The primary concern is the imminent risk of airway obstruction, a potentially life-threatening complication. The swelling associated with the abscess can rapidly compromise the pharyngeal and laryngeal spaces. During the procedure, there is a significant danger of pus aspiration into the lungs, which can lead to severe pneumonia or even acute respiratory distress syndrome. Additionally, the manipulation of tissues during drainage can exacerbate swelling, leading to a sudden and complete airway collapse.

Tracheostomy provides a definitive and secure airway below the level of the obstruction and swelling, effectively bypassing the compromised upper airway. This ensures continuous ventilation and oxygenation throughout the drainage procedure and during the immediate post-operative period, allowing for controlled management of the infection and inflammation.

Other options

Option A: Oral intubation is generally difficult and dangerous. The trismus physically restricts mouth opening, making laryngoscopy and intubation challenging. Limited neck extension, laryngopharyngeal edema and mass effect from the abscess further make intubation difficult.

Option B: Fibreoptic nasotracheal intubation, while a valuable tool in difficult airway situations, is risky in the presence of acute swelling. The passage of the endoscope and tube through an already inflamed and compromised nasal and pharyngeal pathway could traumatise tissues, induce more swelling, or even lead to rupture of the abscess. 

Option C: Cricothyrotomy is an emergency procedure, specifically reserved for scenarios where all other attempts at securing the airway have failed. It is a rapid, life-saving intervention, but is not intended for elective, controlled airway management in a stable patient where the impending airway compromise can be anticipated and proactively addressed with a planned procedure like a tracheostomy. In this case, an elective tracheostomy allows for a more controlled and less emergent approach to airway security.

Pearl PM1405: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space

| Prestyloid | Poststyloid Relation to styloid | Anterior | Posterior Relations | Medially: Tonsillar fossa

Laterally: Medial pterygoid muscle | Medially: Posterior part of the lateral pharyngeal wall

Laterally: Parotid gland Contents | Medial pterygoid muscle | Carotid artery

Jugular vein, IXth, Xth, XIth, XIIth cranial nerves

Sympathetic trunk Presentation | Prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa,

Spasm of medial pterygoid muscle leading to trismus | The pharynx bulging behind the posterior pillar

Injury to of CN IX, X, XI, and XII leading to vocal cord paralysis

Sympathetic chain injury leading to Horner’s syndrome

Swelling of the parotid region

Pearl PM2397: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

* Parotid gland

* Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

* Common carotid artery

* Internal carotid artery

* Internal jugular vein

* Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text: 115. A 70-year-old woman presented to the OPD with complaints of green, foul-smelling discharge. A speculum exam shows a growth over the cervix, which, after biopsy, is diagnosed to be an epidermoid carcinoma. Where are the cells seen on histopathology primarily found?
questions.solution:
Epidermoid carcinoma arises from the squamous cells, which are primarily represented by 4.

The image below shows the various parts of the cervix seen on the speculum examination.



Cervical carcinoma has 2 pathological types :

* Epidermoid carcinoma, which is more common and arises from the squamous epithelium

* Endocervical carcinoma arising from the endocervical canal 

On histopathology, squamous cell carcinoma is most commonly seen. Whereas the most common site of cervical carcinoma is the transformation zone, which contains both the squamous and columnar epithelial cells. Clinical features include postcoital bleeding, foul-smelling discharge, and leucorrhoea. A growth or an ulcer is seen on per speculum examination, which bleeds on touch. Locally advanced carcinoma may present with pyometra and a bulky uterus due to cervical block. Clinical examination is essentially used to stage the carcinoma; however, MRI is used to detect involvement of the parametrium and regional lymph nodes.

Pearl PM1357: Standard staging procedure of Ca Cervix by FIGO guidelines

Physical examination

* Speculum, bimanual, and rectovaginal examination- For pelvic examination (primary tumor, uterus, vagina, and parametria)

* Palpation of groin and supraclavicular lymph nodes, examination of the right upper quadra- For distant metastases.

Cervical biopsy

* Colposcopy with directed cervical biopsy or cervical biopsy without colposcopy

* Endocervical curettage

* Conization

Endoscopy

* Hysteroscopy

* Cystoscopy

* Proctoscopy

Imaging studies

* Intravenous pyelogram/CT/MR – Evaluation for urinary tract obstruction

* Plain/skeletal radiograph – Evaluation for metastases.

If readily available and accessible

* CT / PETCT – For assessing pelvic and paraaortic lymph node involvement.

* MRI - To assess tumor size and local extent of disease.

* Ultrasound – This may also be used to assess tumor size and local extent of disease.

Image-guided biopsy - If imaging shows sites suspicious for metastatic disease.

questions.text: 116. A thin, elderly woman with postural scoliosis is diagnosed with ‘Lady Windermere’ syndrome. Which organism is most commonly implicated in such patients?
questions.solution:
The most common organism implicated in ‘Lady Windermere’ syndrome is Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC). 

Lady Windermere syndrome is seen mostly in elderly, thin women with a chest wall abnormality such as scoliosis and pectus excavatum. The pathophysiology primarily involves the right middle lobe of the lung, resulting from the suppression of the cough reflex out of politeness, which leads to the accumulation of sputum in the respiratory tract. Bronchiectasis is commonly seen on imaging, and patients generally present with fatigue and cough with sputum. 

Treatment modalities include a combination therapy which includes macrolides, rifampicin, and ethambutol, with the addition of an aminoglycoside in severe cases.

Other options:

Option A: M. tuberculosis is known to cause tuberculosis, which can be limited to the lungs or affect other organs.

Option B: M. marinum is implicated in the causation of swimming pool or fish tank granuloma, which are ulcers or papules seen following minor trauma.

Option D: M. ulcerans is seen in the tropics and causes painless ulcers, known as buruli ulcer.

Pearl PM2361: Runyon classification of Non-tubercululous Mycobacteria

2. M. marinum | 1. Similar to TB

2. Swimming pool granuloma II

Scoto-chromogens | Yellow or orange in light or dark | M. scrofulaceum

M. gordonae | Cervical adenitis III

Non photo-chromogens | No pigment | M. avium intracellulare complex (MAC),

M. ulcerans,

M. xenopi | Similar to TB, esp. in AIDS IV

Rapid growers | No pigment | M. fortuitum

questions.text: 117. A 30-year-old male underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy following cholecystitis. During the procedure, the bile duct was injured. The surgeon classified the injury as Strasberg type D. Which of the following represents the injury seen in this patient?

choices.text: Injury to the main hepatic duct
Bile leak from main bile duct without major tissue loss.
Bile leak from the divided right posterior sectoral duct.

questions.solution:
Strasberg’s type D injury involves bile leak from the main bile duct without major tissue loss.

Biliary injury may occur post-laparoscopic cholecystectomy ranging from asymptomatic leak which resolves on its own to complete obstruction of extrahepatic biliary tree within 24 hrs.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to define these injuries by anatomical location. Classification is as follows:



Management - 

Type A - Stent placement and the stent can be removed endoscopically if the patient is asymptomatic and lab results are normal at 2 weeks. Type B - Hepaticojejunostomy and segmental resection of the affected lobes Type C and D - If there is no leak, remove the stent endoscopically and repeat ERCP.  If there is a minor leak, sphincterotomy to facilitate bile flow into the duodenum or stent replacement for a further 4 weeks  Type E - Such cases, if noted during the surgery, should have surgical repair by T-tube drainage or a hepaticojejunostomy.

questions.text: 118. A middle-aged man comes to casualty with altered mental status and confusion. He appears lethargic and complains of nausea and thirst. He is known to have small cell lung cancer but is not under treatment. Which metabolic abnormality will cause these features in this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient who is a known case of small cell lung cancer presenting with clinical features such as lethargy, confusion, altered mental status, and thirst is suggestive of SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone). Hyponatremia is the metabolic abnormality causing these clinical features in the patient. 

SIADH can be associated with several different tumors such as that of the lung, ovaries, pancreas, bladder, etc. In this condition, ectopic vasopressin is produced by the small cell lung cancer which is a neuroendocrine tumor. Ectopic vasopressin increases the anti-diuretic property of the kidney decreasing renal clearance and leading to SIADH. This causes increased free water retention, leading to hyponatremia. Initially, in response to SIADH, there is a decrease in thirst which prevents further progression of the hyponatremia. However, later with increased ectopic vasopressin secretion the osmostat controlling thirst and hypothalamic secretion of vasopressin gets altered causing more thirst in the patient. This mechanism worsens hyponatremia.

SIADH is a syndrome characterized by euvolemic hyponatremia due to a primary defect in osmoregulation. The causes of SIADH include neoplasms of the lung, duodenum, pancreas, ovary, head trauma, infections (tuberculosis, meningitis, pneumonia), and drug overdose (vasopressin, desmopressin).

Treatment involves administration of conivaptan or tolvaptan (vasopressin receptor V2 antagonist), demeclocycline, and fluid restriction to less than 500 ml (although this can be difficult). In severe cases, correction of hyponatremia is done by administering IV fluids with hypertonic normal saline along with diuretics such as furosemide (to increase free water clearance).

questions.text:
119. You received three patients in the ENT OPD. Identify which semicircular canal of the inner ear will be involved in each of these patients.
* A patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo
* A patient with nystagmus who will be subjected to the caloric test
* A patient with a dehiscence in a canal that forms an arcuate eminence in the base of the skull
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B-1-a, 2-b, 3-c

* A patient with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo- Posterior semicircular canal (1) is involved.

* A patient with nystagmus who is subjected to caloric test- Horizontal/ lateral semicircular canal (2) is stimulated.

* A patient with dehiscence in this canal which forms arcuate eminence in the base of the skull- Superior/ anterior semicircular canal (3) is involved. 

Benign positional paroxysmal vertigo is typically thought to be caused by the dislodgement of calcium carbonate from the otoconial membrane within one of the canals. The posterior canal is most commonly affected in benign positional paroxysmal vertigo, and lateral canal pathology causes a few cases. The classical presentation of BPPV is recurrent, brief (<1 minute) episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position. Diagnosis is made by the Dix-hallpike maneuver. The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which displaces the otolith out of the posterior canal. This ends the sensation of vertigo with positional changes relieving the symptoms. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

Fitzgerald–Hallpike test/ bithermal caloric test procedure:

In this test, the patient lies supine with head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical, which will be stimulated here.

* Ears are irrigated for 40 seconds alternatively with water at 30°C and at 44°C (i.e., 7° below and above normal body temperature) and eyes are observed for the appearance of nystagmus till its endpoint.

* Time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of nystagmus is recorded and charted on a calorigram.

* If no nystagmus is elicited from any ear, the test is repeated with water at 20°C for 4 min before labeling the labyrinth dead.

* A gap of 5 min should be allowed between two ears.

Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome occurs due to the third window effect created by the thin/ dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. It is usually diagnosed in middle-aged individuals, and no racial or sexual predominance is seen. Patients present with noise or pressure-induced dizziness. Some may complain of chronic imbalance. As a result, the patient adopts avoidance of noisy environments. Also, some may have gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis.

questions.text: 120. A patient was posted for resection of a deep tissue lipoma in the right hand. The technique of anaesthesia given in the figure was used. Which of the following is not used as an adjuvant to reduce pain in the said technique?
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is Intravenous Regional Anaesthesia (IVRA or Bier’s block). Opioids like morphine are ineffective for pain relief in this procedure, so they are not used.

IVRA is a method of regional anaesthesia used for short surgeries (<90 minutes). A local anaesthetic is injected intravenously into a tourniquet-bound arm to provide anaesthesia in the region distal to the tourniquet. The frequently used drugs are lidocaine and prilocaine. For upper limb procedures, 3mg/kg lidocaine without epinephrine and preservatives is used, while for lower limb procedures, 50-100 ml of 0.25% lidocaine is given.

Though IVRA has a good safety profile, seizures and cardiovascular collapse have been noted even with low doses of lidocaine. Bupivacaine is contraindicated due to its cardiotoxic potential. Opioids such as morphine are ineffective for pain relief and, therefore, are not used in this procedure. Moreover, they can cause dizziness, nausea, and vomiting following tourniquet deflation.

Other options:

Option A: Lornoxicam is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is known to decrease postoperative and tourniquet pain; thus, it is beneficial in Bier’s block.

Option B: Dexamethasone, a corticosteroid drug, has dual benefits. It improves the quality of the block and also provides postoperative analgesia.

Option D: Dexmedetomidine is an ɑ2 adrenergic agonist that has actions similar to dexamethasone, i.e., improved block quality and postoperative analgesia.

questions.text: 121. A young female presents with fever, confusion, seizures, anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal impairment. The coagulation profile is normal. This condition most commonly results from a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of TTP (Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura), and it results from a deficiency of ADAMTS13 metalloprotease.  

This young woman presents with the classical pentad of TTP, which includes 

* Fever

* Neurological manifestations such as confusion and seizures 

* MAHA (Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia) with schistocytes on peripheral smear 

* Thrombocytopenia 

* Renal impairment 

The key diagnostic clue is the presence of fragmented red cells (schistocytes) along with thrombocytopenia in the setting of a normal coagulation profile. A normal PT and aPTT essentially exclude DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation), in which coagulation parameters are always abnormal.

TTP is a severe deficiency of ADAMTS13, the metalloprotease responsible for cleaving large multimers of von Willebrand factor, in its absence. Ultra-large vWF multimers persist in the circulation, promoting widespread platelet aggregation and the formation of hyaline thrombi in small vessels. These platelet-rich microthrombi cause mechanical destruction of red cells as they pass through, resulting in MAHA and schistocytes, while also occluding arterioles and capillaries, leading to ischemia in the brain, kidneys, and other organs.ADAMTS13 activity levels of <10% are diagnostic of TTP.

The treatment of choice in this life-threatening condition is therapeutic plasma exchange (plasmapheresis), which simultaneously removes the inhibitory autoantibodies directed against ADAMTS13 and replenishes the deficient protease. TPE is continued until the platelet count is normal and signs of hemolysis are resolved for at least 2 days.

Adding rituximab to initial therapy decreases the risk of relapse. Caplacizumab, an anti-VWF nanobody, decreases mortality if used in patients with ADAMTS13 <10%.

Supportive therapy, such as steroids and dialysis, may be added, but neither heparin nor antibiotics addresses the underlying defect, and dialysis alone is insufficient.

The given peripheral smear shows fragmented red cells called schistocytes and helmet cells.



Other options:

Option A: Factor 8 deficiency causes Hemophilia A, an X-linked bleeding disorder, which presents with prolonged aPTT, deep tissue bleeds, and hemarthrosis.

Option C: vWF deficiency causes von Willebrand Disease(vWD),the most common inherited bleeding disorder, which presents with mucocutaneous bleeding and prolonged bleeding time.

Option D: Protein C is a vitamin-K-dependent anticoagulant; deficiency leads to a hypercoagulable state.

questions.text:
122. Match the following alkylating agents with their respective classes.

Drug | Class 1. Thiotepa | a. Alkyl sulfonate 2. Ifosfamide | b. Nitrogen mustard 3. Busulfan | c. Ethyleneimine 4. Streptozocin | d. Nitrosourea
questions.solution:
The correct match of the given alkylating agents with their respective classes is 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d. Drug | Class 1. Thiotepa | c. Ethyleneimine 2. Ifosfamide | b. Nitrogen mustard 3. Busulfan | a. Alkyl sulfonate 4. Streptozocin | d. Nitrosourea

Alkylating agents are chemotherapeutic drugs that work by alkylating high-electron-density groups in the DNA structure, such as phosphates, amines, hydroxyl groups, sulphydryl groups, and oxygen. This change in the DNA structure is responsible for their cytotoxic effects, which are useful in treating neoplasms. They are classified into 6 major types: nitrogen mustards, ethyleneimines, triazenes, methylhydrazines, nitrosoureas, and alkyl sulfonates. 

Thiotepa is an ethyleneimine-type alkylating agent, made up of three ethyleneimine groups with a nucleophilic thiophosphoryl base for stability. It is used in high-dose chemotherapy regimens and causes myelosuppression, neurotoxic symptoms like seizures, coma, and sometimes mucositis.

Ifosfamide is an example of a nitrogen mustard and is analogous to cyclophosphamide. It is used in the treatment of pediatric and adult sarcomas and relapsed germ cell testicular tumours. Similar to cyclophosphamide, it can cause urothelial damage due to the accumulation of acrolein; thus, concomitant MESNA should be given to prevent bladder toxicity. Platelet suppression, neurotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are other adverse effects seen.

Busulfan comes under the category of alkyl sulphonates and is used in chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) cases where BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors are not available or not tolerated. Adverse effects include thrombocytopenia, lung fibrosis (busulfan lung), impotence, sterility, and amenorrhea. Hepatotoxicity and veno-occlusive disease of the liver are seen when administered with CYP enzyme inhibitors.

Streptozocin is a nitrosourea due to the presence of the methylnitrosourea group in its structure. It is used in the treatment of pancreatic islet cell carcinoma due to its high affinity for islets of Langerhans and carcinoid tumours. Nausea is a common side effect along with mild nephrotoxicity and hepatotoxicity.

Alkylating agents are generally used in combination with other drugs due to the risk of causing drug resistance, which can be attributed to mechanisms such as reduced permeability of actively transported drugs, detoxification of electrophilic intermediates due to increased concentration of nucleophilic compounds, presence of different DNA repair pathways, active degradation, and inability to recognise reactive intermediates.

questions.text: 123. Some bioterrorism agents are moderately easy to spread, causing moderate illness and low mortality, requiring enhanced diagnostic capabilities. Which of the following agents does not fall into this category?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin from Clostridium botulinum is a Category A agent, indicating a higher threat level. The other agents mentioned above are Category B bioterrorism agents.

Bioterrorism involves the intentional release of biological agents to cause illness or death in people, animals, or plants. Bioweapons are classified into three groups—A, B, and C—based on priority.

Category B agents are the second-highest priority. They spread relatively easily and usually cause moderate illness with low mortality rates. Enhanced diagnostic tools are needed for quick identification to effectively manage these threats.

Some examples of category B agents:

* Melioidosis & Glanders (caused by Burkholderia species)

* Brucellosis

* Psittacosis

* Toxins: Ricin, Enterotoxin B of S. aureus, and Epsilon toxin of C. perfringens

* Q fever (Coxiella burnetii)

questions.text: 124. A patient presents with hypocalcemia, cleft palate, and increased susceptibility to infections. Her G-banding karyotype is reported as 46, XX. Which of the following genetic mechanisms is responsible for the patient's abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient with hypocalcemia, cleft palate, and immunodeficiency is most likely has DiGeorge Syndrome. DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11).

The chromosomal deletion leads to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (Thymus and parathyroid glands).  

Karyotyping is usually normal and definitive diagnosis requires fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) with a fluorescent DNA probe to detect the deleted DNA segment. Treatment is supportive.

Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. In the G-banding technique of karyotyping, Giemsa staining is performed after partial denaturation of chromatin. It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics. 

Other options:

Option B: Nondisjunction is the mechanism by which errors in chromosome numbers occur due to failure of paired chromosomes to separate appropriately during cell division. Examples include Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21), Edward Syndrome (Trisomy 18) and Patau Syndrome (Trisomy 13).

Option C: Robertsonian translocation occurs when two (usually acrocentric) chromosomes break down at the centromere and recombine such that two long arms and two short arms are joined. Down’s syndrome may occur due to Robertsonian translocation.

Option D: Uniparental disomy is the inheritance of a pair of non-identical chromosomes from a single parent. Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome are examples of uniparental disomy.

Pearl PM0535: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

* C – Cardiac defects

* A – Abnormal facies

* T – Thymic aplasia

* C – Cleft palate

* H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: 125. An elderly male presented to the OPD with complaints of difficulty in breathing and a rapidly enlarging, painful mass in the front of the neck. On examination, the mass is hard in consistency. FNAC shows large pleomorphic giant cells, and the cells are negative for thyroglobulin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario, representing an elderly male with dyspnoea and a hard mass in the thyroid region with rapid progression and FNAC showing large pleomorphic giant cells, with thyroglobulin marker negative, is most likely to be Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. 

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma most commonly presents in the 7th to 8th decade of life. The key characteristic features include a long-standing neck mass, with rapid progression associated with pain. The other associated symptoms include dysphonia, dysphagia, and dyspnea. The tumour is sometimes found to be large enough to be fixed to the surrounding structures with areas of necrosis and ulceration. 

FNAC is used for diagnosis as it reveals characteristic giant and multinucleated cells. Histopathological examination reveals a firm whitish mass grossly and a sheet of cells with marked heterogeneity can be seen on microscopy. The neoplastic cells are positive for epithelial markers like cytokeratin, but are usually negative for thyroglobulin, which is a marker of thyroid differentiation.

For patients with intrathyroidal mass, a total or near-total thyroidectomy combined with lymph node dissection is preferred. If extrathyroidal extension is present, an en bloc resection should be considered with R1 resection. Adjuvant therapy includes radiotherapy and chemotherapy for metastatic tumours. 

The image below shows Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.



Other options: 

Option A: Medullary carcinoma is a type of differentiated thyroid carcinoma, and its presentation is more indolent than rapid. Microscopically, the tumour comprises sheets of infiltrating neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid.



Option C: Riedel’s thyroiditis is an invasive fibrous thyroiditis in which the entire or part of the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue. Autoimmune is the most likely aetiology suggested. It progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression and a painless, hard anterior neck mass. FNAC is usually inadequate, and hence, open thyroid biopsy is done, which reveals abundant lymphoid infiltration.

Option D: Thyroid lymphoma is usually observed as the non-Hodgkin B-cell type. It commonly develops from the existing chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is a well-defined hypoechoic mass that usually simulates anaplastic carcinoma; however, it is painless. In rare cases, the patient presents with acute respiratory distress. FNAC is usually non-diagnostic, hence an open biopsy is needed.

* Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma

* Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma

* Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma

* Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma

* Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma

* Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma

* Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma

* Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text:
126. An 8-year-old girl presented with excessive facial hair, clitoromegaly, and increased blood glucose. CT scan of the abdomen revealed a right suprarenal mass. IGF-2 levels are high, and Ki-67 is 25%. What is the diagnosis?

IGF - Insulin like growth factor
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with the laboratory findings, are indicative of adrenocortical carcinoma.

Signs and symptoms of hyperadrenalism are commonly seen in adrenocortical carcinoma. These are based on the excess secretion of the three main hormones from the adrenal cortex. The different features of hyperadrenalism are:

* Cushing syndrome (due to excess secretion of cortisol) - weight gain, hypertension, truncal obesity, moon facies, buffalo hump, increased blood glucose (hyperglycemia), glucosuria, and polydipsia.

* Hyperaldosteronism (due to excess secretion of aldosterone) - secondary hypertension is most commonly seen. If hypokalemia is present, neuromuscular manifestations like weakness, paraesthesias are seen.

* Adrenogenital syndrome (due to excess secretion of androgens) - Signs of virilization, like excess facial hair (hirsutism) and clitoromegaly in women, are seen.

The table below shows the difference between adrenocortical adenoma and carcinoma Feature | Adrenocortical adenoma | Adrenocortical carcinoma Age prevalence | More common in adults | Common in children Clinical features | Clinically silent, incidental finding.

If functional, hyperaldosteronism or Cushing syndrome are commonly seen. | Typically functional.

Most often causes virilization, but can also produce other features of hyperadrenalism. Gross Morphology | Yellow to yellow-brown due to lipids. | Variegated appearance with necrosis, haemorrhage, and cystic changes. Microscopy findings | Inconspicuous mitotic activity with eosinophilic to vacuolated cytoplasm and small nuclei with some pheomorphism | Eosinophilic cytoplasm with pleomorphic nuclei with high mitotic activity, and necrosis. Ki-67/IGF-2 | Ki-67<5%; IGF-2: normal | High Ki-67 and IGF-2 levels

Steroidogenic factor - I (SF-1) and inhibin-alpha are expressed by both adrenocortical adenomas as well as carcinomas.

Other options:

Option B: Phaeochromocytoma is a neuroendocrine tumour arising from the adrenal medulla, which presents with excess secretion of catecholamines leading to headaches, high blood pressure, sweating, and palpitations.

Option D: Adrenal myelolipomas are rare, benign lesions composed of adipocytes and haematopoietic cells. Clinical signs as described above will not be seen in adrenal myelolipomas.

questions.text: 127. A patient presents with high colored urine. A urine dipstick test done was positive. On further evaluation by centrifugation at 2000rpm for 5 min, the sample was still high colored but became colorless after about 3 hours. Which among the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myoglobinuria is most likely in this patient.

A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme which is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or due to porphyrias.

Myoglobinuria is the presence of an excess amount of myoglobin in the urine. It is mostly caused by muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury. 

Causes of myoglobinuria:

* Physical causes are trauma, crush injury, heatstroke, hypothermia, malignant hyperthermia, extensive burns, seizures, strenuous exercise, and prolonged immobility.

* Non-physical causes include hypoxic injury, metabolic disturbances, genetic disorders, infections, drugs, and toxins.

The primary goal of treatment in the case of myoglobinuria is to prevent acute kidney injury (AKI), and for that, the initial therapy is mainly focused on rehydration to facilitate the renal clearance of myoglobin.

questions.text:
128. Which molecule on T cells is required for a costimulatory signal during activation?

TCR: T-cell receptor
questions.solution:
CD28 on T cells is required for the costimulatory signal during activation.

T cell activation requires two signals : 

* Antigen-specific: TCR recognises antigen presented by MHC on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). This ensures specificity.

* Costimulatory: CD28 (on T cell) binds to B7 (CD80/86) on APCs. This provides the necessary costimulatory signal to avoid anergy (functional inactivation).

Without the second signal, the T cell cannot proliferate and becomes anergic, which is an important mechanism of peripheral tolerance.

The given image shows T-cell activation.



Other options :

Option A: CD3 is a part of the TCR complex, important for signal transduction.

Option C: CD40-CD40L is important for class switching, not initial T-cell activation.

Option D: TCR recognises antigen, provides signal 1.

questions.text: 129. A 12-year-old boy presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea for 3 days. His stools were greasy and foul-smelling. A wet preparation of the stool sample is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child having loose greasy, foul-smelling stools, vomiting, and abdominal pain along with stool examination showing trophozoites that are tennis-racquet shaped is strongly suggestive of Giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Infection is common in children and occurs through the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water and food. A single cyst can hatch out into two trophozoites, which eventually colonize the duodenum and upper part of the jejunum. It is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the small intestine in humans.

Clinical features include diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, belching, flatus, nausea, and vomiting which last for more than one week.

Wet mount preparation of stool samples may show the presence of a small, oval cyst surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall or a trophozoite that is shaped like a tennis racket and is also referred to as heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped. Trophozoites are convex dorsally and have a sucking disk ventrally, that helps in attachment to the intestinal mucosa. Other tests include the string test/entero test, and serodiagnosis by ELISA kits to detect Giardia-specific antigen, GSA 65.

Metronidazole and tinidazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

Other options :

Option A: Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery. Microscopic examination of a saline wet mount of the stool shows the presence of diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile crystals called Charcot-Leyden crystals along with nuclear masses called pyknotic bodies. Cysts are spherical in shape with a single nucleus while trophozoites have an irregular shape with the presence of pseudopodia. An image of the cyst is shown below.



Option C: Cryptosporidium parvum has the sporulated oocyst as the infective form. The oocyst is acid-fast. Humans are infected by ingestion of contaminated food and water with feces or autoinfection. The patient may be asymptomatic or cause a self-limiting febrile illness, with watery diarrhea in conjunction with abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss.



Option D: Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan, present in the large intestine, infective form is a binucleate cyst. Clinical manifestations - infection is usually asymptomatic, patient rarely develops intermittent diarrhoea and abdominal cramps.  Diagnosis is by stool microscopy. An image of the trophozoite is shown below.

questions.text: 130. A 55-year-old man who underwent a lung transplant a year ago for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is experiencing chronic cough with expectoration, increasing dyspnea, and wheezing. Examination reveals wheezing, hypoxemia, and crackles. The HRCT thorax image is provided below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with HRCT Thorax findings demonstrating mosaic perfusion with air-trapping in the right lung, points towards the diagnosis of Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS).

Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS) is a clinical diagnosis indicating graft deterioration post-transplantation, characterized by chronic, irreversible, and progressive decline in lung function based on forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1). It is a recognized long-term complication following both lung and bone marrow transplantation.

Risk factors for BOS include:

* CMV pneumonitis

* Aspergillus colonization

* Primary graft dysfunction

* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

* Community-acquired respiratory viruses

* Prolonged transplantation ischemic time    

Histopathology reveals chronic obstructive lung disease affecting the bronchioles and smaller airways. This results from an insult to the lower respiratory tract, leading to inflammation and fibrosis of these small airways.

Clinical manifestations often include cough, dyspnea, chest pain, and respiratory distress, with initial or no improvement with antibiotics. The condition progresses with increasing dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production, and wheezing. Physical examination findings are nonspecific, but may include wheezing, hypoxemia, and crackles. HRCT frequently shows patchy areas or a mosaic pattern of hyperlucency, air trapping, and bronchiectasis. Open lung biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosis.

Treatment involves a combination of optimal supportive care and anti-inflammatory therapy to inhibit lymphocyte proliferation. Corticosteroids should be given early; pulse steroid therapy with methylprednisolone is preferred. Prolonged courses should be avoided to minimise severe side effects and mortality from infections.

Other options:

Option A: Bronchial dehiscence is a common complication after transplantation, occurring 2 to 4 weeks post-surgery. Symptoms include dyspnea, air leaks, and difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation. CT scans may reveal bronchial wall irregularities and defects, while direct bronchoscopy is the definitive diagnostic test.

Option B: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis often recurs months to years after lung transplantation. A CT scan shows bilateral ground-glass opacities with interlobular septal thickening and some spared lobules, creating a "crazy-paving" pattern, especially in the lower lobes.

Option C: Mycobacterial pneumonia typically develops over four months after lung transplantation, caused by tuberculous and nontuberculous species. CT findings include lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion for primary infections, while post-primary infections show upper-lung consolidation, cavitation, and centrilobular nodules.

questions.text: 131. A 29-year-old woman complains of infertility. Her cycles are regular but only 21 days long. An endometrial biopsy is done on day 21 and is given below. Which hormonal therapy might benefit her?
questions.solution:
Progesterone in the luteal phase will help her infertility because she has insufficient progesterone.

The given endometrial biopsy shows subnucleolar vacuoles, suggesting early secretory phase even on day 21. This means that the endometrium is lagging behind the expected dating. By day 21, it should normally show a mid-secretory pattern. This suggests a luteal phase defect - inadequate progesterone action, either from corpus luteum dysfunction or inadequate follicular development. This can present as infertility or recurrent early pregnancy loss. Thus, this can be treated with progesterone in the luteal phase.

Normally, in a 28-day menstrual cycle, days 5-14 are estrogen-driven and are called the proliferative(follicular) phase. Days 15-28 are progesterone-driven and are called the secretory(luteal) phase. Within the secretory phase:

* Early secretory phase - day 15-18, just after ovulation. In this phase, there is the appearance of subnuclear vacuoles. This is due to the secretion of glycogen between the nuclei and the basement membrane.

* Mid secretory phase - around day 19-23. Maximal glandular secretion (secretions seen in the lumen) and stromal edema occur.

* Late secretory phase - around days 24-28. Glands are maximally tortuous, corkscrew glands, nucleus central and well-defined borders.

Other options:

Option A: Estrogen acts in the follicular phase to stimulate the growth of the endometrium. Here, the problem is in the luteal phase.

Option C: Continuous GnRH agonists suppress pituitary FSH/LH. It is used for endometriosis or fibroids. It would actually worsen ovulation and progesterone production.

Option D: Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that lowers prolactin. It is used in infertility due to hyperprolactinemia.

Pearl PM1514: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: 132. Baclofen is a:
questions.solution:
Baclofen is a GABAB receptor agonist.

Baclofen is a centrally acting muscle relaxant. It is an analog of the inhibitory transmitter GABA and acts as a selective GABAB receptor agonist. It also acts at the spinal cord where it decreases excitatory transmitter release of excitatory neurotransmitter release.

Baclofen is used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal injuries, and flexor spasm. In these conditions, baclofen is the preferred drug for symptomatic relief.

It can also be administered intrathecally around the spinal cord through a catheter placed surgically.

Side effects of baclofen include drowsiness, mental confusion, weakness, and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Nm receptor antagonism is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants. The drugs in this class include pancuronium, vecuronium, rocuronium, atracurium, mivacurium, etc.

Option C: D2 receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of bromocriptine. It is used for the treatment of prolactinoma and Parkinson's disease.

Option D: α2 adrenergic receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of clonidine. It is used for the treatment of hypertension.

questions.text: 133. A school-going boy presents to the clinic with a fever and irritability for the past two days. On examination, vesicular lesions on the oral mucosa and rashes on the palms and soles are observed, as shown in the image. Which of the following characteristics correctly describes the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy with fever and irritability, along with the images of vesicular lesions on the oral mucosa and rashes on the palms and soles, points to the diagnosis of Hand-foot-mouth disease caused by Coxsackie virus, which is typically a naked single-stranded RNA virus. 

Hand, foot and mouth disease typically occurs as sporadic cases or localised outbreaks. Coxsackie A16, A9 and B 1-3 are commonly associated with hand-foot mouth disease (HFMD). It includes oral and pharyngeal ulcerations along with the rashes on the palms and soles, which heal without crusting. HFMD is recognised as an important infectious disease worldwide. Diagnosis is confirmed by virus isolation and RT-PCR.

Coxsackie virus belongs to the Picornaviridae family and the Enterovirus genus. They are divided into Group A (causes herpangina, hand-foot-mouth disease, aseptic meningitis) and Group B (pleurodynia, myocarditis, orchitis). Transmission is primarily faecal-oral. Coxsackie group A is commonly associated with herpangina. Small vesicles appear on the fauces and back of the throat. These vesicles rupture and form painful ulcers.

The given image shows the classification of viruses based on envelope presence and type of nucleic acid.



Other options:

Option A: Enveloped double-stranded DNA viruses include herpes(mucocutaneous and vesicular ulcerative genital lesions) and hepadna(hepatitis B).

Option B: Naked double-stranded RNA virus is the Rotavirus virus, which is the most common cause of diarrhoeal disease in infants and children.

Option C: Enveloped single-stranded RNA viruses include orthomyxovirus and paramyxovirus. Orthomyxovirus is responsible for causing influenza (upper respiratory tract infections). Paramyxovirus includes mumps(parotitis) and respiratory syncytial virus(acute bronchiolitis).

questions.text:
134. An elderly diabetic male was started on intravenous KCl in dextrose solution by an intern for treating hypokalemia. After beginning the infusion, the patient experienced sudden weakness of the lower limbs. What is the pathophysiology behind this sudden weakness?

KCl - Potassium chloride
questions.solution:
The pathophysiology behind the sudden onset of weakness in a diabetic patient given intravenous KCl in dextrose solution is dextrose-induced hyperinsulinemia.

Dextrose causes the release of insulin, which causes hypokalemia and is used in the treatment of hyperkalemia. Therefore, when intravenous KCl is administered to patients with hypokalemia, it is done so in a solution of normal saline. Administration of excess KCl can lead to local effects such as chemical phlebitis, irritation, and pain at the site.

Hypokalemia is a common electrolyte abnormality seen in diabetes mellitus due to poor glycemic control, causing polydipsia and polyuria. Moreover, insulin therapy causes the uptake of potassium in the cells, thus causing hypokalemia. It presents as fatigue, muscle weakness, and may show T-wave changes on the ECG. Chronic hypokalemia causes damage to the renal tubules and affects vasopressin action on the collecting ducts, leading to exacerbation of polydipsia and polyuria.

Other options:

Option A: Polyuria can cause hypokalemia due to excess excretion of K+ in the urine. However, sudden exacerbation of hypokalemia is not attributed to polyuria.

Option B: Hyperkalemia is an emergency and is associated with cardiac arrhythmias. Sudden weakness is unlikely.

Option D: Polydipsia has not been known to reduce potassium levels enough to show features of hypokalemia. However, hypokalemia can cause polydipsia by diminishing the ability of the kidney to concentrate urine, leading to polyuria and subsequent polydipsia.

questions.text: 135. A 35-year-old male presents with a single, dark red, well-demarcated plaque on his upper lip that has recurred in the exact same spot after taking a medication for a fever. Over time, the lesion has become hyperpigmented. What is the cause of this hyperpigmentation?

choices.text: Drug residue accumulation in the dermis
Pigment-laden macrophages in the upper dermis

questions.solution:
The characteristic lesion healing with hyperpigmentation following drug intake is suggestive of fixed drug eruption. Hyperpigmentation is caused by the presence of pigment-laden macrophages in the upper dermis.

Fixed drug eruption (FDE) is a cutaneous adverse drug reaction that is characterised by recurrent, well‐defined lesions that appear in the same sites each time the offending drug is taken. It typically occurs 30 minutes to 8 hours after drug exposure. They occur due to the persistence of memory T-cells at the site of the lesion long after clinical resolution. Subsequent exposure activates these cells, causing lesion at the same site.

The most common drugs that act as triggers are:

* NSAIDs 

* Paracetamol

* Cotrimoxazole

* Tetracyclines

Fixed drug eruptions (FDE) mostly occur on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation. They are usually solitary or few in number and recur at the same location. But new lesions can occur on different body parts on re-exposure to the offending drug. FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. 

Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported. These include the following:

* NSAID‐induced FDE - lips and genitals

* Tetracycline and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole-induced FDE-genitals

* Metamizole-induced FDE-trunk and extremities

* Carbocysteine-induced FDE-face

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

The image below shows a well-defined hyperpigmented patch of a fixed drug eruption.



Other options: 

Option A: While the drug or its metabolite is the cause of the hypersensitivity reaction, drug residue accumulation in the dermis is not the direct cause of the hyperpigmentation.

Option B: The number of melanocytes is typically normal in FDE pigmentation. 

Option D: Hemosiderin ( an iron-storage complex) deposition causes a brownish-yellow to purplish colour. While it can occur in bleeding-related conditions, the primary dark pigmentation in FDE is due to pigment-laden macrophages.

questions.text: 136. A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions as shown below. KOH stain revealed the presence of predominant macroconidia and scanty microconidia. Which of the following conditions is also likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopic examination point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection.

The given image shows annular lesions with central clearing which is seen in dermatophytosis.

Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

* Trichophyton: involves skin, hair, and nails. Microconidia > Macroconidia

* Microsporum: involves skin and hair. Macroconidia > Microconidia

* Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia.

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

* Endothrix - It is a non-inflammatory type of tinea in which multiple black dots and fine scaling are present within the areas of alopecia; it is most commonly caused by Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum.

* Ectothrix - It is a mild inflammatory type of tinea in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, Microsporum canis, Microsporum equinum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.

* Kerion - It is a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation. It is commonly caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

* Favus - It is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

questions.text: 137. The most common position of the appendix is denoted by:
questions.solution:
The labelling ”1“ represents the retrocecal position of the appendix, which is the most common position.

This is because the appendix develops during the descent of the colon in embryonic life.

The base of the appendix is fixed and, depending on the direction of the tip, the positions of the appendix are as follows:

questions.text: 138. A 16-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of gradually progressive swelling and pain over the upper portion of the tibia for the past 5-6 months. An X-ray of the affected area is shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the radiograph showing an area of lucency with sclerotic borders, is suggestive of Brodie's abscess. An open biopsy with curettage is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Brodie's abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. The organism mostly involved would be Staphylococcus aureus. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

Differential diagnosis: The clinical features and x-ray can mimic several other conditions.

* Cystic tuberculosis

* Eosinophilic granuloma

* Osteoid osteoma

* Ewing's sarcoma

Investigations: 

* WBC counts and blood cultures are usually normal.

* ESR may be elevated in some cases. 

* The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity. 

* MRI may be helpful in diagnosis.

* Open biopsy with curettage is indicated if there is any doubt in the diagnosis.

Treatment:

* Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) intravenous for 4-5 days, followed by oral administration for another 6 weeks; healing may take up to 12 months

* Curettage is needed if the x-rays show no healing after conservative management.

* Curettage is also done along with open biopsy in doubtful cases.

questions.text: 139. A 50-year-old man comes to ophthalmology OPD with the complaints of diminished vision along with floaters and photopsia. The consultant on duty uses the following instrument to assess the retinal lesions. All of the following are the advantages of this instrument except ______

Produces real image with 15 times higher magnification
Field of view is much larger
Depth perception of the lesion is possible

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and it produces an inverted real image of 4 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

* The field of view is much larger than direct ophthalmoscopy.

* Examination of the peripheral retina up to the ora serrata is possible.

* Depth perception of the lesion is possible due to stereopsis with a binocular indirect ophthalmoscope.

* Visualization of the fundus in very high refractive error is also possible, where it may not be possible to focus the lesion with a direct ophthalmoscope.

questions.text:
141. A patient is undergoing the estimation of p-aminohippuric acid (PAH) clearance. He was infused with PAH, and the plasma and urinary concentration were measured. Which of the following is the correct conclusion based on the values given below? * Concentration of PAH in urine: 14 mg/mL * Urine flow: 0.7 mL/min * Concentration of PAH in plasma: 0.02 mg/mL

(GFR: Glomerular filtration rate, ERPF: Effective renal plasma flow)
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the effective renal plasma flow (RPF) is 490mL/min. 

Clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which a particular substance is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes). Para aminohippuric acid (PAH) is filtered by the glomeruli and secreted by the tubular cells. Therefore, the amount of the PAH that enters the kidney is almost completely removed. It means that the entire renal plasma is cleared from PAH in a given time. Because of this, PAH clearance measures the renal plasma flow.

The formula used to calculate PAH clearance (CPAH) is:

UPAH × V ⁄ PPAH  , where UPAH  is the concentration of PAH in urine (14mg/mL), PPAH  is the concentration of PAH in plasma (0.02mg/mL), and V is the urine flow (0.7 mL/min). Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

PAH clearance =  UPAH × V ⁄ PPAH  = (14 x 0.7)/0.02 = 9.8 / 0.02 = 490 mL/min.

In an actual scenario, about 90% of the PAH is removed by the kidney. Therefore, this is called effective renal plasma flow. Actual renal plasma flow is calculated by dividing the PAH clearance by an extraction ratio. The extraction ratio is arterial concentration minus renal venous concentration divided by arterial concentration. Normally, the extraction ratio is 0.9.

If we consider the extraction ratio to be 0.9 in this scenario, the actual renal plasma flow will be 490/0.9 = ~544 mL/min

Similarly, inulin and creatine clearance are used in the measurement of the glomerular filtration rate.

The sonographic report showed a singleton fetus with normal amniotic fluid volume. There was a sudden termination of the spine above the level of the iliac wings and abnormal positioning of the lower extremities. Which among the following is likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg with proteinuria

questions.solution:
The clinical case described with the mentioned ultrasound findings suggests caudal regression sequence/ sacral agenesis, which is associated with overt or pregestational diabetes with high HbA1C levels ≥ 6.5.

Caudal regression sequence is a rare anomaly, characterised by the absence of the sacral spine and sometimes portions of the lumbar spine as well. It is 25 times more prevalent in pregnancies complicated by diabetes. Poorly controlled diabetes is the underlying factor for this malformation risk.

Sonography shows an abnormally short spine lacking normal lumbosacral curvature, which terminates abruptly above the level of the iliac wings. Since the sacrum does not lie between the iliac wings, they may appear shield-like because they are abnormally close together. Abnormal positioning of the lower extremities and lack of nor­mal local soft tissue development may also be seen.

The image below shows a case of sacral agenesis.



Overt diabetes may be pre-existing or detected for the first time during the present pregnancy. The following criteria are used to diagnose it according to the American Diabetes Association:

* Random plasma glucose level of >200 mg/dL plus classic signs and symptoms such as polydipsia, polyuria, and unexplained weight loss

* Fasting glucose level of >126 mg/dL

* First-trimester glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level of ≥6.5%

Other options:

Option B: Blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg with proteinuria points to preeclampsia, which can lead to intrauterine death, intrauterine growth restriction, asphyxia, or prematurity of the fetus.

Option C: Use of valproate in pregnancy leads to neural tube defects, cardiac anomalies, and developmental delay. 

Option D: Lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly if taken during pregnancy. Ebstein's anomaly is characterised by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to severe tricuspid regurgitation and marked right atrial enlargement.

Pearl PM2022: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

questions.text: 143. A young, non-smoking woman with a history of migraine without aura seeks oral contraception. What is the primary mechanism of action of the most suitable prescribed contraceptive?
questions.solution:
For a young, non-smoking woman with a history of migraine headaches (without focal neurological changes), progesterone-only pills are the preferred oral contraceptive and their primary mechanism of action is by thickening of cervical mucus.

Migraines can increase the risk of stroke in young women, especially when using combined oral contraceptives (COCs), raising the risk by two to four times. While ACOG guidelines do permit combined hormonal contraceptives (CHCs) in such cases due to the low absolute risk, intrauterine devices or progestin-only pills are often better options. 

Progesterone-only pills primarily work by thickening cervical mucus, which reduces sperm penetration. They also cause decidualization and atrophy of the endometrium, impairing implantation. Unlike combined pills, they do not consistently prevent ovulation. To be most effective, these pills must be taken at the same time every day, as their effects on cervical mucus decline after 24 hours. Additionally, these pills have little impact on carbohydrate metabolism, coagulation factors, or blood pressure, making them a good choice for women with a higher risk of cardiovascular issues.

Other options:

Option A: Prevention of breakthrough bleeding is a therapeutic effect caused by estrogen due to suppression of FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) release, not a mechanism of action.

Option C: The release of FSH is inhibited by estrogen, but this is not the main mechanism of progestin-only pills.

Option D: Progestin-only pills do not consistently suppress gonadotropins, meaning ovulation is not reliably prevented. Thus, this is not a primary mechanism.

Pearl PM2328: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

* Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)

* Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate

* Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)

* Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women

* Norethisterone 350 μg

* Norgestrel 75 μg

* Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg

* Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results

* Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone

* Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia

* Post-coital pills or interceptive

* Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart

* Mifepristone 10-600 mg

* Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse

* Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse

* GnRH agonists  

* CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

* Progesterone only injectables

* DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months

* NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months

* Combined injectables

* Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg

* Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

* Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day
