* Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week

* Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: 144. A 7-year-old boy started experiencing weakness in his limbs in the evenings. Mild ptosis was noted on examination. Anti-AchR and anti-MuSK antibodies are negative. What can be the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of congenital myasthenic syndromes.

Congenital myasthenic syndromes are a group of syndromes seen in infancy and childhood, caused by mutations in genes that aid in the transmission of impulses across the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). Patients present with weakness and easy fatiguability of the limb muscles along with ptosis and diplopia, indicating involvement of the levator palpebrae superioris and extraocular muscles.

On serology, anti-AChR and anti-MuSK antibodies are negative. Molecular testing is used for precise diagnosis, to plan the management options, and aid in genetic counselling. Some forms of CMS improve with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, while other types, such as slow channel syndrome, acetylcholinesterase deficiency, and DOK7-related CMS, worsen. Fluoxetine and quinidine have been used in the treatment of slow channel syndrome and albuterol for mutations in acetylcholinesterase, rapsyn, DOK7, and agrin.

Other options:

Option A: Botulism is caused by ingestion of food contaminated with Clostridium botulinum toxin. Weakness of the limbs is commonly seen along with respiratory muscle weakness, leading to respiratory failure and diminished tendon reflexes. Toxin detection in serum is diagnostic, and prompt use of anti-toxin is warranted.

Option C: Lambert-Eaton myasthenia syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against P/Q-type calcium channels at the presynaptic motor nerve terminals, and these impair the release of ACh from nerve terminals. It is characterised by weakness of the proximal muscles, depressed or absent reflexes, and autonomic symptoms like orthostatic hypotension, dry mouth, and impotence. 

Option D: Spinal muscular atrophy is a progressive motor neuron disease. Types I and II present early in infancy, while type III is seen in childhood. Patients present with loss of muscle tone and weakness due to the denervation of the muscle fibres. Fasciculations may be seen due to compensatory reinnervation of the adjacent motor units. Motor nerve nuclei supplying the extraocular muscles are usually spared.

Pearl PM1844: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text:
145. A 45-year-old man with acute flank pain is found to have nephrolithiasis. He is advised DECT instead of conventional non-contrast CT. What is the primary advantage of DECT in this clinical setting?

DECT - Dual Energy Computed Tomography

choices.text: It helps in characterization of stone composition
It improves sensitivity for detecting small stones

questions.solution:
DECT offers a non-invasive method for characterising urinary stone composition.

It is particularly useful in differentiating uric acid from non-uric acid stones. This distinction is critical for treatment decisions, as uric acid stones are often treatable with medical dissolution therapy. Non-uric acid stones (e.g., calcium oxalate) typically require interventions like ESWL or surgery. By identifying the stone type before intervention, DECT enables personalised and less invasive treatment strategies.

Comparison of Conventional CT and DECT Feature | Conventional CT | DECT Detects stones | Yes | Yes Characterise stone type | No | Yes Radiolucent stones detection | Yes (by density) | Yes (with composition info) Sensitivity for small stones | High | Similar or slightly less Radiation dose | Lower with low-dose | Similar to conventional CT

DECT operates by acquiring images at two distinct energy levels (e.g., 80 and 140 kVp). The varying attenuation of X-rays by materials like uric acid and calcium-based stones across these energies allows for their specific identification. This overcomes the limitations of Hounsfield Units (HU) in single-energy CT, where values can overlap between different stone types.

The image below shows characterisation of kidney stones using dual-energy computed tomography (DECT).

* (a)-Axial image showing a non-uric acid renal stone in the right kidney (arrowhead), colored in blue

* (b)-Graph showing the composition of this stone (blue arrowhead)

* (c)-Axial image showing a uric acid renal calculus in the left kidney (arrow), colored in red

* (d)-Graph confirms the composition of the stone (red arrowhead)



Other Options:

Option B: DECT offers comparable sensitivity, not superior, to standard CT for stones ≥3 mm.

Option C: Standard non-contrast CT already detects uric acid stones (radiolucent on X-ray), so this is not unique to DECT.

Option D: DECT often has a higher radiation dose than low-dose CT, though dose-optimisation protocols are improving.

questions.text:
146. A 62-year-old male who presented with cervical lymphadenopathy got his workup done. The PET scan image is shown below. Which of the following triad is seen with this condition?

PET - Positron emission tomography
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male with cervical lymphadenopathy and a PET scan showing increased uptake in the nasopharynx suggests the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Trotter's triad is seen in cases of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can be caused by a variety of factors, including EBV infection, tobacco and opium smoking, air pollution, and chronic exposure to incense and burning wood. Pathologically, it may be proliferative, ulcerative, or infiltrative and can be diagnosed by a contrast-enhanced high-resolution CT scan of the neck and nasopharynx. Patients present with nasal obstruction, discharge, hyponasal speech, and epistaxis. In addition, the trotter's triad is also seen, which includes:

* Conductive deafness: This occurs due to obstruction or dysfunction of the eustachian tube, leading to impaired middle ear function.

* Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia: This symptom is characterized by sharp, shooting pain in the temporoparietal region of the head. It is primarily caused by the involvement of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which carries sensory fibers from the face and certain parts of the head.

* Palatal paralysis: This condition results from the involvement of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), which innervates the muscles of the soft palate. Palatal paralysis can lead to difficulty in swallowing, nasal regurgitation of fluids, and a nasal voice quality.

Other options

Option D: Meltzer's triad is observed in cryoglobulinemia and comprises of purpura, arthralgias, and weakness.

Pearl PM1615: Triads in Surgery

Triad | Seen in | Components Borchardt’s Triad | Gastric Volvulus | Epigastric pain + Inability to vomit + Inability to pass a nasogastric tube Cushing’s Triad | Intracranial hypertension | Hypertension + Bradycardia + Irregular respiration Dieulafoy’s Triad | Acute appendicitis | Hypersensitiveness of skin + Reflex muscular contraction + Tenderness at Mc Burney’s point Galezia's Triad | | Dupuytren’s contracture + Retroperitoneal fibrosis + Peyronie’s disease of the penis Hutchinson’s Triad | Congenital syphilis | Hutchison’s teeth (notched upper incisors) + Interstitial keratitis + Nerve deafness Mackler’s Triad | Boerhaave’s syndrome | Thoracic pain + Vomiting + Cervical subcutaneous emphysema Quincke's Triad | Hemobilia | Gastrointestinal hemorrhage + Biliary colic + Jaundice Rigler’s Triad | Gallstone ileus | Small bowel obstruction + Pneumobilia + Ectopic gallstone Saint's Triad | | Hiatus hernia + Gallstones+ Colonic diverticulosis Tillaux’s Triad | Mesenteric cyst | Soft fluctuant swelling in umbilical region + Freely mobile perpendicular to mesentery + Zone of resonance all around Trotter’s Triad | Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma | Conductive hearing loss + Immobility of homolateral soft palate + Trigeminal neuralgia Virchow’s Triad | Thrombosis | Hypercoagulability + Stasis + Endothelial injury Whipple’s Triad | Insulinoma | Symptoms of hypoglycemia + Serum glucose <50 mg/dL + Symptomatic relief on glucose ingestion

questions.text: 147. A child presents to the OPD alone, seeking treatment for a minor medical condition. A general physical examination can be performed with just the child’s consent, only if the child is older than ______.
questions.solution:
A general physical examination can be performed, exclusively by the child's consent, if that child is older than 12 years of age.

According to Section 27 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), previously Section 89 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), a child under 12 years of age and an insane person cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may result from an act done in good faith and for their benefit. In these cases, the consent of the parent or guardian should be taken. If they refuse, the doctor cannot treat the patient, even to save the patient's life.

Additionally, a father giving consent for an operative procedure on the child in good faith and for the child's benefit, though the said procedure is risky, cannot be held responsible if the child dies.

questions.text:
148. A two-step diagnostic protocol is used for syphilis. The first test (RPR) has high sensitivity and low specificity. The second test (FTA-ABS) has high specificity. What will this two-step process do to the positive predictive value (PPV)?

FTA-ABS - Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody-Absorption Test RPR - Rapid Plasma Reagin test

choices.text: PPV decreases due to increased false negatives
PPV increases due to decreased false positives
PPV increases due to increased true positives

questions.solution:
The positive predictive value (PPV) increases due to decreased false positives because the second test eliminates false positives.

In the given question, the First test (RPR) is very sensitive. So it detects almost everyone who actually has syphilis(true positives). But it is not very specific. So it also gives many false positives. The second test is very specific, so it rules out those false positives. | Diseased | Not diseased Test positive | True positive (TP) | False positive (FP) Test negative | False negative (FN) | True negative (TN)

Positive predictive value (PPV) = True positives / ( True positives + False positives). Hence, PPV improves when false positives go down, because the positives that are left are mostly true positives.

Positive predictive value (PPV) is defined as the probability that a person who tests positive for a disease actually has the disease, i.e, is a true positive. Sensitivity is the ability of a test to correctly identify those who have the disease (true positives). Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify those who do not have the disease (true negatives).

Other options:

Option A: The second test mainly reduces false positives and increases the PPV; it does not increase false negatives.

Option C: PPV does change when a highly specific confirmatory test is added.

Option D: The first test detects all true positives and also gives false positives because it is not very specific. The second test comes in and filters out all these false positives, thereby increasing the PPV. The number of true positives remains the same.

Pearl PM0358: Validity of a Screening Test

* Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.

* It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.

* These are the inherent properties of a screening test.

* PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.

* Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.



Formulae Sensitivity | TP     TP + FN Specificity | TN     FP + TN Predictive value of a positive test (PPV) | TP     TP + FP Predictive value of a negative test (NPV) | TN      TN + FN Percentage of false positives | FP      FP + TN Percentage of false negatives | FN      TP + FN

* PPV varies directly with prevalence

* NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: 149. You are encountering a case at the forensics department where the victim's body had an entry wound from a shotgun as shown below. What is the most likely distance range of the shot?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central rat-hole with peripheral satellite pellet holes appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun. So it was most likely shot at a distance range of 1-5 meters. 

Appearance of shotgun entry wounds at different ranges:

Contact shot

* Soft tissues -

* Single circular wound, often with muzzle imprint

* The diameter of the wound is approximately the same as that of the muzzle.

* No soot soiling, tattooing, singeing

* Bone

* Same as that of soft tissues, but wound may be split and ragged due to gas rebound

<30 cm

* Circular wound with surrounding soot soiling

* Burnt hairs - singeing

* Punctate skin lesions from powder particles - tattooing

30 cm to 1 m

* Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes

* Soot soiling

* Powder tattooing

1–5 meters

* Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes

* No soot, tattooing +/-

>5 meters

* Diffuse pellet pattern

* No central hole, no soot soiling, tattooing, singeing

questions.text: 150. A patient is posted for esophagectomy for the presence of esophageal carcinoma in the middle third of the esophagus. During the operation, the surgeon performs laparotomy and constructs a gastric tube. After this, he performs a right thoracotomy and removes the tumor. He then anastomoses the remaining part of the esophagus with the stomach in the upper part of the thorax. What is the type of esophagectomy done by the surgeon?
questions.solution:
The resection of a tumor in the middle third of the esophagus by laparotomy and right thoracotomy is called the Ivor Lewis approach. 

In the Ivor Lewis approach, partial esophagectomy and esophagogastric anastomosis are done in the thorax. 

Other approaches in esophagectomy:

* Orringer approach (option B) is used for tumors in the lower part of the esophagus. The stomach is mobilized through a midline abdominal incision or by laparotomy, and the tumor is removed. The cervical esophagus is mobilized through an incision in the neck, and anastomosis of the remaining part of the esophagus and the stomach is performed. This is a palliative procedure. 

* McKeown approach (option C) is used for the tumors in the upper part of the esophagus. In this technique, the surgeon performs laparotomy and thoracotomy to remove the tumor. A right-side neck approach is done for the anastomosis between the pharynx and stomach. 

McEvedy approach (option A) is used in the repair of the femoral hernia. The surgeon reaches the site of the hernia via a horizontal incision in the lower part of the abdomen, centered at the lateral edge of the rectus muscle.

Pearl PM1578: Replacement conduits after esophagectomy

* Best conduit after esophagectomy – Stomach

* Best conduit of choice after carcinoma esophagus resection – Stomach

* Best conduit of choice after benign disorders – Colon

* Best conduit of choice after short segment replacement – Jejunum

* Gastric conduit is based on right gastric and gastroepiploic arteries

* Left colon conduit is based on left colic artery

* The posterior mediastinal route is preferred for placement of conduit as it is the shortest route.

questions.text: 151. A 40-year-old woman who had recently been to the desert in the southwestern US presents with fever, cough, severe fatigue, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain. On examination, erythema nodosum is noted. Tissue culture findings are as shown below. What is the most likely causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a flu-like illness, erythema nodosum, symmetrical joint pain, and pleuritic chest pain with a history of travel to south western USA and tissue culture showing spherules points toward the diagnosis of coccidioidomycosis and the causative agent is Coccidioides immitis.

Coccidioides immitis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It occurs as a spherule in tissues and culture at 37°C and as the mycelial form in soil and culture at room temperature. They are endemic to the arid desert regions of the southwestern USA and California. Infection is acquired by inhaling dust containing arthrospores of the fungus.

The infection can be asymptomatic, or patients may present with symptoms like fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It is also referred to as Valley fever. Some clinical features occur due to an immunologic response. These include toxic erythema, erythema nodosum, and erythema multiforme. Symmetrical arthralgias called desert rheumatism may also be seen. Clinical dissemination of infection outside the thoracic cavity occurs in immunocompromised patients. 

Diagnosis:- Sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage, and biopsy specimens are the samples used for diagnosis. Microscopy shows spherule with endospores. Culture on brain heart infusion agar with 5% blood shows white-coloured colonies and is the most specific for diagnosis. Serology using ELISA, Immunodiffusion assays, and complement fixation assays are also used to detect IgM and IgG antibodies. Delayed hypersensitivity can be demonstrated by a positive skin test with 'coccidiodin' (analogous to the tuberculin test).

Azole drugs such as fluconazole and itraconazole are the mainstay of treatment. Severe cases are managed with intravenous amphotericin B. 

Other options:

Option B: Paracoccidioidis brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis. It is a chronic ulcerative granulomatous disease of the skin and mucosa.

Option C: Blastomyces dermatitidis causes blastomycosis, a systemic pyogranulomatous infection involving primarily the lungs. Infection may resemble tuberculosis, or get disseminated to various parts forming multiple abscesses. A cutaneous form of the disease would present as a papule, with secondary nodules that coalesce and form ulcerative lesions.

Option D: Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis. It is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system that is acquired by inhalation. It causes a pulmonary disease similar to tuberculosis.

Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings





1. Histoplasma:

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Pearl PM0567: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease | Common name Histoplasmosis | Darling’s disease Sporotrichosis | Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease Para-coccidioidomycosis | South American blastomycosis Coccidioidomycosis | Valley fever or desert rheumatism Blastomycosis | North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text: 152. A primigravida underwent a quadruple screening test at 16 weeks of gestation. All the parameters were low except for serum inhibin A level which was normal. Identify the condition in which the findings given above are seen.
questions.solution:
All the parameters like maternal serum alfa-fetoprotein (MSAFP), beta HCG, and unconjugated estriol levels are reduced in trisomy 18/Edwards syndrome. Maternal serum inhibin A level may be normal or reduced.

Quadruple testing is usually done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. This test can additionally help in picking up Smith-Lemli-Optiz syndrome. However, one of the limitations of the test is that it fails to detect trisomy 13. 

In trisomy 21 and neural tube defects, the changes in the screening markers are as follows: Parameter | Trisomy 21 | Trisomy 18 | Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect MSAFP | Low | Low | High β hCG | High | Low | Normal Unconjugated estriol | Low | Low | Normal Inhibin A | High | Normal/Low | Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows: Dual test (1st trimester) | Triple test (2nd trimester) | Quadruple test (2nd trimester) Beta HCG | Beta HCG | Beta HCG PAPP-A | Unconjugated estriol | Unconjugated estriol This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG | MSAFP | MSAFP | Serum inhibin A

questions.text: 153. Letulles technique is an autopsy technique characterised by ________

choices.text: Removal of organs one by one

questions.solution:
Letulle's technique is characterized by en masse removal of organs. It means thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one big organ block.

Pearl PM1458: Autopsy Techniques

* Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.

* Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.

* Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.

* Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: 154. A child being treated with drug X for head lice ingests the entire bottle. He subsequently develops chest pain, difficulty in breathing, drooling, eye discharge, and loss of consciousness. These symptoms are reversed with atropine. Identify drug X.
questions.solution:
Drug X is Malathion, an organophosphate which is used topically in the treatment of permethrin-resistant cases of pediculosis. In children > 6 years of age, a formulation with 78% isopropyl alcohol is used, which works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, causing paralysis and death of head lice. 

Since malathion is an acetylcholinesterase (AchE )inhibitor, overdose leads to a cholinergic toxidrome, which includes excess salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea, excessive bronchial secretions, bronchospasm, and loss of consciousness, and is reversed by atropine. It is also used as a pesticide to control the population of Mediterranean fruit flies and mosquitoes, which destroy the crop and can transmit infectious agents like the West Nile virus.

Other options:

Option A: Echothiophate is an irreversible inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase. It is used to treat glaucoma and, due to its quaternary ammonium structure and positive charge, is poorly absorbed.

Option B: Parathion is also an organophosphate insecticide; however, its use in treating head lice is not known

Option C: Permethrin is an over-the-counter drug that is used in treating head lice and acts by interfering with the Na+ transport proteins, causing paralysis and death in the insect. However, it is not an organophosphate.

Pearl PM0643: Certain specific clinical features diagnostic of poisons and poisoning

Clinical features | Possible causes Pupillary constriction (Miosis) | Barbiturates, caffeine, carbamates, carbolic acid (phenol), clonidine, methyl dopa, nicotine, opiates, organophosphates, parasympathomimetics. Pupillary dilatation (Mydriasis) | Alcohol (constricted in coma), amphetamines, antihistamines, benzodiazepines, carbon monoxide, cocaine, cyanide, datura (atropine), ephedrine Hippus (alternate constriction and dilatation of pupils) | Aconite, alcohol, barbiturates. Nystagmus | Alcohol, barbiturates, carbamazepine, phencyclidine, phenytoin Pinpoint pupils, and reduced respiratory rate | Opioids, cholinesterase inhibitors (organophosphorus or carbamate insecticides), clonidine, phenothiazines, Pontine hemorrhage Cyanosis | Any CNS depressant or agent causing methemoglobinemia Needle tracks, pinpoint pupils, and reduced respiratory rate | IV Opioids Dilated pupils or mid-point pupils, and reduced respiratory rate | Benzodiazepines Dilated pupils, tachycardia | * Tricyclic antidepressants – dry mouth, warm peripheries, may also be twitchy or have seizures

* Amphetamines, ecstasy, cocaine – may also be hallucinating or agitated

* Anticholinergic drugs such as benzhexol, benztropine – may also have hyperreflexia and myoclonus

questions.text: 155. The mechanism of normal labour with the fetus in the occipito-lateral position involves internal rotation of the occiput anteriorly to 2/8th of a circle with simultaneous shoulder rotation to 1/8th of a circle. Which of the following movements takes place during restitution?

choices.text: 1/8th rotation in the opposite direction of internal rotation
2/8th rotation in the same direction as internal rotation
1/8th rotation in the same direction as internal rotation
2/8th rotation in the opposite direction of internal rotation

questions.solution:
During normal labour, movement of restitution occurs by rotating the head through 1/8th of a circle in the direction opposite to that of internal rotation.

The most common position of the fetus is the left occipito-lateral position, where the vertex occupies the left anterior quadrant of the mother's pelvis. During internal rotation, there will be anterior rotation of the occiput by 2/8th of a circle, placing the occiput behind the symphysis pubis. There is always an accompanying movement of descent with internal rotation.

Torsion of the neck is an inevitable phenomenon during internal rotation of the head. The neck cannot withstand such a high degree of torsion, so the shoulders will rotate in the same direction to the extent of 1/8th of a circle, placing the shoulders in the oblique diameter with one-eighth of the torsion still left behind.

Restitution is the passive movement of the head due to the untwisting of the neck that occurred in internal rotation.

The specific cardinal movements of labour are:

* Engagement is the mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (in occiput presentation) passes through the pelvic inlet.

* Descent is a continuous process that is completed with the expulsion of the fetus.

* Flexion of the head occurs as soon as the descending head meets resistance from the pelvic floor/pelvic walls/cervix.

* Internal rotation is the mechanism by which the occiput gradually turns away from the transverse axis. Crowning occurs after internal rotation.

* Crowning occurs when the vulval outlet is stretched by the maximum diameter of the head, and there is non-recession of the head after the contraction is over.

* Extension occurs when the flexed head reaches the vulva.

* Restitution is the passive movement of the head due to the untwisting of the neck that occurred in internal rotation.

* External rotation is the visible movement of the delivered head occurring due to internal rotation of the shoulders.

* Expulsion is the process by which the anterior shoulder comes under the pubic symphysis to be delivered and is followed by the posterior shoulder and the rest of the fetal body.

questions.text: 156. A child presents with a 5-day history of sudden-onset high-grade fever, skin rash, body aches, and myalgia. Laboratory tests show a low platelet count and elevated hematocrit. The tourniquet test is positive. Which of the following is not a criterion for severe disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture indicates dengue fever with warning signs, in which mucosal bleeding is classified as a warning sign, but is not considered a severe disease.

Dengue fever is an acute illness presenting with fever, muscle and joint pain, and a rash. Severe dengue is characterized by issues with blood clotting and plasma leakage from capillaries. Criteria for severe dengue:

* Severe plasma leakage - the loss of volume leads to shock (DSS), and the accumulated fluid leads to respiratory distress

* Clinical signs of severe bleeding 

* Severe organ impairment - elevated liver enzymes, decline in consciousness

Dengue fever is an acute illness presenting with fever, muscle and joint pain, and a rash. Severe dengue is characterized by issues with blood clotting and plasma leakage from capillaries.

Dengue infection progresses through three distinct phases:

* Febrile phase- It lasts 2-7 days, presents with a sudden onset of high-grade fever, often accompanied by facial flushing, skin erythema, body aches, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.

* Critical phase- It is characterized by bleeding and shock, marked by a drop in platelet count and an increase in hematocrit, indicative of capillary leak.

* Recovery phase- After 24-48 hours in the critical phase, patients enter the recovery phase. During this period, general well-being improves, appetite returns, gastrointestinal symptoms subside, hemodynamic status stabilizes, and diuresis begins.

questions.text: 157. A 60-year-old man presented with resting tremors, slowness of movements, and a festinating gait. A clinical diagnosis of paralysis agitans was made. He, however, died later on due to other causes. At autopsy, a section of his brain was taken. What is true regarding the marked structure in this patient compared to that of normal individuals?

choices.text: Accumulation of synuclein and reduction in pigmentation
Accumulation of synuclein and increase in pigmentation
Accumulation of tau-proteins and reduction in pigmentation
Accumulation of tau-proteins  and increase in pigmentation

questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra with the accumulation of synuclein and reduction in pigmentation is seen in Parkinson's disease (paralysis agitans) compared to normal individuals.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Note: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease but is per se not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

questions.text: 158. While performing a Purkinje image test in a patient having a mature cataract, you notice only 3 images. Which of the following images are absent in this patient?

choices.text: Erect image formed by anterior surface of the lens
Erect image formed by posterior surface of the lens
Inverted image formed by anterior surface of the lens
Inverted image formed by posterior surface of the lens

questions.solution:
Image 4 i.e Inverted image formed by the Posterior surface of the lens is absent in patients with mature cataract.

Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje–Sanson images.

Normal 4 images are formed from four different reflecting surfaces i.e.

* Image 1—Anterior surface of the cornea: Erect

* Image 2—Posterior surface of the cornea: Erect

* Image 3—Anterior surface of the lens: Erect

* Image 4—Posterior surface of the lens: Inverted



* In aphakia: Image 3 and Image 4 are absent.

questions.text:
159. Match the following:

Disease | Defect 1. Leukocyte adhesion defect | a. Defect in tyrosine kinase 2. Bruton's agammaglobulinemia | b. Deficiency of CD40L 3. Hyper IgM syndrome | c. Adenosine deaminase deficiency 4. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) | d. Absence of CD18
questions.solution:
The correct answer is - Disease | Defect 1. Leukocyte adhesion defect | d. Absence of CD18 2. Bruton's agammaglobulinemia | a. Defect in tyrosine kinase 3. Hyper IgM syndrome | b. Deficiency of CD40L 4. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) | c. Adenosine deaminase deficiency

Leukocyte adhesion defect is due to the absence of CD18 (an integrin), which is necessary for the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium. Thus, leukocytes can't migrate out of the blood vessels to the sites of inflammation.

Bruton's X-linked agammaglobulinemia is due to a defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK), which is required for the maturation of pre-B cells. Thus, the defect leads to the arrest of maturation of pre-B cells and a decrease in the number of mature B cells.

Hyper IgM syndrome is due to a deficiency of CD40L on T-cells. B-cells have CD40 on their surface, which interacts with CD40L on T-cells to undergo class switching from IgM to various other classes (IgG, IgA, IgE) depending on the type of antigen. Thus, failure of this class switching leads to an increase in IgM and a decrease in other classes of antibodies.

SCID is due to many defects, but the most common cause of an autosomal recessive form of SCID is the deficiency of the adenosine deaminase enzyme. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of adenosine derivatives inside the cell, which is toxic to them. Since lymphocytes are rapidly dividing cells, they are most affected by them, leading to immunodeficiency.

questions.text: 160. The brain CT scan of a 42-year-old man shows multiple punctate calcifications and two cystic lesions in the brain parenchyma with surrounding edema. A fecal examination reveals round eggs as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely mode of infection in this condition?

choices.text: Ingestion of fruit contaminated with cow manure

questions.solution:
The CT scan with multiple punctate calcifications and cystic lesions in brain tissue suggests neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium, and autoinfection in a human is the most likely mode of infection among the given options. Autoinfection in T. solium may occur if eggs derived from his or her own feces are ingested.

T. solium mainly causes two forms of infection in humans:

* Intestinal taeniasis: Adult tapeworms in the intestine. It results when raw or undercooked meats containing the cysticerci are ingested. Intestinal taeniasis may be asymptomatic with the passage of proglottids in the feces.

* Cysticercosis: Larval forms in the tissues. It results from ingestion of T.solium eggs- either by auto-infection or by ingestion of human feces contaminated food, or water. In cysticercosis, the cysticerci are most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or eye.

Neurocysticercosis is the most common form of cysticercosis, presenting with seizures, symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, including headache, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, dizziness, ataxia, or confusion. Papilledema may develop secondary to hydrocephalus. Cysticerci may even cause chronic meningitis or arachnoiditis, hemorrhages, or strokes.

Diagnosis:

* Fecal examination shows eggs of Taenia, but species identification requires examination of proglottids.

* Histologic demonstration of the parasite from a biopsy of a brain or spinal cord lesion

* Fundoscopic visualization of subretinal cysticercus

* Demonstration of a scolex within a cystic lesion on CT or MRI. Findings include cystic lesions with or without enhancement (e.g., ring enhancement), nodular calcifications, focal enhancing lesions, or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Treatment:

* Intestinal T. solium infection - single dose of praziquantel.

* Neurocysticercosis - anti-epileptic drugs, antiparasitic drugs like albendazole or praziquantel, high-dose glucocorticoids.

* For hydrocephalus, removal of cysticercus by endoscopic surgery may be done.

Other options:

Option B: Exposure to dogs can lead to a Hydatid cyst caused by Echinococcosis granulosus.

Option D: Ingestion of fruit contaminated with cow manure would lead to intestinal taeniasis due to Taenia saginata.

questions.text: 161. A preterm neonate born 1 week ago presents with an inability to tolerate feeds and abdominal distention. He is admitted in the NICU and is not responding well to the treatment. An X-ray of the abdomen is taken, which is shown below. Based on the radiological findings, what stage of the suspected disease is this child currently in?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture, along with radiological findings, is indicative of pneumoperitoneum, which is seen in Stage IIIB necrotizing enterocolitis, as per Bell's staging. 

The findings in the given X-ray include the clear visualization of bowel loops (Rigler sign) and a distinct diaphragm, which point to the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity. In addition, the football sign is also seen.

Necrotising enterocolitis is an emergency in neonates, with a mean incidence in neonates born between 30-32 weeks of gestation. Prematurity is the greatest risk factor and contributes to microbial invasion, hypoxia, and mucosal damage due to inflammation. Genetic variations in toll-like receptor-4, IL-4α, and IL-16 may also contribute to the pathophysiology of the disease.

The Bell's staging classifies the disease, based on symptoms and signs, into 3 stages: Stage I (suspected), Stage II (definite), and Stage III (advanced) Stage | Abdominal signs | Systemic signs | Radiology | Management IA | Abdominal distension, occult blood | Unstable temperature, apnea, low heart rate | Normal, mild ileus | Nil per oral, Antibiotics for 3 IB | IA + Gross blood | Same as IA | Same as IA | Same as IA IIA | Signs in I with absent bowel sounds, abdominal tenderness | Same as IA | Pneumatosis intestinalis, ileus | Nil per oral, Antibiotics for 7-10 days IIB | IIA with abdominal cellulitis and mass | IA with metabolic acidoses and thrombocytopenia | IIA with portal venous gas, mild/no ascites | Nil per oral, Antibiotics for 14 days IIIA | IIB signs with peritonitis and marked abdominal distension | IIB with hypotension, respiratory acidosis, DIC, and neutropenia | IIB with definite ascites | IIB with an ionotropic ventilator and paracentesis IIIB | Same as IIIA | Same as IIIA | IIIA with pneumoperitoneum | IIIA with surgery

On X-ray, the following signs are seen in pneumoperitoneum:

Bowel-related signs:

* Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible

* Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of the bowel or between two loops of the bowel and the abdominal wall

Peritoneal ligament–related signs:

* Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments

* Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas outlines the lateral umbilical ligament

Right upper quadrant signs:

* Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline, seen on chest x-ray

* Fissure for ligamentum teres sign

* Morrison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch

questions.text: 162. A 24-year-old male presented with fever and burning micturition and was started on nitrofurantoin 3 days back. Now he presents with jaundice, and on investigation, the peripheral smear showed heinz bodies and spherocytes. The pathway affected in this disease occurs at which site of the cell?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a patient suffering from G6PD deficiency, which is the rate-limiting enzyme of the HMP shunt pathway that occurs in the cytoplasm of the liver.

The HMP shunt pathway/pentose phosphate pathway has oxidative and non-oxidative phases. The oxidative pathway provides a major portion of the body's NADPH, which functions as a biochemical reductant. It also produces pentose phosphate, which is required for nucleotide biosynthesis. In the non-oxidative phase, pentose phosphate is converted to intermediates of glycolysis.

Abnormalities in the HMP shunt pathway resulting from deficient or impaired enzyme function reduces NADPH production, which will result in oxidative injuries to the RBC‘s causing hemolysis. Episodic hemolysis is a characteristic feature of G6PD deficiency. The triggers for hemolysis include oxidative stress such as certain infections, fava beans, drugs like sulfonamides, antimalarials, nitrofurantoin. Patients are usually asymptomatic until any oxidant exposure. Patients can develop acute intravascular and extravascular hemolysis resulting in anemia, jaundice and hemoglobinuria.  On investigation peripheral smear shows spherocytes, bite cells and heinz bodies.

questions.text: 163. A patient with anemia undergoes a test on a blood sample and his results are shown in the image below. Which of the following characteristics are shown by the cells affected in this condition?

choices.text: High mechanical fragility; High osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility; Low osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility; High osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility; Low osmotic fragility

questions.solution:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility test, which is a screening test for thalassemia. The red blood cells in thalassemia will show a high mechanical fragility and low osmotic fragility.

The principle of NESTROFT is based on the low osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows:

* Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution.

* Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes.

* Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or lines.

Due to decreased osmotic fragility, the cells do not lyse in 0.36% saline solution. Therefore, if this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will not be visible.

Thalassemia can cause RBCs to become smaller and less flexible. This can make them more mechanically fragile.



Conditions that can cause increased mechanical fragility of RBCs:

* Sickle cell anemia

* Thalassemia

* Red blood cell membrane disorders

* G6PD deficiency

* Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

* Malaria

Conditions that can cause increased osmotic fragility of RBCs:

* Hereditary spherocytosis

* Elliptocytosis

* Ovalocytosis

* Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text:
164. A neurologist was observing the EEG waves in a patient who was awake with eyes closed. Which of the following conditions does not reduce the frequency of the waves seen?

EEG - Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
Diabetes mellitus causes hyperglycemia, which increases the frequency of alpha waves. Alpha waves are seen in patients who are awake, with their eyes closed.

Alpha waves are seen in all healthy adults, mostly in the occipital region, followed by the frontal and parietal regions. They are in the frequency range of 8 to 13 cycles/min with a voltage of 50µV and are seen in an awake, quiet, and relaxed state. In times of increased concentration, alpha waves are replaced by beta waves. This phenomenon is called the alpha block, also known as the alerting or arousal response. Deep sleep is characterized by the disappearance of the alpha waves. Alpha wave variations on the EEG can be due to the following reasons:-

* Age - The occipital lead shows a slow rhythm in infants and speeds up with age. Other leads, however, show a beta-like rhythm in infants. Adult-like waves are seen in adolescence.

* Drugs - Barbiturates, antipsychotics, alcohol, amphetamines, and phenytoin are responsible for the reduction in frequency of alpha waves. An alpha-wave-like rhythm can be induced by propofol.

* Encephalopathies induced by toxins/metabolic abnormalities can reduce the frequency and magnitude of alpha waves. Hyponatremia and Vitamin B12 deficiency are also contributory factors. Conditions causing hyponatremia, like severe intractable diarrhea leading to volume loss, also have the same impact. (Option A)

* Low blood glucose, adrenal insufficiency (Option B), hypothermia (Option D), and a high PaCO2 decrease the frequency of alpha waves.

questions.text: 165. A postgraduate student in oncology studies a case of Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma, linked to a microorganism with the oncogenic Tax gene. What receptor facilitates its attachment?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma caused by the retrovirus HTLV-1, which expresses the oncogenic Tax gene. HTLV-1 infects CD4 T-cells by binding to GLUT1 receptors on these cells.

Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus type 1 (HTLV-1) is an oncogenic virus linked to cancers like Adult T-cell Leukemia/Lymphoma and cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, as well as tropical spastic paraparesis. It spreads through breast milk, sexual contact, and infected blood. The virus targets CD4 T-cells via the GLUT1 receptor and expresses the Tax gene, which drives its oncogenic capabilities.

Other options:

Option A: CR2 (CD21) receptor is essential for EBV infection of B-lymphocytes. EBV is linked to Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option C: Alpha 2-6 sialic acid receptors are specific to the human influenza virus and are found abundantly on the epithelium of the human upper respiratory tract; however, these receptors are not linked to any malignancies.

Option D: Intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) is a receptor utilized by rhinoviruses, which are the most common cause of the common cold. Additionally, it is not linked to any malignancies.

questions.text: 166. A 62-year-old hypertensive male with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine checkup. He smokes 10 cigarettes/day and has a BMI of 32 kg/m². His father had a stroke at 65 years. Which of the following is the most effective primary preventive strategy to reduce his risk of ischemic stroke?

choices.text: Lifestyle advice for smoking cessation only
Screen for carotid artery stenosis with doppler

questions.solution:
The most effective primary preventive strategy to reduce the risk of stroke is strict control of blood pressure of the patient.

Hypertension is the strongest risk factor for stroke. Adequate control reduces both incidence and recurrence of stroke. WHO has defined stroke as rapidly developed clinical signs of focal disturbance of cerebral function; lasting more than 24 hours with no apparent cause other than vascular origin. The 24-hour threshold is mentioned to rule out a transient ischemic attack.

Risk factors of ischemic stroke include are classified as: Non-modifiable risk factors | Modifiable risk factors Age - The incidence of stroke rises with age. 

Sex - Men display a higher incidence compared to women at all ages.

Genetic predisposition /family history

Previous history of stroke or TIA | Hypertension - Hypertension is considered the single most important risk factor for cerebral thrombosis as well as cerebral hemorrhage.

Diabetes

Smoking

Dyslipidemia and obesity

The prevention of stroke can be achieved at different levels - 

Primordial prevention involves preventing the emergence of risk factors, which includes health education on a healthy diet, exercise, and population-wide salt reduction, while Primary prevention involves controlling risk factors in susceptible individuals before disease occurs. Includes hypertension control( most important), diabetes and dyslipidemia management, smoking cessation, and weight reduction.

Secondary prevention is early diagnosis and prompt treatment to prevent complications. Includes early detection of TIA and aggressive treatment, screening, and management of carotid stenosis in selected high-risk patients, while tertiary prevention involves reducing disability, preventing recurrences, and improving rehabilitation. Includes rehabilitation with physiotherapy, speech therapy, and occupational therapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Aspirin is used to treat cases of stroke. Hence, it comes under secondary prevention after TIA/ stroke.

Option C: Smoking cessation is important but has less impact than BP control when considered singly.

Option D: Carotid Doppler screening is not recommended for the general population- only for selected high-risk cases.

questions.text: 167. Histopathological examination of a lymph node is as seen below. Which of the following condition does this pathology represent?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a granuloma formed by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleate giant cells, and surrounded by lymphocytes, as illustrated below. This is an example of Type IV or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.



Type IV or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction:

* Seen with persistent or nondegradable antigens, such as tubercle bacilli in lungs or other tissues. Infiltrate is dominated by macrophages over a period of 2 or 3 weeks.

* With sustained activation, macrophages often undergo a morphologic transformation into epithelioid cells (large epithelium-like cells with abundant cytoplasm).

* A microscopic aggregation of epithelioid cells, usually surrounded by a collar of lymphocytes, is referred to as a granuloma.

* This pattern of inflammation, called granulomatous inflammation, is typically associated with strong TH1-cell activation and high-level production of cytokines such as IFN-γ.

questions.text:
168. A 28-year-old male with tendon xanthoma and premature coronary artery disease is found to have elevated LDL levels and normal TG. Which apoprotein defect can cause this condition?

LDL- Low-density lipoprotein

TG- Triglyceride
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) with normal TG and premature coronary artery disease points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia, which occurs due to a defect in the Apo B100 protein.

Familial hypercholesterolemia  (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. Apo B-100 acts as a ligand for the LDL (low-density lipoprotein) receptor for the uptake of LDL. A mutation in the apo B100 or LDL receptor, therefore, can cause this condition. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk of developing atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of Familial hypercholesterolemia:

* Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.

* Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over the Achilles tendon and the dorsum of the hands.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

* LDL > 190 mg/dl

* Family history of hypercholesterolemia 

* Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum, respectively.





Other options:

Option A: Apolipoprotein C-II is a lipoprotein lipase cofactor that catalyses the cleavage of chylomicrons. Deficiency of apo C-II can cause hypertriacylglycerolemia.

Option C: Apo B48 is involved in the assembly of chylomicrons. Defects in this protein are not associated with familial hypercholesterolemia.

Option D: Apo A1 activates lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT). LCAT is the enzyme present in HDL, which is activated by apo A1. LCAT converts free cholesterol in HDL to cholesterol ester(hydrophobic). The initial discoidal shape now becomes spherical. This facilitates reverse cholesterol transport.

questions.text: 169. A 32-year-old woman with 2 months of amenorrhea presents with painless vaginal bleeding. She has a history of dilatation and curettage for a miscarriage 6 months ago. Her urine pregnancy test is positive but ultrasonography shows an empty uterus and no gestational sac was found in the adnexa. On further investigation, it is suspected that embryo implantation has occurred in the cervical canal below the internal os. Which of the following criteria would you use for the diagnosis in this type of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The given presentation is suggestive of cervical pregnancy, Rubin's criteria are used for the diagnosis, in these cases.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where implantation occurs in the cervical canal at or below the internal os. Thinning and distension of the cervical canal occurs due to erosion of the walls by the trophoblasts. The morbidity and mortality is high due to profuse bleeding.

Paalman and McElin: Clinical diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy:

*

Uterine bleeding without cramping pain following a period of amenorrhea

*

A soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus

*

Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix

*

A closed internal cervical os

*

A partially opened external cervical os.

The incidence of cervical pregnancies appears to be rising because of artificial reproductive techniques, especially in-vitro fertilization and embryo transfer. A risk factor unique to cervical pregnancy is a history of dilatation and curettage in a prior pregnancy.

Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:

* Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria) and Rubin's criteria (Histological criteria)

* Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria

* Primary abdominal: Studdiford's criteria

Other option: Rotterdam's criteria are not related to ectopic pregnancies; it is used as diagnostic criteria for PCOS.

questions.text: 170. A 40-year-old patient undergoes routine chest radiography in a hospital. The radiology department needs to dispose of the used X-ray film developing solution. How should the waste be managed?
questions.solution:
Liquid chemical wastes like X-ray film developing solution should be collected in a yellow bin and sent to the effluent treatment system for neutralization.

The biomedical waste management rule applies to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose of, and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorized and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors, namely yellow, red, white, and blue, is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then treated by various methods. They are:

* Incineration - This is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single-chamber incinerator

* Chemical disinfection - Chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes

* Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam, and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process 

* Microwave irradiation - Microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely

* Land disposal - They are of two types: open dumps and sanitary landfills. Healthcare waste should always be disposed of in sanitary landfills

* Inertization - It involves mixing waste with cement and other substances like lime to minimise leaks of hazardous substances contained in the waste

* Plasma pyrolysis

Other options:

Option A: Plasma pyrolysis is used for human anatomical wastes, soiled wastes, and expired medicines. But for X-ray developer/fixer solutions, it must be treated in an effluent treatment plant first. Plasma pyrolysis is a thermal treatment technology where plasma(ionised gas) breaks down organic matter.

Option B: Blue bin is for glassware and metallic implants. The contents of the blue bin are treated by autoclave/microwave for disinfection. Then they are sent for recycling after shredding or mutilation.

Option D: Black bin is used for general municipal wastes and sent to the municipal disposal system. It is not used for biomedical waste management.
