questions.text: 171. A 6-year-old girl was rescued from a neglected household. The girl was in severe malnutrition and was therefore fed high-calorie meals at the rehabilitation home. She developed confusion and seizures. Investigations revealed that her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels were low. These electrolyte abnormalities are due to excessive administration of ____.
questions.solution:
The child in this case is suffering from refeeding syndrome, and her serum phosphate, potassium, and magnesium levels are low due to the increased serum insulin levels, which in turn is caused due to the excessive administration of carbohydrates.

The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia after the cellular uptake of phosphate during the 1st week of starting refeeding.

Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral alimentation. 

When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant increase in serum insulin levels may produce the following:

* Hypophosphatemia (hallmark)

* Hypokalemia

* Hypomagnesemia

Hypophosphatemia can produce the following manifestations:

* Cardiac: Hypotension, Decreased stroke volume

* Respiratory: Impaired diaphragm contractility, Dyspnea, Respiratory failure

* Neurologic: Paresthesia, Weakness, Confusion, Disorientation, Lethargy, Areflexic paralysis, Seizures, Coma

* Hematologic: Leukocyte dysfunction, Hemolysis, Thrombocytopenia

A controlled transition over 3 days is recommended by the WHO for treating malnutrition, to prevent refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: 172. A term neonate, 12 hours old, was born to a mother with foul-smelling liquor. The baby is otherwise active and feeding well. What is the next best step according to the neonatal sepsis protocol among the given options?

choices.text: Wait for culture report to start antibiotics
Stop breastfeeding to reduce infection risk

questions.solution:
The next best step would be to start empirical IV antibiotics.

The term neonate is 12 hours old, and hence comes under the early-onset sepsis window. The baby was born to a mother with foul-smelling liquor (extreme risk factor)and is currently asymptomatic. According to the neonatal sepsis protocol, blood culture should be sent and empirical antibiotics should be started if an extreme risk factor is present, even if the neonate is asymptomatic. The extreme risk factors include chorioamnionitis, foul-smelling liquor, and rupture of membranes > 72hours.

The other perinatal risk factors include spontaneous preterm labour, rupture of membranes < 72hours. If the neonate has just these non-extreme perinatal risk factors and is asymptomatic, close monitoring is enough, and IV antibiotics should be started only if symptoms develop.

If the neonate is symptomatic - lethargic or unresponsive, poor cry, hypothermia, vomiting, etc, blood culture should be sent and empirical antibiotics should be started immediately. Neonatal sepsis can be classified as follows: | Early-onset sepsis | Late-onset sepsis Presentation | Within the first 72 hours of life | After 72 hours of life Source of infection | Maternal genital tract | Nosocomial or community-acquired Manifestation | Respiratory distress and pneumonia | Septicemia, pneumonia, or meningitis



Other options:

Option A: If extreme risk factors are present, empirical IV antibiotics can be started with out waiting for culture report. 

Option B: Lumbar puncture is indicated only in symptomatic patients or if the blood culture comes out to be positive.

Option D: Breast milk provides antibodies and immune protection, reducing the neonate’s infection risk. Hence, breastfeeding should not be stopped in this case.

questions.text: 173. A 3-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with a cough, fever and dysphagia. On examination, there is inspiratory stridor, stiffness of the neck and a bulge is seen in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline. Which of the following is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The most likely site of the lesion is the area marked as 1 which is the pharynx.

The patient with cough, fever, dysphagia, inspiratory stridor with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall is likely to have a retropharyngeal abscess. Inspiratory stridor is seen in conditions involving the pharynx and supraglottis.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both. A few causes of inspiratory stridor include conditions like laryngomalacia and a retropharyngeal abscess, as in this case.

Biphasic stridor can be seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea. These include laryngeal papilloma and vocal cord palsy. Expiratory stridor is seen in the conditions involving the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi like bronchial foreign bodies and tracheal stenosis.

The image below describes the various types of stridor and the corresponding sites. Grading of stenosis is done using Cottle-Mayer classification.



Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It occurs due to suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to an infection involving the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.

Clinical features include dysphagia and difficulty in breathing due to the abscess obstructing the air and food passages, stridor and a croupy cough may be present. Torticollis develops, which manifests as neck stiffness and the head is kept extended. 

A bulge along the posterior pharyngeal wall is observed, usually seen on one side of the midline. An X-ray will reveal a widening of the prevertebral shadow. Gas may also be present.

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is tubercular and is the result of

* Caries of the cervical spine

* Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes.

Complications of a retropharyngeal abscess include:

* Airway obstruction

* Bronchial erosion

* Mediastinitis

* Sepsis

* Acute respiratory distress syndrome

* Cranial nerve palsies

* Esophageal perforation

* Erosion into carotid artery or jugular vein

* Meningoencephalitis

Treatment:

* Incision and drainage

* Antibiotics

* Tracheostomy if respiration is compromised.

* ATT if tubercular etiology is noted.

The image below depicts a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed by an x-ray (lateral view) of the soft tissues of the neck by the following findings:

* Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow

* Loss of cervical lordosis

* In an acute abscess, air-fluid levels can be seen.



Pearl PM1799: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials: Condition | Findings Croup | Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign Epiglottitis | Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign Diphtheria | Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane Foreign body aspiration | Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text:
174. Which of the following is correct?

Assertion: Chronic venous disease leads to venous ulceration.

Reason: Chronic venous disease leads to elevated venous pressure during standing, which normalises on ambulation, impairing oxygen exchange and delaying wound healing.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
The assertion is true, but the reason is false.

Chronic venous disease leads to venous ulceration, which is a true statement. At the microvascular level, chronic venous disease leads to changes in the dermal capillaries, including dilation and increased permeability. This allows proteins like fibrinogen to leak into surrounding tissues, where they convert into fibrin and form a cuff around blood vessels. These fibrin cuffs can hinder oxygen exchange and trap essential growth factors such as fibrinogen and α2-macroglobulin, ultimately delaying wound healing.

The reason stated in the question is a false statement because elevated venous pressure during standing, which normalises on ambulation, is a normal physiological phenomenon and does not impair oxygen exchange or delay wound healing. The correct reason for the assertion is that chronic venous disease leads to elevated venous pressure during standing, which does not fall during ambulation. This persistent high pressure impairs oxygen exchange, delays wound healing, and leads to venous ulceration.

Normally, during walking (ambulation), the calf muscle pump squeezes blood out of the deep veins, resulting in the fall of venous pressure at the ankle from 90 mmHg (standing) to 20-30 mmHg. In chronic venous insufficiency (valve incompetence or calf muscle pump failure), this pressure does not fall adequately during walking, leading to ambulatory venous hypertension and venous ulcers.

Another proposed mechanism involves neutrophils adhering to the capillary walls, leading to blockage and reduced blood flow in the skin. Prolonged venous pressure and capillary injury also cause red blood cells (RBCs) to leak out, with the breakdown of haemoglobin producing irritating substances. These lead to itching, skin damage, and a distinctive brown pigmentation. Along with the loss of subcutaneous fat, these changes result in a condition known as lipodermatosclerosis.

questions.text:
175. An elderly patient presented with tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, and visual hallucinations. On examination, mild cognitive impairment was noted. CSF analysis showed alpha-synuclein oligomers. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CSF- Cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the findings of alpha-synuclein in CSF, is suggestive of Lewy body dementia.

Lewy body dementia is the second most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. It is characterized by the protein deposition of Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra, limbic system, and cerebral cortex, comprising α-synuclein and ubiquitin. Thus, they are classified under synucleinopathies.

The image given below shows immunohistochemistry showing positive staining (brown) for alpha-synuclein of an intraneural Lewy-body:



The core clinical features are (the first three typically occur early and may persist throughout the course):

* Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.

* Recurrent visual hallucinations are typically well-formed and detailed.

* REM sleep behavior disorder may precede cognitive decline.

* One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rest tremor, rigidity).

* Sensitivity to neuroleptics - severe adverse reactions if treated with antipsychotics

Other features are mood disorders like depression, anxiety, and autonomic disturbances like orthostatic hypotension, and constipation.

The mainstay of treatment here is symptomatic management which includes cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine, galantamine, or donepezil), atypical antipsychotics, and SSRIs. Highly potent typical antipsychotics like haloperidol are contraindicated in this condition due to extreme neuroleptic sensitivity.

Pearl PM1864: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition | Features Alzheimer’s disease | * Insidious onset

* Short-term memory loss

* Language deficits and spatial disorientation

* Later, personality changes Vascular Dementia | * Stepwise decline

* Early executive dysfunction

* Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging Frontotemporal dementia

(Pick’s disease) | * Early personality changes

* Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors

* Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging Dementia with Lewy bodies | * Visual Hallucination

* Spontaneous parkinsonism

* Fluctuating cognition Normal-pressure hydrocephalus | * Gait abnormalities 

* Urinary Incontinence

* Dementia

* Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

(Prion disease) | * Behavioral changes

* Rapidly progressive

* Myoclonus and/or seizures

Pearl PM1780: Revised criteria for the clinical diagnosis of probable and possible dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)

* Essential for a diagnosis of DLB is dementia, defined as a progressive cognitive decline of sufficient magnitude to interfere with normal social or occupational functions, or with usual daily activities.

* Prominent or persistent memory impairment may not necessarily occur in the early stages but is usually evident with progression.

* Deficits on tests of attention, executive function, and visuoperceptual ability may be especially prominent and occur early.

Core clinical features (The first 3 typically occur early and may persist throughout the course.)

* Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.

* Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.

* REM sleep behavior disorder, which may precede cognitive decline.

* One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism: these are bradykinesia (defined as slowness of movement and decrement in amplitude or speed), rest tremor, or rigidity.

Supportive clinical features:

* Severe sensitivity to antipsychotic agents; postural instability; repeated falls; syncope or other transient episodes of unresponsiveness; severe autonomic dysfunction, e.g., constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence; hypersomnia; hyposmia; hallucinations in other modalities; systematized delusions; apathy, anxiety, and depression.

Indicative biomarkers

* Reduced dopamine transporter uptake in basal ganglia demonstrated by SPECT or PET.

* Abnormal (low uptake) 123iodine-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy.

* Polysomnographic confirmation of REM sleep without atonia.

Supportive biomarkers

* Relative preservation of medial temporal lobe structures on CT/MRI scan.

* Generalized low uptake on SPECT/PET perfusion/metabolism scan with reduced occipital activity ± the cingulate island sign on FDG-PET imaging.

* Prominent posterior slow-wave activity on EEG with periodic fluctuations in the pre-alpha/ theta range.

A. Probable DLB can be diagnosed if:

* Two or more core clinical features of DLB are present, with or without the presence of indicative biomarkers, or

* Only one core clinical feature is present, but with one or more indicative biomarkers

Note: Probable DLB should not be diagnosed on the basis of biomarkers alone

B. Possible DLB can be diagnosed if:

* Only one core clinical feature of DLB is present, with no indicative biomarker evidence, or

* One or more indicative biomarkers is present but there are no core clinical features.

Pearl PM0401: Delirium vs Dementia

Features | Delirium | Dementia Presentation | Hallmark is impaired consciousness | Loss of memory and intellectual abilities Commonly seen in | Children and elderly | Elderly Associated physical findings | * Acute medical illness 

* Autonomic dysfunction

* Abnormal EEG 

* Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) | * No medical illness

* Little autonomic dysfunction

* Normal EEG Psychological findings | * Impaired consciousness

* Illusion, delusion 

* Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) | * Normal consciousness

* Depressed mood 

* Personality changes in early stages in Pick’s disease 

* Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) Course | * Develops quickly

* Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning) | * Insidious-onset

* Progressive downhill course Etiology | * CNS disease (E.g: Huntington or Parkinson disease)

* CNS trauma

* CNS infection (E.g: Meningitis)

* Systemic disease (E.g., hepatic, cardiovascular)

* Substance abuse/withdrawal

* HIV infection

* Prescription drug overdose (E.g: atropine) | * Alzheimer's disease

* Vascular disease (15-30% of all dementias)

* CNS disease (E.g., Huntingtons or Parkinsons disease)

* CNS infection (HIV, Prion diseases)

* Lewy body dementia

* Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia) Treatment: | Treat the underlying medical cause | Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

questions.text:
176. Which of the following services is correctly covered under the SUMAN initiative?
* Free treatment for complications during normal or C-section delivery
* Comprehensive abortion care services in line with the MTP Act
* Cash incentive for every institutional delivery
* Grievance redressal system for denial of services
* Free specialist care for children up to 5 years of age
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are covered under the SUMAN initiative.

SUMAN (Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan) is a Government of India initiative launched in 2019 under NHM (National Health Mission). It aims to provide zero-cost, assured, dignified, and respectful quality health care. It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.

The beneficiaries include:

* All pregnant women

* Mothers up to 6 months postpartum

* Sick infants

Key Features:

* Free & assured services: At least 4 antenatal checkups, safe delivery, postnatal care,

* Comprehensive abortion care in line with the MTP Act. (Statement 2)

* Free referral transport and drop-back transport.

* Grievance redressal system to eliminate denial of care or mistreatment. (Statement 4)

* Promotes Respectful Maternity Care (RMC).

* Early initiation and support for breastfeeding

* Birth registration

* Post-partum services and counselling, including family planning

* Cashless management of delivery (normal/cesarean) complications (Statement 1)

* Free treatment for sick infants up to one year

* zero/birth dose vaccination.

Other statements:

Statement 3: Cash incentive for institutional delivery is not part of SUMAN. A cash incentive is provided to all pregnant women who undergo an institutional delivery under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY). The incentives under JSY are as follows: Category | Rural area | Urban area LPS | Mother package: 1400/- ASHA's package:600/- | Mother package: 1000/- ASHA's package:400/- HPS | Mother package: 700/- ASHA's package:600/- | Mother package: 600/- ASHA's package:400/-

Statement 5: Free specialist care for children up to 5 years of age is not covered under SUMAN. It covers sick infants up to 1 year of age, not older children. Specialist care for children up to 18 years is part of RBSK (Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram) and other child health components under RMNCH+A.

questions.text: 177. A 24-year-old girl with a maculopapular rash and positive anti-dsDNA antibodies underwent a renal biopsy due to declining renal function. The biopsy shows a membranous pattern with subepithelial deposits. Which class of the lesion does the biopsy represent?
questions.solution:
According to the clinical vignette and biopsy findings, a membranous pattern with subepithelial deposits is observed in Class V lupus nephritis.

Positive anti-dsDNA antibodies can be correlated with kidney involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The membranous pattern of nephropathy shown in the image below includes basement membrane thickening and a characteristic ‘spike and dome’ pattern on electron microscopy. In addition, subepithelial deposits are seen that can be better visualised using silver stains, as shown in the image below.



Lupus nephritis develops following the deposition of circulating immune complexes. These immune complexes are primarily constituted of DNA and anti-DNA, which trigger the complement pathway and lead to leukocyte invasion, activation of coagulation factors, and release of inflammatory mediators like cytokines and interleukins, thereby causing complement-mediated damage.

Proteinuria (most common), hematuria, different degrees of kidney injury, hypertension, and RBC casts in the urine are noted. Laboratory findings include the presence of anti-dsDNA antibodies and reduced complement levels.

Pearl PM1568: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class | Findings Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I) | Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy. Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II) | Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits Focal lupus nephritis (class III) | Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV) | The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy. Membranous lupus nephritis (class V) | Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI) | Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli

* Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli

* Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli

* Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus

* Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text: 178. A young female patient presented to the outpatient department with burning micturition and greenish-frothy vaginal discharge. Her past history revealed that she underwent mechanical heart valve replacement surgery and is currently undergoing warfarin therapy for transient ischemic attacks. She was started on a drug for her current complaints. The next day, she presents with complaints of excessive bleeding after a trivial injury. Which of the following drugs was most probably prescribed?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman with a mechanical valve undergoing warfarin therapy presenting with excessive bleeding is most likely due to the administration of the antibiotic metronidazole. The greenish, frothy vaginal discharge is characteristic of trichomoniasis.

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that inhibit the CYP2C9 enzyme, like metronidazole, reduce the metabolism of warfarin, enhancing its anticoagulant effect, which increases the risk of bleeding. Interactions with warfarin can be caused due to alterations in the absorption and metabolism of the drug, the circulating levels of clotting factors, and the state of the epithelial surface.

Reduced efficacy of warfarin:

* Decreased absorption - Conjugation with cholestyramine

* Increased clearance - CYP2C9 activation by drugs (barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin)

* Reduced circulating volume - Nephrotic syndrome

* Resistance - High vitamin K consumption, High circulating clotting factor levels in pregnancy

Increased efficacy:

* Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:

* Amiodarone

* Azole antifungals

* Cimetidine

* Clopidogrel

* Cotrimoxazole

* Disulfiram

* Isoniazid

* Metronidazole

* Fluoxetine

* Zafirlukast

Nystatin, amoxicillin, and clindamycin do not alter the effect of warfarin.

questions.text: 179. A 60-year-old female patient presented with the following finding. Her medical history includes hypertension for which she has been taking regular medications for the past 3 months. Which of the following medication is most likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows pitting pedal edema in a hypertensive patient. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) like amlodipine are most likely to be associated with peripheral edema.

The frequency of CCB- induced peripheral edema is both drug-specific (i.e more potent drugs like amlodipine will be associated with higher rates of developing edema) and dose-dependent (i.e incidence of edema increases with an increase in drug dosage and chronicity of its usage). It is more common among females.

CCB-induced peripheral edema occurs due to a disproportionate decrease in the arteriolar resistance than in the venous circulation, resulting in increased hydrostatic pressure in the precapillary circulation. This leads to a fluid shift into the interstitial compartment causing edema.

Treatment:

* Dose reduction.

* Interclass switching of CCB - switch to non-dihydropyridines like verapamil, and diltiazem.

* Addition of a venodilator - ACE inhibitor, ARBs, Nitrates.

* Others - compression stockings, avoiding prolonged upright position.

* Definitive treatment would be discontinuation of the CCB and switching to another class of antihypertensives.

Other options:

Option A: Common side effects of ACE inhibitors like enalapril include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dry cough, rashes, urticaria, dysgeusia, gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness.

Option B: Telmisartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARBs), causes adverse effects such as hypotension, hyperkalemia, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

Option D: Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide are hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, hypercalcemia, rashes, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

Pearl PM1223: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

Indication | Initial treatment of choice Hypertension alone or hypertension with diabetes/ cerebrovascular disease | ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D) Hypertension with coronary artery disease | ACEi/ ARB + beta blocker/CCB (A+B or A+C)

or

beta-blocker + diuretic (B+D)

or 

CCB+ diuretic/ beta-blocker (C+B or C+D) Hypertension with chronic kidney disease | ACEi/ARB + CCB/diuretic (A+C or A+D) Hypertension with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction | ACEI/ ARB + diuretic + beta-blocker (A+D+B) + SGLT2i Pregnancy | Labetalol, Nifedipine, methyldopa

ACEi – Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

ARB – Angiotensin II receptor blockers

CCB – Calcium Channel Blockers

SGLT2i – Sodium Glucose co-Transporter 2 inhibitors

Pearl PM1224: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

| Drugs | Contraindications Beta-blockers | Labetalol, esmolol, metoprolol | Heart block, systolic heart failure, asthma bradycardia Calcium channel blockers | Clevidipine, nicardipine | Advanced aortic stenosis D1 receptor agonist | Fenoldopam | Caution in glaucoma Vasodilators | Nitroglycerin | Pericardial tamponade Nitroprusside | Relatively contraindicated in liver failure and renal failure Hydralazine | CAD, RHD ACE inhibitors | Enalaprilat | History of angioedema Alpha-blocker | Phentolamine, Urapidil | Aortic stenosis, AV shunt Centrally acting sympatholytics | Clonidine | Severe AV block, sick-sinus syndrome

questions.text:
180. Which of the following statements are true regarding antrochoanal polyp?
* It is more common in older adults
* It grows posteriorly and may hang below the soft palate
* It usually arises from the maxillary sinus
* It is allergic in origin and recurrence is common
* It is usually multiple and bilateral
questions.solution:
Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoid masse of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum (Statement 3), comes out of it, and grows backward to the choana and nasal cavity and may hang below the soft palate (Statement 2).

It is usually infective in origin (Statement 4). It is usually single and unilateral (Statement 5) which are more commonly seen in children (Statement 1) and young adults.   | Antrochoanal Polyp | Ethmoidal Polyp Age | Young | Adults Etiology | Infective | Allergic / Multifactorial Numer | Single | Multiple Site | Unilateral | Bilateral Origin | Maxillary sinus | Ethmoidal Sinus, uncinate process, middle turbinate and middle meatus Growth | Grows posteriorly towards the choana. May hang back behind the soft palate in the pharynx | Grows anteriorly towards the nares Appearance | Trilobed with antral, nasal and choanal parts. | Small and grape-like masses Recurrence | Uncommon | Common Treatment | Endoscopic sinus surgery | Endoscopic sinus surgery

Pearl PM1297: Antrochoanal Polyp

* Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy

* Usually affects children

* Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum

* Clinical features:

* Usually single and unilateral

* Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana

* Mucoid nasal discharge

* Hyponasal voice

* Findings:

* Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy

* Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx

* Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.

* Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: 181. A 40-year-old man with a spinal cord injury shows rhythmic ankle plantar flexion after sudden dorsiflexion of the foot. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates clonus in a patient with spinal cord injury, which can be explained by decreased input to the Renshaw cell.

Clonus is defined as regular, rhythmic, repetitive involuntary muscle contractions of a part of a limb (ankle, patella) when an abrupt, sustained muscle stretch is given. It is seen in states of increased gamma motor neuron activity. When the muscle is stretched, muscle spindles send strong signals to the spinal cord, activating many motor neurons at once, causing the muscle to contract. It happens because muscle stretch reflexes are overactive due to upper motor neuron lesions. As the muscle contracts, the spindle stops firing — but since the stretch is still being applied, it starts firing again as soon as the muscle relaxes. This repeat cycle of stretch → contraction → relaxation causes the rhythmic movements seen in clonus. 

When the clonus is sustained for 5 or more beats, it is considered abnormal. In spinal cord injury, loss of descending cortical input disrupts Renshaw cell function. Since Renshaw cells normally inhibit alpha motor neurons, their reduced activity leads to unchecked motor neuron firing. This causes hyperactive muscle spindles to trigger repetitive, rhythmic muscle contractions—resulting in clonus. Clonus can be observed in conditions such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, stroke, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, epilepsy, and metabolic disorders like liver or kidney failure and hepatic encephalopathy. Immunosuppressants (azathioprine and corticosteroids), anticonvulsants ( primidone and levetiracetam), and tranquillisers (clonazepam) can be used in treatment.



Other options:

Option A: Activation of the Golgi tendon organ happens in an inverse stretch reflex. It involves relaxation of muscles when a strong stretch is applied to the muscle.

Option B: Inhibition of the alpha motor neuron will lead to decreased reflexes, not clonus.

Option D: Inhibition of the gamma motor neuron will lead to reduced reflexes, not clonus.

questions.text:
182. A young man is brought to you with a history of fasting for 5 days and complaints of lightheadedness and tremors. Which of the following are correctly matched with the substrates they utilise during prolonged starvation?
* Heart - Ketone bodies
* RBC - Glucose
* Liver - Ketone bodies
* Brain - Fatty acid
questions.solution:
During prolonged starvation, the organs correctly matched with the substrates they utilise are options 1 and 2, that is, the heart, which uses ketone bodies, and red blood cells (RBC), which use glucose.

During prolonged starvation, ketone bodies are the major fuel source for the heart. Muscles and adipose tissue also utilise ketone bodies during starvation.

RBCs lack mitochondria. Thiophorase is a mitochondrial enzyme, and hence RBCs cannot utilise ketone bodies, and so their source of energy during fed, fasting, and starving states is glucose only.

Other options:

Option 3: Thiophorase is absent in the liver; hence, ketone bodies are not utilised by the liver. Liver utilises fatty acids in the fed state and lactate, glycerol, and glucogenic amino acids in starvation.

Option 4: During prolonged starvation, ketone bodies are the major fuel source for the brain and other parts of the central nervous system. Fatty acids cannot cross the blood-brain barrier.

Pearl PM0735: Ketone body utilisation



1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: 183. A 45-year-old woman presented with abnormal uterine bleeding. The images below show the transverse section of the uterus and the histology of the specimen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of haemorrhage. The H&E-stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis is a condition caused by the ingrowth of the endometrial tissue into the uterine wall. The presence of endometrial glands and stroma with the uterine myometrium eventually leads to the thickening of the uterine wall.

Patients are usually multiparous women presenting most commonly with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB)- menorrhagia > dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. On per-vaginal examination, symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy is felt. On bimanual examination: Halban’s sign - Tender, softened uterus is seen.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. The uterus is symmetrically enlarged and rarely exceeds 14 weeks in size. Transvaginal ultrasonography(TVS) or MRI ( MRI is superior to USG in showing hypo or anechoic areas in the uterine wall) can be done. A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management of adenomyosis (because of menorrhagia). Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel-containing IUCD, Mirena, is tried in younger women.

Other options:

Option A: Leiomyomas are well-circumscribed, firm, whorled nodules within the myometrium, not diffuse enlargement. Histology would show bundles of smooth muscle cells.

Option B: Endometrial hyperplasia involves the proliferation of endometrial glands within the endometrium, not extending into the myometrium.

Option D: Endometriosis is endometrial glands/stroma outside the uterus(ovary, peritoneum, pouch of Douglas, etc.

questions.text: 184. A 55-year-old man with advanced pulmonary embolism develops sudden onset dyspnea and hypoxemia. Despite administering 100% oxygen, his arterial pO2 shows only partial improvement. Which of the following best explains this?
questions.solution:
Increased physiological dead space is the reason why his pO2 does not increase despite giving 100% oxygen.

Dead space is that part of the lung that is ventilated but not perfused. No gas exchange occurs here. Anatomical dead space is air in the conducting system (trachea, bronchi). This air is not available for exchange with the blood. Normally, it is 150 ml in adults, and it is fixed. It does not change with disease. Physiological dead space is anatomical dead space plus the alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused. This is increased in certain diseases, like pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism is a condition where the pulmonary arteries are blocked, causing ventilated alveoli to no longer receive blood flow. These alveoli contribute to increased physiological dead space because they are ventilated but not perfused. Hypoxemia occurs as less blood is available for exchange. Unlike a shunt, giving 100% oxygen does not fully normalize it.

Other options:

Option A: Anatomical dead space is fixed and does not change in cases of pulmonary embolism.

Option C: An increase in physiological shunt is seen in cases of pneumonia, atelectasis, and ARDS. The shunt is the part of the lung that is perfused but not ventilated. Blood passes through without being oxygenated.

Option D: Total alveolar ventilation is normal in pulmonary embolism. The problem here is ventilation-perfusion mismatch, not overall reduced ventilation.

questions.text: 185. A 12-year-old boy on recombinant growth hormone therapy presents with thigh pain and an antalgic gait. A hip radiograph confirms the diagnosis. Which clinical sign would most likely be positive?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and radiographic findings are consistent with Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE). The most relevant clinical sign in SCFE is Drehmann’s sign. Trethowan, Steel, and Capener’s signs are all radiographic findings of the condition.

SCFE is a hip disorder that typically occurs in adolescents aged 10 to 15, characterized by the displacement of the femoral head from the growth plate. It is commonly seen in those who are overweight, have osteodystrophy due to chronic renal failure, or have endocrine disorders like growth hormone therapy or hypothyroidism. Symptoms typically include pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.

Patients often exhibit an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait. Physical examination may reveal a shortened leg held in external rotation with limited abduction, flexion, and internal rotation. A key finding is Drehmann's sign, where hip flexion causes obligate external rotation and abduction.

Radiographic findings include:

* Trethowan sign (Option A): When Klein's line is drawn on an AP pelvis X-ray along the superior femoral neck, it normally intersects the femoral head epiphysis. A positive Trethowan sign occurs when it does not intersect, indicating SCFE and serving as an early marker for the condition.

* Steel sign (Option B): also known as a double-density sign, on an AP radiograph, indicates posterior displacement of the femoral head epiphysis, confirming SCFE and posterior slippage.

* Capener's sign (Option C), which shows a loss of crescent overlap between the posterior acetabulum and lateral metaphysis as the condition deteriorates.

questions.text: 186. A 7-month-old child with acute diarrhea is being treated with oral rehydration solution (ORS). Which of the following is correct regarding zinc supplementation in this child?
questions.solution:
A 7-month-old child being treated for acute diarrhea should be supplemented with oral zinc at 20 mg/day for 10-14 days.

Zinc administration for diarrhea management can significantly reduce mortality and hospital admission. In addition, it improves diarrhea recovery rates and reduces the inappropriate use of antimicrobials.

Zinc supplementation is usually done for 10 to 14 days. The dosage is age-dependent as follows:

Age <6 months: 10 mg/day

Age >6 months:  20 mg/day

Pearl PM1883: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool. Age | Amount <2 years | 50–100 mL 2-10 years | 100–200 mL >10 years | As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration Age | First, give 30 mL/kg in | Followed by 70 mL/kg in | Total 100 mL/kg in Infants (under 12 months) | 1 hr | 5 hrs | 6 hrs Older | 30 min | 2½ hrs | 3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

Pearl PM1884: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition | Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) | ReSoMal (mmol/L) Glucose | 75 | 125 Sodium | 75 | 45 Potassium | 20 | 40 Chloride | 65 | 70 Citrate | 10 | 7 Magnesium | --- | 3 Zinc | --- | 0.3 Copper | --- | 0.045 Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) | 245 | 300

Symptoms | No or minimal dehydration | Mild to moderate dehydration | Severe dehydration Loss of body weight | <3% | 3–9% | >9% Mental status | Well; alert | Fatigued or irritable | Lethargic or unconscious Thirst | Drinks normally | Thirsty; eager to drink | Drinks poorly Heart rate | Normal | Normal to increased | Tachycardia Quality of pulse | Normal | Normal to decreased | Weak, thready or impalpable Skin turgor test | Instant recoil | Recoil in <2 sec | Recoil in >2 sec Capillary refill | Normal | Prolonged | Prolonged

questions.text: 187. A baby is brought to the outpatient department for the facial defect shown in the given image. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is not included in Millard's criteria to undertake surgical repair of this condition?

choices.text: Child's age should not exceed 10 months
Child should be minimum 10 weeks old

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. 

Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for a cleft lip:

* 10 pounds in weight

* 10 weeks old

* 10 g% Hemoglobin

Millard cleft lip repair is done by rotating the local nasolabial flaps. Cleft lip repair is preferably done between 3 to 6 months of age.

A cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can vary in severity from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both nostrils. There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors. 

A cleft palate can occur in the primary palate (anterior cleft) or in the secondary palate (posterior palate). A Complete cleft palate involves both the primary and secondary palate. An incomplete cleft palate involves only the secondary palate.  

In the bilateral complete cleft palate, a Y-shaped cleft is seen with gaps between the primary and secondary palate and between the two halves of the secondary palate. In addition, there is a bilateral cleft upper lip. 

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:



* Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement

* Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement

* Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate

* Bilateral cleft lip and palate

* Cleft palate only

Pearl PM1952: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

* Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

* Soft and hard palate - Two operations

* Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months

* Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

* Bilateral - Two operations

* Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months

* Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

* Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

*

Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

*

Orthodontic management

- Mixed dentition - 8–10 years - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

*

Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: 188. A 50-year-old man with a 30-year history of type 1 diabetes on intensive insulin therapy presents with sudden confusion and slurred speech while watching TV. His caregiver notes no sweating or palpitations. Capillary blood glucose level is 45 mg/dl. On further questioning, the caregiver reports he had multiple similar episodes in the past. Which of the following best explains the symptoms?
questions.solution:
This elderly man with long-standing type 1 diabetes on intensive insulin therapy presents with recurrent episodes of neuroglycopenic symptoms (confusion, slurred speech) without preceding autonomic warning signs such as sweating or palpitations. His capillary blood glucose is very low (45mg/dl), yet he did not experience adrenergic manifestations. This clinical feature is typical of hypoglycemic unawareness.

Hypoglycemic unawareness, a condition that occurs in patients with recurrent hypoglycemia, especially in those with long-standing diabetes (diabetic neuropathy). Repeated episodes blunt the sympathoadrenal response, leading to loss of warning symptoms and placing patients at higher risk for severe hypoglycemia with abrupt neuroglycopenia.

Other adverse effects of insulin therapy include:

* Hypoglycemia

* Weight gain

* Lipodystrophy at injection sites 

* Hypokalemia -insulin drives K+ into cells 

* Allergic reactions

* Insulin edema 

Other options: 

Option C: Beta-blockers can blunt adrenergic warning signs of hypoglycemia, such as palpitations, tremors, and anxiety, by blocking β-adrenergic receptors. However, sweating usually persists because it is cholinergically mediated. In this patient, even sweating is absent, suggesting a loss of the entire sympathoadrenal response. Moreover,beta-blockers alone would not explain multiple recurrent episodes of severe hypoglycemia.

Option A and D: Somogyi and Dawn phenomenon cause hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

Pearl PM0992: Dawn Phenomenon and Somogyi Phenomenon

| Dawn phenomenon | Somogyi phenomenon Features | Early morning hyperglycaemia | Early morning hyperglycaemia | Normal blood glucose levels at 3 am | Hypoglycaemia at 3 am Mechanism | Early morning surge in growth hormone and cortisol which causes hyperglycemia | Excessive night basal insulin dose > hypoglycemia in middle of night > triggers the release of counterregulatory hormones which causes hyperglycemia. Treatment | Increase nighttime long-acting insulin dose | Decrease night time long-acting insulin dose

questions.text: 189. A woman presents with a sudden-onset headache a few days after the symptoms of right eyelid drooping, a dilated right pupil that is poorly reactive to light, and an eye deviated down and out. Which of the following is the most likely location of an aneurysm causing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The most likely location of an aneurysm causing the symptoms of sudden onset headache due to rupture and features of third nerve palsy (right eyelid drooping, dilated right pupil that is poorly reactive to light, down and out deviation of eye) is the junction of posterior communicating artery-internal carotid artery that is marked as 3.

The course of the third cranial (oculomotor)nerve is such that it passes between the superior cerebellar and posterior cerebral arteries, then moves forward through the interpeduncular cistern, alongside the posterior communicating artery, to reach the cavernous sinus. Thus, an aneurysm at the posterior communicating artery and internal carotid artery junction is most likely to compress the third cranial nerve, causing the symptoms.

Berry(saccular) aneurysms arise at the bifurcation of large to medium-sized intracranial arteries, and they rupture into the subarachnoid space in the basal cistern. The image given below represents the sites of berry aneurysm:



Other options:

Option A: An aneurysm at the anterior communicating artery-Anterior cerebral artery junction (marked by 1)presents with visual field defects.

Option B: An expanding aneurysm at the middle cerebral artery (marked by 2)may cause pain behind the eye or in the lower temple region.

Option C: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm (marked by 4)presents with posterior cervical pain and occipital headache.

questions.text: 190. Secretion of all the hormones are decreased in section of pituitary stalk except
questions.solution:
Unlike other pituitary hormones, prolactin secretion is primarily under inhibitory control by the hypothalamus. The key inhibitor is dopamine, also known as prolactin-inhibiting hormone (PIH), which travels from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary via the hypophyseal portal circulation.

When the pituitary stalk is transected (due to trauma, tumors, or surgery), the delivery of hypothalamic hormones to the anterior pituitary is disrupted. This leads to a decrease in all anterior pituitary hormones except prolactin, which increases due to the loss of dopaminergic inhibition.

Consequently, prolactin is the only anterior pituitary hormone that increases after pituitary stalk section. 

The hypothalamus regulates the anterior pituitary through hypophysiotropic hormones transported via the hypophyseal portal system:

* Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH): Stimulates ACTH

* Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH): Stimulates TSH (and mildly prolactin)

* Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH): Stimulates GH

* Somatostatin: Inhibits GH and TSH

* Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH): Stimulates FSH and LH

* Dopamine (Prolactin-inhibiting hormone): Inhibits prolactin

Effects of Stalk Section:

The interruption of stimulatory hormones leads to a decrease in their respective pituitary hormones, whereas the removal of dopamine inhibition results in unopposed prolactin secretion. This phenomenon is clinically known as the "stalk effect." Mildly elevated prolactin in the presence of other low pituitary hormones can indicate hypothalamic or stalk compression, such as by a craniopharyngioma. 

Although often associated with the pituitary, vasopressin (ADH), oxytocin are produced in the supraoptic nucleus and in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, respectively. These hormones are transported via axons through the pituitary stalk and stored in the posterior pituitary.

If the stalk is severed above the posterior pituitary, initially, there is a decrease in ADH and oxytocin secretion due to disrupted transport. Over time, some recovery may occur through alternative axonal sprouting or compensatory mechanisms.

questions.text: 191. A child presents with esodeviation of one eye, which is worse during near work. It is fully correctable by the use of convex spectacles. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the given scenario of esodeviation of one eye, worse during near work, and fully correctable by the use of convex spectacles is refractive accommodative esotropia.

Accommodative esotropia occurs due to excessive convergence linked to the accommodation reflex. Accommodative esotropia is now recognised as the most common childhood squint, surpassing congenital esotropia. It typically develops around 2–3 years of age and is classified into three types: refractive, non-refractive, and mixed.

Refractive accommodative esotropia is caused by high hypermetropia (+4D to + 7D). Here, the AC/A (accommodative convergence to accommodation)ratio is normal. Deviation is seen for both near and distance, and is fully correctable with convex spectacles.

Other options:

Option A: Non-refractive accommodative esotropia is caused by an abnormally high AC/A ratio. It can occur even without any refractive error. Esotropia is more pronounced at near than at distance (often minimal or no deviation at distance). Therefore, a bifocal lens with + 3 D for near vision is necessary to reduce the accommodative effort when focusing on near objects, thereby reducing convergence and esotropia.

Option C: Mixed accommodative esotropia results from a combination of hypermetropia and a high AC/A ratio. Distance esotropia improves with full hyperopic correction. Any residual near esotropia is managed by adding a +3.00 DS lens for near work.

Option D: Infantile esotropia (previously known as congenital esotropia) typically begins between 2 and 4 months of age. The angle of deviation is usually large and constant, often greater than 35 degrees. Binocular vision fails to develop, and infants show alternate fixation in primary gaze with cross fixation in side gazes. Surgical correction is ideally performed between 6 months and 2 years of age to support normal binocular vision development.

questions.text: 192. A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with pain, redness and decreased vision in both eyes. Examination revealed raised IOP, slit lamp shows rubeosis iridis, and gonioscopy reveals fibrovascular tissue blocking the angle of the anterior chamber. Which type of secondary glaucoma does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a diabetic patient with raised IOP and rubeosis iridis is suggestive of neovascular glaucoma. 

Neovascular glaucoma is an intractable glaucoma caused by neovascularisation of iris and the angle of anterior chamber. It develops due to retinal ischemia, which is commonly seen in

* Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

* Central retinal vein occlusion

* Eales disease

Three stages of neovascular glaucoma include

* Pre-glaucomatous stage: New vessel formation on the iris(rubeosis iridis) occurs at this stage.

* Open-angle glaucoma stage: Formation of fibrovascular membrane over the trabecular meshwork, leading to aqueous outflow blockage.

* Secondary angle-closure glaucoma: Contraction of the fibrovascular membrane causes peripheral anterior synechiae.

Anti-VEGF agents, panretinal photocoagulation and cryotherapy is done to prevent further neovascularisation. Then the raised intraocular pressure can be controlled by trabeculectomy, along with antifibroblastic agents or an anterior chamber drainage implant

Other options:

Option A: Inflammatory glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma that occurs due to the inflammation of the uveal tissue. It is characterised by features of acute/chronic iridocyclitis with raised IOP.

Option C: Glaucoma capsulare or Pseudoexfoliative glaucoma is a secondary glaucoma that occurs in pseudoexfoliation syndrome, where a grey dandruff-like material deposits on the pupillary border, anterior lens surface, iris, zonules and ciliary processes.

Option D: Uveitic glaucoma is a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma that occurs due to swelling and dysfunction of the endothelial cells or infiltration and obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by inflammatory materials. It is the same as that of inflammatory glaucoma.

questions.text: 193. A lesion in which of the following structures leads to decreased aggressiveness, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality, without memory disturbance?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario can be caused by a lesion in the amygdaloid nucleus, marked as 3.

Bilateral or unilateral lesions in the amygdala and para-amygdaloid region result in the behavioural features described — classically part of Klüver-Bucy syndrome — which include:

* Reduced aggression and fear

* Emotional instability

* Increased oral tendencies and hyperphagia

* Hypersexuality

* Restlessness

Notably, memory remains intact unless adjacent medial temporal structures (like the hippocampus) are also damaged.

The amygdala is an almond-shaped cluster of nuclei located anterior and superior to the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, closely related to the tail of the caudate nucleus. It has two main subdivisions:

* Basolateral group (involved in emotion and sensory input integration)

* Corticomedial group (linked to olfactory and hypothalamic pathways)

Given below is the image of the limbic system:



Other options:

Option A: The hypothalamus is a part of the diencephalon that extends from the optic chiasma anteriorly to the caudal border of the mammillary bodies posteriorly. Dysfunction can result in hypoplasia/atrophy, diabetes insipidus, obesity, sleep disturbances, irregular fever, and emaciation.

Option B: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, rounded, hemispherical structures located posterior to the tuber cinereum, on the inferior surface of the hypothalamus. Atrophy here is associated with Wernicke's Encephalopathy, often linked to chronic thiamine deficiency.

Option D: The hippocampus is a curved elevation of gray matter that runs along the entire length of the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. A small hippocampus is seen in Medial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy, characterised by common aura, intractable seizures, postictal disorientation, behavioural arrest, memory loss, complex automatisms, dysphasia (dominant hemisphere focus), and unilateral posturing.

questions.text: 194. A 22-year-old woman is brought to the hospital after she received the news that her father was hospitalised following an accident. She is immobile, mute, and unresponsive for several hours. She has had recurrent episodes of mutism and unresponsiveness in the past 6 months, each after a distressing family event. Electroencephalogram and lab testing are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dissociative stupor is the most likely diagnosis.

Dissociative stupor is a condition where a person suddenly stops moving or speaking, appearing as if in a stupor, without any medical or neurological cause. Key features include multiple/recurrent episodes of reduced or absent voluntary movements, minimal or no speech. The patient is conscious, but appears unresponsive. It is often associated with psychological stress or trauma.

Other options:

Option A: Catatonia is seen in schizophrenia. It is characterised by mutism and stupor along with posturing (voluntary assumption of bizarre postures), negativism, and waxy flexibility.

Option C: Depersonalization is a dissociative condition characterized by a sensation of being disconnected from oneself, often feeling as though one is watching their own body or thoughts from an external perspective. Here, the patient is aware of his surroundings, does not completely believe in the delusional change, and describes it as an “as-if” phenomenon. There is no mutism or complete unresponsiveness. 

Option D: Conversion disorder usually consists of specific motor/ sensory deficits. Motor symptoms like paralysis, gait abnormalities, and sensory symptoms like numbness or blindness.

questions.text: 195. A 60kg patient receives 300mg of drug A intravenously. Plasma concentration thirty minutes later is 3mg/L. If 30mg of the drug was eliminated during this time, what is the approximate volume of distribution?
questions.solution:
Based on the given parameters, the volume of distribution would be 90L.

The volume of distribution is given by the formula:



In the given scenario, 300mg of drug A was administered intravenously. But 30mg of the drug was eliminated. Hence, the amount of drug in the body is 300 - 30 = 270. The plasma concentration is 3mg/L. Substituting the values: V = 270/3 = 90L.

Volume of distribution is a theoretical volume that describes how a drug distributes in the body relative to the plasma concentration. Low volume of distribution means the drug stays in the plasma, and high volume of distribution means the drug distributes into tissues. Clinical uses of volume of distribution include calculating the loading dose, adjusting the dose in special conditions like obesity, edema, etc.

questions.text: 196. A 56-year-old female presents with a 2-year history of gradually worsening vision in both eyes. She also complains of seeing glare and halos in the morning, which disappear later in the day. On slit lamp examination, ‘beaten-metal’ appearance on the posterior surface of the cornea, with associated stromal oedema, is seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with 'beaten metal' appearance on slit lamp, is suggestive of Fuch’s endothelial dystrophy.

Fuchs’ endothelial corneal dystrophy is a slowly progressive, bilateral condition that affects females more than males and is caused by changes in the endothelium. These changes lead to the formation of small, drop-like deposits on the Descemet’s membrane called cornea guttata. Over time, these guttata can lead to the atrophy of endothelial cells.

As the disease progresses, these changes result in a diffuse oedema of the stroma and epithelium, which is clinically visible. Patients often complain of halos around lights in the morning that disappear as the day goes on. This is due to the massaging effect of blinking and evaporation, which helps reduce the swelling temporarily.

In advanced stages, the periodic rupture of the epithelial bullae can be painful and lead to secondary infections. Eventually, the entire cornea becomes opaque and insensitive.

Initial management is done by using hypertonic saline drops or ointment to help reduce the oedema. Definitive treatment is by penetrating keratoplasty.

Other options:

Option A:  Lattice dystrophy is a stromal dystrophy of the cornea. The classic form of lattice corneal dystrophy has an autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene. It is characterised by recurrent corneal erosions at the end of the first decade of age. Histopathology in lattice corneal dystrophy will show the deposition of amyloid in the stroma. These deposits stain with congo red and exhibit apple-green birefringence on polarised microscopy.



Option B: Macular corneal dystrophy is a stromal dystrophy of the cornea that shows deposition of mucopolysaccharide glycosaminoglycan in the stroma. Clinical examination shows macules, that is, superficial, elevated, irregular whitish opacities.

Option D: Granular corneal dystrophy is characterised by discrete opacities in the corneal stroma. These deposits are bilaterally symmetric and most dense centrally with clear intervening stroma.

questions.text:
197. A young rugby player during one of his games sustained a severe blow to the chest and lost consciousness. The medical team could not palpate the pulse and connected an AED, which showed the rhythm given below. What is the diagnosis?

AED - Automated external defibrillator
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with an ECG showing ventricular fibrillation, points to a diagnosis of commotio cordis.

Commotio cordis is an electrical abnormality in a structurally normal heart, which is seen following non-penetrating chest wall injury, such as during sporting events like rugby, football, and hockey, or following motor vehicle accidents. When chest wall trauma with ample force is incurred during the susceptible phase of repolarization, i.e., just before the peak of the T-wave, it can cause commotio cordis. The patient presents with ventricular fibrillation, which is closely followed by cardiac arrest. Therefore, prompt defibrillation is vital in such cases. 

ECG findings include fibrillatory waves, as seen in the image above, which may be coarse or fine based on the amplitude of the wave. If untreated for prolonged periods, the coarse fibrillatory waves are converted to fine waves, eventually leading to asystole.

Other options:

Option A: Ventricular tachycardia is a wide complex tachycardia, which is defined as ≥ 3 successive premature ventricular complexes (PVCs) at ≥100 beats/min. 

Option B: Torsades de pointes is seen as QT prolongation with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Gradual variation in QRS polarity and amplitude in different leads is seen, with twisting around the baseline with the changing QRS axis. 

Option D: Atrial fibrillation is an atrial tachycardia caused by abnormal automatic firing along with various re-entry circuits around the atria. On the ECG, QRS waves are irregular with the presence of fibrillation waves without P waves. The image below shows atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
198. A 59-year-old man presented with complaints of abdominal pain and fever for the past 2 days. Examination shows palmar erythema, testicular atrophy, and distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness. Shifting dullness is present. His vital signs and laboratory findings are given below. He has a history of alcohol consumption for the past 30 years. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

Vitals and laboratory findings: * BP: 138/90 mmHg * Pulse: 93 bpm * Temp: 101.8 F * WBC: 12,500/mm3
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards liver cirrhosis with ascites. The raised temperature and the increased WBC count are most likely due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Paracentesis and ascitic fluid analysis is the next best step in the management of this patient.

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Abdominal paracentesis within 12 hours of admission is the investigation of choice. The diagnosis of SBP is made when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

Infection with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp. can also be found.

Management: The first line of empirical treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin or a combination of beta-lactam/beta-lactamase agents. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, prophylactic antibiotics are given to prevent a recurrence.

Other options:

Option A: Liver biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of liver cirrhosis. It determines the grading of inflammation and staging of fibrosis of the liver. Ultrasonography, CT, and MRI are not sensitive to detecting liver cirrhosis. It is not the next best step for this patient.

Option B: The administration of fluids is not the best next step for this patient.

Option D: Administration of furosemide and spironolactone is done for the treatment of ascites along with dietary restrictions. However, the patient has a fever and abdominal pain, which is a concern for SBP, for which diuresis is not indicated.

questions.text: 199. Which of the following images shows a gastric ulcer at a location where vagotomy is not indicated, according to the modified Johnson anatomic classification?
questions.solution:
Images 1 and 4 show an ulcer on the lesser curvature at incisura, which corresponds to type Ⅰ, and an ulcer high on the lesser curvature, which corresponds to type Ⅳ gastric ulcer, respectively, according to the modified Johnson anatomic classification, for which vagotomy is not indicated. 

Gastric ulcers are caused by decreased defensive factors, increased destructive factors, or both. Damaging factors include hydrochloric acid secretion, pepsins, ethanol ingestion, smoking, duodenal reflux of bile, ischemia, NSAIDs, hypoxia, and H.pylori infection. 

It can occur at any location in the stomach, with the most common location being the lesser curvature near the incisura. They constitute 60% of the total and are classified as type I(image 1). These are usually not associated with excessive acid secretion and may present with low/normal acid output. 

Type II(image 2) ulcers are located in the body of the stomach in combination with a duodenal ulcer. Type III(image 3) is prepyloric in location. Both these types are associated with excessive acid production. Type IV gastric ulcers(image 4) occur high on the lesser curvature near the GEJ(Gastroesophageal junction). They are quite uncommon and not associated with hypersecretion of acid. Type V ulcers can occur at any location, but their association is with NSAID abuse. 

The following table shows the modified Johnson’s classification for gastric ulcers - TYPE | LOCATION | ACID LEVEL Type Ⅰ | Lesser curve at incisura | Low to normal Type Ⅱ | Gastric body with a duodenal ulcer | Increased Type Ⅲ | Prepyloric | Increased Type Ⅳ | High on the lesser curve | Normal Type Ⅴ | Anywhere | Normal, NSAID-induced

Diagnosis in the first place should differentiate the benign causes from the malignant etiology, and treatment changes accordingly. Acid-reducing procedures like Vagotomy are reserved for cases with type II and III gastric ulcers. Types I and IV ulcers with normal acid levels usually don’t benefit from acid-reducing vagotomy. 

Medical management basically includes anti-H. pylori drugs, acid-reducing drugs that decrease the acid secretion/neutralize the acidity, and drugs that increase the mucosal protection mechanism. Antacids like magnesium are the best buffers but cause diarrhea, and phosphorus components cause constipation. Newer modalities include H2-antagonists and PPIs. 

Sucralfate is an aluminium salt of sucrose that dissociates under acidic conditions, and the sucrose polymerizes to bind to the ulcer crater and produce a protective coating. It lasts for 6 hours. Acid reduction surgeries are generally reserved for intractable conditions.

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine. The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows:

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

questions.text:
200. A man brings his 4-year-old son to the OPD claiming that he was bit by an insect shown in the image below. The child may suffer from which of the following diseases?
* Q fever
* Rocky Mountain spotted fever
* Colorado tick fever
* Relapsing fever
* Tularaemia
questions.solution:
The given image is of a hard tick. Among the given options, the diseases transmitted by hard ticks are Rocky Mountain spotted fever, Colorado tick fever, and tularaemia.

Hard ticks are covered by a chitinous shield on their dorsal surface, which is called the scutum. They have a head or capitulum present at the anterior end, which is visible from above. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks:

* Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)

* Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)

* Viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever)

* Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g., Kyasanur Forest disease in India)

* Tularaemia

* Tick paralysis

* Human babesiosis.

Diseases transmitted by soft ticks:

* Q fever

* Relapsing fever

* Kyasanur Forest disease

An image of a soft tick is shown below:



Pearl PM1684: Ticks

* The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.

* The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
